review_title: Fast paced environment with timed opportunities.
pros: Compensation was excellent and a lot of flexibility.  The motto I recall and strived for was pay for performance/results.  Over my 11 years there, I advanced many times and felt like a respected, knowledgeable and secure contributor.  Excellent annual review process and rating system ranking highly successful each year with compensation and bonus to match.
cons: I can deal with change and in fact, advocate for it; however, in my last few years at Aetna and specifically the individual plan I worked for, the direction and leadership was just murky.  It was like turn left, no go right, I said left, we need a U turn.  All of this occurred over a short period of time.  Some of this came all the way from the top at Aetna while other directives were necessitated from the state and etc.  The work seemed to pile on more and more and found myself working late into the nights and weekends.  Burnout was inevitable.  I witnessed many mergers, reassignments and the dreaded  lay offs over my time there.  Layoffs were always something swift and unspoken.  I never expected that one day, I too would suffer a similar outcome.  We lost a contract/RFP  bid that I had no part in delivering but was one of the several no longer needed.  It was devastating and still on my mind all this time later.  I will add that Aetna provides an excellent severance package based of what you made and length of service.

review_title: This company is too large and is very impersonal.
pros: Management appreciates hard work and will promote employees who can keep up with the workload and get good audit scores. Decent salary, and good PTO.. although you can't take PTO unexpectedly without getting an "occurrence" if you are an hourly employee.
cons: There are several things I do not like about this company. Like most companies with a claims department, the workload is unmanageable in a 40 hour work week. The expectations are very high, and so is the stress level.  Also, the disability benefit managers are hourly, which is unheard of in this industry. This means you cannot work even 15 minutes beyond your normal schedule without getting permission because this will be considered overtime pay. Because the disability benefit managers are hourly, they are subject to a different attendance policy than the salaried employees. Hourly employees get "occurrences" any time they are unexpectedly absent. If you get 4-5 occurrences in a rolling 12 month period, you can be put on probation. Therefore, I would not recommend this company to single parents, or parents of young children who are frequently ill. Additionally, the work space is not private. People sit in "quads" of 4 people and are almost completely open to one another with low cube walls. This is a very distracting work environment and can be very unprofessional when you are on the phone and it is very noisy in your work area. The health benefits are very poor for a primarily health insurance company with a very high deductible health plan with a health savings account.

pros:
- Ability to work at home

- Expensive medical benefits
- Too much emphasis on fluffy benefits.  Cut medical benefit costs instead.
- IT work is outsourced.  Job security in IT is nonexistent
- IT spends too much time on process and paperwork

review_title: No reason NOT to work for Aetna, but . . .
pros: Generous work-at-home and severance provisions.  Casual or business-casual dress in many locations (although I am told not so much at Hartford).  From what I see, Aetna deals with employees with fairness and integrity.  Salaries are market-reasonable, and the self-imposed $15 minimum wage is welcomed by people impacted by it.  Certainly no worries about the company's financial stability.   Senior management is socially liberal, but I do not see discrimination against employees who believe differently then they do.
cons: HR is outsourced, so an employee typically cannot just phone someone to ask a question.  IT has an oddly meeting-intensive culture.  Change control for small modifications is vast overkill.  Much of IT is outsourced to Asian consulting firms, and some of us are in the position of training our overseas replacements.  "Breakthrough inclusion" is coming to Aetna and whether that is good or bad depends upon one's worldview.  "Mindfulness" is promoted as unquestionable truth, although I doubt if there is any reprisal against people who decline to embrace it.  Higher management's social liberalism is encouraging or despairing depending upon one's worldview.

job_title: Applications Support Analyst in Fresno, CA
pros: I started with Aetna 10 years ago after losing my job in construction.  So the first pro is they gave me the opportunity to work for them with no obvious experience in the health care industry.  I worked through customer service on the phones and then applied to claims processing and am now an analyst.  The 2nd pro would be the freedom to transfer to other areas of the business, assuming you possess some aptitude for the job you are applying for.  The pay has always been decent and you get all of the standard benefits like 401k, dental, eye and health.
cons:
Oddly enough working for a health insurance company doesn't mean the best health insurance prices. Lol, so don't be surprised when you find out your insurance isn't free. Although, there are many health programs you can enroll in to get credits toward your premiums. There seems to be a high turnover rate for management so you are often exposed to a couple different management styles even within a year. My current position has me working on a pretty complex processing program and I often feel a lack of support (it doesn't help that I have been through 12 managers within a 2 year period).
I have to say, I'm not to excited about the exclusive employee engagement groups. Sure, you can join in with them but you are kind of excluded when you don't line up with the cultures or creeds of the of the groups that are available in that you don't fit in.

review_title: The company is OK but the local/regional management is out of touch and, for the most part, incompetent.
pros:
Aetna is a good company (overall) and they do try to do the right things for their customers, members and providers.  
If you're working in a large office there is some opportunity for internal promotion, otherwise career growth within the organization is limited.
Aetna's teleworkers make up about 30% of their workforce - which is great for employee flexibility, but some teleworkers may find themselves working many more hours when working from home than they would if they were in an office.
cons:
The company has too many internal barriers -- its hard for any employee to do their job well which negatively impacts customer service.  
The systems, policies and procedures are extremely complex and burdensome - reminiscent of the old "Ma Bell" phone company. 
Both local and regional senior management are extremely out of touch with the market and they are not prepared to act as a partner to our customers.
Local senior management demonstrates no business acumen, competency or management skills, rather the use of extremely divisive and disrespectful tactics are used to "motivate" an already frustrated and overworked staff.

They transfer calls that are confusing to them instead of trying to learn how to handle them. I even question the quality of the off shore supervisors because they seem to be just as clueless as the reps.

job_title: Manager, IT Project Management in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Good people; I worked on teams with high-quality, dedicated and helpful people.  Very competitive compensation and benefits package.  Flexible work situation (work from hope opportunities, fair work/life balance).
cons:
Annual layoffs were regular and widespread, even in the face of record revenues and profits, affecting solid (and even top) performers; this kept a large portion of the workforce living in fear for their jobs ... and of course led to low morale (and even lower employee engagement scores).  
Additionally, there was constant pressure to increase the span-of-control for management - so much so that it became commonplace for managers (regardless of performance levels) to be demoted into individual contributor roles ... this is a reprehensible practice that has been in place for several years, up to and including 2017. 
In the technology area, there was an obsession with high utilization rates (i.e. we were encouraged to maximize "billable" project hours, billable back to the lines of business), and an obsession with high allocation rates (i.e. if a resource appeared to be less than fully-allocated on a project, there was pressure to eliminate resources); this was another reprehensible practice which caused good managers to be constantly forced to justify their teams' impact and preserve their teams' jobs.   
All of these served to create extremely high attrition rates (due to involuntary and voluntary departures), which of course led to shortages of subject-matter experts, confusion and frustration for those that remained.

review_title: I've grown personally and professionally since working for Aetna
pros:
Aetna allows a lot of employees to work from home which is very convenient for employees with families, it also helps now that gas prices are so high.  

Aetna provides several tools to help employees further their careers.  

There are a lot of amentities in the Hartford, CT office such as a gym, a store, a pharmacy, a doctor on site, chair massages, vendors who come weekly and sell things (it's nice to take a break and shop duing the day!), financial planners you can meet with onsite and Aetna also offers many free workshops to it's employees for career AND personal growth such as parenting classes and personal financial workshops there are also many opportunities for volunteering and getting involved in the community.
cons:
If you don't park in the garage (Hartford, CT office) it's a far walk to the lots and there are always reports of people getting robbed/attacked. 

In my opinion, (I've only experienced this in my current dept. it may be different elsewhere) it's all about who you know and who likes/doesn't like you, promotions are never given based on actual work performance.  You'll get farther by "playing the game" and going along with whatever management says rather than having a mind of your own!

pros: Good Pay, Generous PTO, extensive training period (although not a lot can really be applied to the job itself)
cons: Insurance Benefits are rather inadequate considering Aetna is an INSURANCE company.  Micromanaging supervisors who care much more about numbers/adherence than they do the morale of their subordinates or thorough customer service.  Customer Service Reps in the Aetna Disability Department take calls back to back (about 60 calls a day).  85 percent of these callers are very angry, and rattling off at Customer Service asking to speak with their Claim Managers (who are, conveniently, NEVER available to speak with a Claimant about why their claims have been denied while they are suffering debilitating and life-threatening illnesses.  Customer Service Reps have to take constant verbal abuse due to Claim Manager/DBM Mistakes.  Also, Most Claim Managers work on the East Coast in Plantation Florida and Portland Maine.  So, what they do is just BEFORE they conveniently leave the office for the day, they call a claimant on the West Coast or mountain time zone, leave a generic message to call back customer service-then the Claimant Calls back demanding to know why their claim was denied (which a CSR is not allowed to discuss in detail) and to speak with their claim manager.   A very inefficient and upsetting business practice.

pros: Lots of positions offer work at home opportunities.
cons: The company is on a quest to become the largest healthcare company, and in doing so, doesn't care how this affects employees.  Many mergers and acquisitions which results in very frequent reorganizations and job elimination.  Employees are constantly worried about being let go, yet are told they must remain focused on their jobs and not about job elimination.  Morale is very low because of constantly worrying if your position will be the one to be eliminated next.  Benefits are the worst.  The medical insurance offered here is ridiculous, as  the only thing offered is a HDHP.  Constantly shoving their political views down your throat and send emails to employees asking for contributions to their political fund.  Also always shoving core values down your throat, but I have seen so much unethical behavior here that always goes unpunished.  Ridiculous.  Constantly boasting about earnings, but when it comes to bonuses, you never get your target regardless if you had a stellar performance review.  Many locations have gym/workout facilities but you must pay to use them, so not really a benefit, IMO.  They suck the life out of you if you are on salary, and you never get comp time for any extra hours worked.  But if you are hourly, they want more and more done in a 40 hour week and will not pay overtime to get these things done, nor hire additional employees.  Do yourself a favor and stay away and don't get involved.

pros: They are good to their work-at-home staff, and there are many opportunities to WAH.  My managers have also been 100% supportive of my growth and have maintained true open door policies.  Aetna is also committed to encouraging and enabling their employees to live healthier lives with various wellness incentives and reimbursements.  There is a really good fringe benefits package overall, even if the health insurance itself leaves something to be desired.
cons: It can be difficult to find other opportunities within the company, especially if one is in a smaller or specialized area such as EAP.  Many enterprise-wide systems aren't used in these specialty product divisions, and without that knowledge the chances to expand into other areas is VERY limited.  In regards to the health insurance mentioned earlier, we only have a choice between (basically) two high deductible health plans.  While I'm grateful for this option as a relatively healthy individual who has no chronic conditions, I resent not even having the choice to pay a higher premium with a lower out-of-pocket cost.  Also, more and more "perks" are being taken away, the most recent being the sudden decision to end the policy of offering more PTO to employees with 25+ years of service.  It felt like a punishment to the most loyal and enduring employees, and I'm not even one of them!

cons:
The benefits are god awful. Only PPO, no HMO, no idea what you will be paying out when going to provider's offices, picking up medications, etc. It's one big guessing game and HR doesn't know either, so you'll be wasting your time calling out to them.

They came into the state and decided to pull out of the state before the plan even  opened, so we are just waiting (im)patiently for the plan to fully close and we be out of jobs. 

9 weeks of pay will terminate if we do not accept a position (whatever is thrown at us first) within the company.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Middletown, CT
pros: PTO is ample.  Job security is better than average.  Working remotely is possible for most.
cons: Aetna is only a decent place to work if you're skilled at and more interested in organizational politics than you are in actually accomplishing productive work that makes a difference.  Aetna is a large org with many, many people in all layers of management constantly jockeying for position and working against one another instead of encouraging all departments to pull in the same direction to collaboratively accomplish good things.  If you are a software engineer worth your salt, do not work there.  Intelligence, hard work, and actual leadership skills are not recognized or rewarded.  People are only rewarded and advanced on the basis of how well they can navigate the internal politics.  It's also a technological wasteland.  You'll be siloed into a department with one, very narrow job function.  You'll rely on other uncooperative departments for everything else.  As a result, your skills will atrophy and you'll get restless.  The only hope you will have of avoiding this fate is to find a position within one of the company's few, more progressive divisions, but even then the problems of poor leadership and politics still apply.

review_title: Aetna - great place for personal growth and opportunity but....
pros: The building and campus are beautiful. The overall work environment is fine relative to other companies. Since Aetna is such a large company, there are always opportunities to change job role and function without having to leave the company.
cons:
The Hartford office location is terrible - the air is polluted and the campus is located on the edge of an urban blight zone; cars occassionally get stolen or damaged in the parking lots and one must walk from the parking lot through the ghetto (past the occassional bag-person and beggar) to get to and from the office - it's creepy, especially during the winter when one must walk to and from work in the dark! To add insult to injury - Aetna charges their employees to park in that mess! 

Recently, Aetna has apparently adopted a sexist, racist, agist philosphy for promotion to upper management positions - those who are over 40'ish, white male, non-ethnic need not apply! I am so sorry to see this happen.

I used to believe that senior management truely ascribed to the 'Aetna Way' but I don't any more. ...so sad - I keep hoping that I will see evidence that will change my mind.

review_title: Nothing to show for a job well done
pros: One thing Aetna does right is work life balance and flexible work accommodations.  About 40-50% of Aetna's work force are telecommuters.  And the health care benefits are pretty good and reasonably priced compared to other employers.
cons:
If you want to advance your career or move within the company, Aetna is not the place for you.  Once you are slotted in a particular job or function, it's very difficult to move around, unless you have connections and have senior managers who are willing to go to bat for you.  Aetna is notorious for being a very closed-door community.  Additionally, Aetna is known for frequent layoffs, reorgs and a revolving door of management.  Their overall strategy is constantly in flux.  There is no discipline to product development or management.  It seemed like a constant state of uncertainty.  Morale has been low for a long time.  There is a lot of posturing and land grabbing to make sure you're not on the outside looking in.

After being at Aetna for over a decade, I didn't have much to show for it.  Even after consistently stellar reviews and awards, my position was eliminated and I was out the door once the new leadership came on board.

This equation is 70% OJT, 20% informal training, and 10% formal (i.e, education, degree, college, graduate ed, etc)--WTF... Culture and Diversity is a joke. Health plans offered are worst in class and so is management. Bertolini is the worst CEO to date and needs to be fired!!! The company is penny wise and dollar foolish from the top down. No consideration is given to members, providers, employers, or employees. This company has a fake public face and a ugly internal face. DOJ, don't  approve any merger with Humana, I beg you!!!

pros:
Great wellness program - will pay back up to $250 for healthy initiative items such as gym memberships, workout equipment, and FitBits
Employee Life Assistance benefits - Tuition assistance, free therapy sessions (limited), and more
Offices located all over the US
cons:
Promises are made but not kept - multiple discussions for advancement in my area, but nothing has been completed
Turnover is high - My team has had three different managers in the past year
Not enough resources - company expects high results on limited resources (budget, personnel, technology)
IT relies too much on contractors - a lot of the IT work is outsourced
Job sites - there are offices all over, but unless you are at one of the "main" buildings (Hartford, Blue Bell), you will miss out on a lot of workplace benefits

job_title: Call Center Representative in Philadelphia, PA
pros: It’s a job but requires absolute clock
cons: It’s a job which serves clients

review_title: One of the best companies I have ever worked for hands down
pros: The pay was very good compared to some other health plans or call centers. Easy to get bonus checks which is nice extra income. Hours are flexible and no weekends until open enrollment with only Saturday and you choose how many hours you wanna come in on that Sat most of the time. Free breakfast and or free lunches or both on Sat if doing overtime ( at least when I was there). Nice managers who in a lot of cases at one time had the same position as a rep so they know the job entails. I loved my Sup as he was motivating and friendly to all on the floor. Excellent training! Great benefits with lots of choices and some free perks. If single your health ins is free. A wellness program that puts money towards your HSA. A new gym on site. Nice and friendly co-workers who seem to care about the kind of work they do
cons: Once a year mandatory overtime, usually lasting 2 to three months only. This is only during open enrollment with the market place and this was in my department so not sure if it is in all lines of business.

review_title: Good company to work for overall
pros: Stability, flexible work schedules, work at home opportunities, career advancement.  I have worked for the company 9 years and I have been able to work my way up through different jobs and titles.  It has not been hard to move up being a minority and a female. There are great mentoring programs, tuition reimbursement, wellness programs, 401k, stock, gym and showers on site, full cafeteria. Newer buildings and amenities. lots of online resources and communities for employees.
cons: 2 of the positions I have worked for did not have a good training structure which I would not have minded if the on the job training was structured.  The pay ranges are not listed when applying for jobs which makes it hard to know if you really want to go for certain positions.

pros: The option to work at home is honestly probably the only thing keeping as many employees as it is. So many of my teammates have admitted if it wasn't for that they'd be long gone. (Since most employees have kids and working at home makes it easier to take care of family business.)
cons:
There is zero work life balance. I haven't had any work life balance for the last 4 years but this is the worst it has ever been. Last week I was working 7am-1130pm just to get work done. Every single one of my teammates has been working overtime which we do not get paid for and yet we still get constant reminders from management that we are not getting enough work done. 
Also majority of the managers now are from the new business department so they could care less about you if you are from renewals. Nor are they willing to learn how it works. 

And you would think working for an insurance company the benefits would be great. Nope!

review_title: Great Team, Not So Great IT Organization
job_title: Business Analyst in Cranberry Twp, PA
pros:
I work for an awesome team that exemplifies team work, I feel very fortunate to be under the Senior Director that I am.  
Flex-time and the ability to work from home in inclement weather
Open door policy with my immediate supervisor
Decent bonuses
cons:
The likelihood of being promoted in IT is slim to none
If you're at the top of the pay scale for your position, there will be no raise. 
You're "graded" on a bell curve, BA's are compared to Developers and Architects, AND each director is normally allowed to give out one 5, one 4 and as many 3's as they want.  Even if you're a great performer, the likelihood of getting a 4 or 5 is pretty slim.
High deductible healthcare plan.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Increased work from home options.
Bonus pool for lower than senior leadership staff.
cons: Farmed out all of our IT staff and downsized many other departments after buy out.  Big talk about taking best practices from both companies, but that was definitely not true.  Extremely micro-managed by corporate.  They have their nose in everything, yet don't actually know the local business.  Most of the good (Coventry) local leadership have left & their replacements are worthless.  Local leadership has little to no control or input on their business. Corporate pulls all the puppet strings, leaving local talent frustrated or fired if they point out the flaws.  They've caused a solid, strong company to flounder because of  the "our way or the highway" mentality, won't take suggestion from the idiot locals on how to fix these problems, and blame us for all the mistakes they made.  It's such a shame to see true leaders lose their voice and a strong company go up in flames so quickly.

review_title: been at aetna for a year and the beginning was good, but as time went on I found that Aetna is not a place I want to be
job_title: Care Manager Associate in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: the pay. the pay is great, PTO is good.  you can work at home within a year or so which is amazing
cons: higher ups has been rude, there's no team work,  everyone is out for themselves. To much Gossiping,  team lead talks to us like we're their children, to much favoritism, they expect us to work. work, work but as soon as we talk were talked down to. supervisors always in a meeting that when there is a problem that need to be handled as far as provider issues we have to try to figure it out on your own.  Your time for breaks is constantly being monitored. If you are late from your breaks you will get an email from higher ups or team lead  advising you of this. this. This job is overwhelming and can be stressful

review_title: the belly of the beast is right there for those that choose to see it
job_title: Dishcarge Planning in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: when i went to aetna it fit all the criteria i needed to make my career and family life better- worked for a caring supervisor who stuck up for  her staff and would get you what ever support you needed- thought i was finally at the last job i would ever have- company culture seemed in line with my core values.  work at home was a perfect fit-or so i thought
cons: where do i start?  twice yearly right before thanksgiving and again right after the xmas holidays-there would be layoffs and working in that environment was torture to experience and watch- the company culture flowed one way after a while and you either got on board or were told if you don't like it here-you know where the door is..everyone is drinking the juice and if complaints were pennies?  we would all be walking around rich- cut to the bone, do more with less, treat employees as pretty much the furniture and remind people that they are lucky to have a job!

job_title: OA Senior Analyst in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
Aetna encourages a healthy lifestyle and allows time to volunteer and participate in giving time, money and service to the community. We are constantly trained and updated with technology. We have a very vibrant intranet system with a lot of great articles and information that helps employees to keep up to date with many different things. Bonus is good if your manager favors you. 
We have a very good CEO who is very innovative and keeps us informed as necessary.
cons: Some managers and supervisors give a bad rap to the name of Aetna by treating employees bad. They play favoritism, promote their friends and bring in their friends and family. Some of them have no management skills so they lack the necessary experience to maintain the department. This demotivate the department and results in the loss of skilled employees.

review_title: I got the training I wanted, however, lots of work w/o a lot of people working
pros: They are flexible with PTO time.  For Analysts, they have flexible hours which are fantastic, and they provide passes for public transportation.  They have a decent benefits spread including stock options.  They have current technology.  They give you surprise bonuses in lieu of competitive compensation.  They have high-profile clientele.
cons: My job was the type that is production driven with 30 monthly "audits" that are mainly done to avoid giving a performance bonus.  The co-workers do NOT support each other and/or work together.  A lot of very aggressive and mean-spirited behavior is practiced by some managers.  The workload is set up for "cherry picking" from electronic buckets of data.  Most people pick and choose the easiest work from the buckets leaving the lemons for their coworkers  knowing management won't call them on it.  If you're not on the east coast where the main offices are, there is little opportunity for promotion.

review_title: A company in flux, trying to find its way
pros: Good support from direct supervisors and managers, good training programs for employees.  Pay is average.
cons: No mingling of divisions, everything is in a silo.  You will not know the person in the division across the floor from you, so little opportunity to move between divisions.  Senior management has little interaction with field and makes decisions that ruin Aetna's competitive advantage.  Aetna will only play in areas they can make money in, so they are quick to pull products and service areas regardless of potential.  No waiting for a territory to develop over time here.  Very much a company of favoritism and a cover your butt mentality which leads to keeping things status quo.  Everything is about the stock price here, and shareholders return.  No job security and the worst and most expensive employee health benefits of any carrier.  Good place to get your training and experience and then leave.

review_title: Aetna does not reward loyalty or innovative thinking, but it does train its employees.
pros: Aetna does allow for some of it's employees to work at home which means it can be a great place for parents to work. Their training resources are great as is their internal communications. Can we a wonderful place to start out, especially if you are in one of the "schools" such as sales, actuarial, etc. People there do seem to like it and I know many people who have been there for 20+ years. People do buy into the ethics espoused in "the Aetna Way."
cons: Because of constant reorgs, people are terrified of losing their jobs. Pay raises are minimal, even with significant promotions. In Hartford everyone is recruited from various CT state colleges and there is very little diversity of thought. For people who stay 20+ years there is very little upward movement; even as people change jobs they tend to make lateral moves for tiny salary increases. Bigger salary increases are spent on recruitment from competitors, and loyalty is not rewarded.

pros: Flexible schedule, depends which department. Overtime is available. Yearly metabolic testing to help decrease your insurance premium. Quarterly bonus based on performance.
cons: Insurance benefits could be better: an 80/20 plan is ok but when you have high deductible/coinsurance 1800/3600, and $400 a year HRA/HSA does not help bridge the gap. Wellness perks is a joke, jump through hoops to get your money for HRA/HSA. Management creates unrealistic expectations when they have never done the job and freely express they were promoted behind the scenes. Management changes bonus structures on a whim and puts into effect immediately instead waiting for next quarter. They will hire management outside of company with no experience and place in training along side the peers they will manage instead of promoting a qualified personnel who knows the job, been doing the job and fluent in all systems used to perform the tasks and policy/procedures. Management encourages/rewards sloppy inaccurate production than the quality of work.

review_title: watch out at the end of the year
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Hartford, CT
pros: While it is a good company to work for as far as work life balance & work from home opportunities....
cons:
Come areas review the upcoming projects & budget and what may happen due to a pending merger, and they have the "job eliminations" at the end of November/December.

My manager's manager's manager gave me the news my job was being eliminated while I was on a vacation---really enjoyable time that day.  

To receive the compensation package they asked me to work another 3 weeks without telling my co-workers.  During this time I received my end of year performance review as if there wasn't any way I wasn't going to be there next year or get my bonus after the beginning of the year.

pros: Pay checks are always on time.
cons: Horrible leadership, horrible employees, HORRIBLE benefits, lack of resources, lack of opportunities, horrible pay.

pros: Paid time off is excellent. Use your time however you want or need for sick, vacation, and personal. Work from home is accepted and encouraged, and creates good work-life balance.
cons:
Too much reliance and spending on vendors and consultants. Technology is modern and cutting-edge, but no training or investment in employees to implement and support the technology will lead to failure.

Employees are kept in the dark on major decisions and long-term strategy and vision is not clear. Multiple reorganizations and job eliminations in the past few years. As a product of this, job responsibilities and departments can change very quickly, but it takes many months for HR details (reporting structure, title, salary, etc) to follow suit. What appear to be promotions end up being increased responsibility with no title change and no salary increase.

No support from HR, told to talk to your manager whose hands are often just as tied by upper management

Limited opportunity for advancement unless you are in headquarters in Hartford. Salaries are low and internal moves are capped at a percentage that will often not even bring you to the minimum of the salary range.

review_title: Major decline since CVS took over
job_title: Utilization Management Nurse Consultant in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Working from home BUT chained to computer
cons:
Excessive workload (2-3 times the expected volume for one individual)
Salary pay = mandated overtime on weekends & holidays
Restricting employees from seeking same level position changes
Managers that don't understand or care
Poor communication & training. You are solely responsible for knowing what is going on but with your workload, you don't have the time to read up
Team meetings that have no direction & end up being a chat session
Reduction in company match to 401k
Expensive benefits and high deductibles
1.5% or less annual raise. Bonus does not compensate
Very stressful place to work. 
I am looking for another job!

review_title: Steady advancement is possible if you search out opportunities and make your goals and qualifications known.
pros: Most employees are proud to work at Aetna.  The CEO's drive to impact health care and wellness, as well as making Aetna a Fortune Fifty company, inspire the staff to contribute toward those goals.
cons: Currently Aetna is integrating the Coventry tools and staff.  In such a large undertaking, the individual employee cannot be considered and  talented people have not be able to obtain an optimum position for their skills and background. Some of my peers are having to find other employment.

pros:
- Ability to work from home.
- Good learning opportunity for someone starting his or her career.
- Very dedicated employees.
- For someone in an analytics role, plenty of tools available.
cons:
Most of the cons are simply inherent to any company as large as Aetna:
- Severely understaffed, at least on the commercial and Medicare insurance side of the business. This was the case for all business units that I worked with - sales, finance, medical management, networks, marketing, compliance, IT, claims, etc.
- Extremely bureaucratic. It can take a very, very long time to get things done.
- Lots of "empire building."
- Constant reorganizations.
- Low morale. 
- Promotion is largely based on tenure rather than performance.

pros: Some positions are work from home. However, they're changing the work from home policy so some employees who are working from home, will have the rescended. Tuition reimbursement is great. Good health promotions - they want you to stay healthy.
cons: Very POOR management. MICRO-MANAGERS! Management concentrates on make money more than the quality of services being provided. Layoffs every 2 years. NO ROOM FOR GROWTH! It is so hard to get promoted or move to a different department. And if your department is short, they will block you from leaving the department. Not flexible when it comes to taking PTO. They limit the amount of employees that are out on PTO. So, it makes it really hard to use your time off. For it to be a health insurance company, the insurance is very high and the deductibles are almost not affordable.

review_title: Aetna employees feel unappreciated; Let's schedule a strike
pros: Technology is great, they attempt to provide us with all the newest technology possible. BE thankful for a job.
cons: We are a number bottom line. We need to get the member off the phones within 5-6 minutes or else we are penalized by being forced into working late hours.  The customer wants all the time needed to resolve their issue not 6 minutes.  The CEO is completely distant and we need an advocate to help us but everyone is afraid to stand up in fear they will loose their job.  Employees that have dedicated their life to aetna working over 15-30 years are forced to retire or want to because the company has drastically changed since Ron Williams has left.  The stress level is unreasonable, not a family friendly work environment.  They create programs to help you manage your life and advance your career but if you work on the telephones you really are not eligible to particpate because you are dedicated to answering the phones.  The work loads are not balanced.

review_title: It's a good job if you work for a good person!
pros: Aetna is a good company to work for. It has a good culture of trying to help make the world a healthier place. It also provides many resources for its employees to utilize such as internal social media sites where employees can communicate on different topics. Just recently the company increased its minimum wage to $16 per hour for all employees which helped out a lot of people.
cons: The biggest con here is that all of the great policies initiated by the company can be trumped  by your manager. For example, the company allows you to waive your lunch in case you need to leave work early but it's up to management if you can. Another example, the company encourages work from home but if your manager wants you in the office with them because they don't want to be home alone, you're stuck in the office.

review_title: It would be nice if they lived their values
job_title: Marketing Communications Account Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits (including onsite clinic, cafeteria, and gym); good pay; good 401(k) match; the feeling that you are helping others; opportunities for volunteering and getting involved.
cons: I think it depends on the department you're working for, but it really feels like many managers and team members don't live the corporate values (integrity, caring, etc.). Managers promote the worst, most toxic team members because those individuals are deemed effective even if they are not liked or respected by other team members. There was a complete lack of recognition of work/life balance, with people routinely working insane hours, including weekends.  It was difficult to get a straight answer about anything; eventually team members just took everything management said with a grain of salt, knowing that it was either untrue or likely to change at a moment's notice. In addition, the company is in a state of flux thanks to its recent acquisition by CVS, with changes happening on nearly a weekly basis. Between the lack of communication and the toxic workplace, working in my department was a pretty miserable experience. I got the impression it was different in other departments, though.

pros: WAH, Benefits (pro & con), excellent manager, ability to be a patient advocate in an insurance setting.  I love what I do and I'm good at it.
cons:
As Employee: Our benefits are expensive, raises and bonus are slim to none, when they come they do not cover the increase in expenses that occur each year.  Sadly feel like a disposable employee.  Layoffs usually around end of year holidays. 

Company VIPs probably don't have to call member service themselves.  Telephone prompts abysmal.  

As Aetna member: Getting questions answered about insurance coverage, I think it's geared to make people give up.  If you're sick and have to call Aetna, good luck to you.  Better to hire advocate on your behalf it may save one money in the long run to have an advocate working for you.

pros: At a time of economic difficulty in the U.S. it's good to be employed and Aetna is a paycheck with medical benefits.
cons: Aetna used to be a great company to work for. Now, either because of health care reform/Obama Care or maybe just the changes in leadership I wouldn't recommend Aetna as a choice for employment. The attitude of what they call senior management is one of almost disdain toward those who actually do the work. The subtle “sit down shut up and do as you’re told” atmosphere is prevalent among almost all management with no one to speak for or defend the employees. They’ve cut back drastically on the workforce and now require double and triple workloads for those left. In the mean time they’re hiring and training overseas and will eventually move most of the remaining jobs to off shore locations. If you’re just entering the work force Aetna may be an option to get some experience and training but don’t look to this company as a career move. You will most certainly be disappointed.

job_title: Complex Case Manager in South Jordan, UT
pros: Aetna is a large company which means there are many opportunities.  If you like working at home there are many opportunities to do that.  My 2nd and 3rd line supervisors both work at home.  I am hoping to go home in the next few months.
cons: Since so many people work at home there are many phone meetings.  I think that dilutes the interactions and makes it difficult to really get to know who you are working with.   I don't fine staff support to be very high.  For example Aetna took away all the amenities in the lunch room and took away our on site tech support person.  They lowered our budget for celebrations.  This lowers morale and a sense of office community.

review_title: Very corporate, no concerns for employee's personal lives
job_title: Employee Assistance Clinical Counselor in Austin, TX
pros:
This job pays fairly well and provides the opportunity to work from home. 

In some ways the job is easy in the sense that it can be monotonous and once you know how to use the computer programs that part becomes second nature. 

You accrue PTO 12hrs/month starting out.

Fairly good benefits overall, and domestic partners can be included.
cons:
The monotonous work is certainly also a con. 

It's very corporate, and while I'm sure every department is different, EAP has definitely become a place where they don't care about the individual employee. 

There is a push to treat employees equally instead of fairly, and some members have management have made it clear they don't even understand the difference. 

The medical insurance itself is shockingly expensive (high deductibles, $1600-1800 for an individual) working as an employee for the actual company. 

Lots of the company is 24/7 which may lead to an awful schedule you're stuck in.

review_title: Re-Hired and unimpressed.  Drastic change in culture and employee focus
pros: Aetna has a wide pool of talented employees who strive to provide the best service and care to their customers/members
cons:
As a rehire, the previous culture has drastically changed for the worse.  Aetna used to be focused on employee satisfaction and work life balance.  Now Aetna is focused on the bottom line and managing, not leading, the employees.  Aetna wants more for less; employees are expected to work long, uncompensated hours with no regard to work/life balance.  Since Ron Williams left Aetna, the upper leadership pays very little attention to the line workers, laying employees off (primarily minority groups), increasing costs of benefits, and paying less attention to the psyche and well being of it's employees.
My disappointment with current day Aetna is overwhelming.  I had expected to return to Aetna and retire however, the "promises" that were made during the interview process have turned out to be lies and misrepresentations and I am eagerly seeking additional opportunities external to Aetna.

job_title: Answer Team Consultant in Allentown, PA
pros: Aetna offers benefits that are not bad overall of course there is room for improvement on that front. As far as job specific, AAT is like the cream of the crop of call center jobs. At the end of the day you're on the phone, but the call volume is lower than other departments that take inbound calls. Management of the department is actually not bad. They actually care about making things better for their employees which is better than my previous position within the company.
cons:
Pay is not good for anyone in student loan debt.
Hard to move around the company. (Politics run rampant)
AAT is the crutch for other departments meaning they may loan you out to help other departments that can't meet their metrics.
Very little company defined Career Development.

pros: Decent 401K, telecommuting possible, healthy life styles program that reimburses for exercising. If you just need an income, it’s a job.
cons: Health insurance is so disappointing. Horrible management. Aetna is hiring new employees at $16 an hour instead of letting employees transfer internally. If you are married and have a spouse with a job and good health insurance this may be a decent place to work. If you are the breadwinner or you have goals and ambitions, look somewhere else. CEO speaks about mindfulness and exercise. Smh. Some people cannot leave their desks for hours at a time. He is so phony. For anyone coming in at $16 an hour, you will be glued to your computer/phone for hours. The emails to remind employees to get up and move for 5 minutes every hour are for management because no one else has that luxury. But everyone receives them so you are reminded just how far down you rank.

review_title: Great Flexibility, Some Great People, Below Market Pay
pros: The flexibility at Aetna is the best I've ever seen - the ability to work from home, and the limited travel make a home/life balance extremely easy to attain.  In addition, the people who I get to work with on a daily basis are exceptional.
cons: The flexibility comes at a price - Aetna seems to pay most of its employees well below market value compared to other companies.  Also, in a company of this magnitude, naturally there are a lot of people who keep their head down and skate by for years.  Finally, while management is trying to change the culture at Aetna, it seems more of window dressing.  A selfish, whiny, blameworthy culture is seemingly ingrained in a lot of the legacy employees.  It is going to be truly monumental to change the culture at a 160 year old company in a relatively antiquated industry.

review_title: Aetna life insurance is a detriment to society
job_title: Short Term Disability Case Manager in Plantation, FL
pros: Some benefits are good, some flexibility in schedule,  bonuses (if ceo is not blowing it on some random remarketing strategy in order to personalize it for his own delusion of grandeur), and cafeteria in building
cons: Aetna is only concerned about your typical beauracracy. With nepotism, cronyism, and favoritism, you'll find that climbing the latter is basically at the mercy of the warm and fuzzies upper management gets when they see your face, unless you're black, then affirmative action supercedes any competency anyone may have. For the record, i was promoted thrice in the 5 years i was there, it just was so unfortunate i saw others suffer, especially those i tried to help that merited the promotion through hard work. They have a dress down policy but discriminate against you when you do. If you are a veteran and have issues, they target and get rid of you. They make inept people managers based on how apathetic you are towards others. In other words, if they find that members of your team like you, they will not choose you for leadership unless you are their drinking buddy. Plantation aetna is a modern day slave ship and the fact that it's in Plantation Florida seems to be rather appropriate.

pros: The only pro's are the vacation time and a way to get into the health insurance industry.
cons: Well lets start with them saying they were using the 2018 corporate tax cut to pay for medicare advertising all year instead of increasing employee pay (The purpose of the tax cut, but at least they were honest with us this time) Low raises even for top performers (avg 2% for a top performer), Inadequate staffing (you do the job of 3-4 people and they call it "efficiency") , The health insurance you get are expensive or have really high deductibles, No real room for growth (if you move up sometimes you can't get the starting salary that they would give to a non-employee because its "too much of a percentage increase"). All the outsourcing.. everything seems to be getting outsourced.

review_title: Micromanaging RUN from Star Kids program
job_title: Clinical Care Manager in Grand Prairie, TX
pros: The pay was great. There were some good extra benefits that they offered. Office was located near where I lived.
cons: Micromanaging, Deceit, upon hiring we were told we would be working at home and after the time period we were supposed to wait before going home we were told it’s no longer an option.  Leadership was poor due to director that came in.  She came from hospital and has no experience of field work and expectations are unrealistic for a productive field worker.  There is a queue that you have to be in the office to answer incoming calls so many hours a week. Medical insurance deductible was incredibly high and difficult for me to meet for my child that has several medical needs. No specific areas for home visits everyone is expected to travel all 6 counties on the plan.

job_title: Customer Service Advocate in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Aetna does provide for some of better benefits that I have seen. In an age where the cost of coverage is constantly on the increase, and individuals are asked to may more of their share, at Aetna your share is pretty comparable to what it would be elsewhere.  As they are an insurance company you can find work in almost any state, and at any position.
cons: There are a couple of cons that I can give, that I can think of, and one would be the vacation table. You get an increase of your tine after being there for four years, but then there are no further increases until you are there 20 years. The other one that I can think of would be the salary. The hook here that they offer you a generous salary to start, but then the increases are not so generous.

review_title: Need for improved parent company intervention
job_title: LTC Case Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The company has a strong ethical framework for business practices. The core values for diversity, inclusion and innovation make it a very well rounded company to work for.
cons: As with many health care positions, the nurse/patient ratio creates a very heavy work load which makes it difficult to deliver the time and attention needed to every individual. Many of the supervisors and managers do not recognize the talents, skills and potential of each team member.There are not equal opportunities for all, especially if targeted by management. This decreases morale and the ability to improve. In any industry, every person should be given the opportunity to grow and improve.There was retaliation when attempting to take a stand with no assist from HR.  There was a disconnect between the parent company and it's subsidiaries .

pros: Large company, so you get the Fortune 500 benefit package. Career growth is available, and is clearly communicated by HR. Great mentors around the company and many that are willing to support others in their career aspirations. Flexible when it comes to work/life balance.
cons: Aetna as a company is shady. When they were trying to acquire Humana, there was a lot of smoke and mirrors and some of the activities in preparation for that acquisition I felt were ethically questionable. Director level management and above seem to be very pretentious, and will often create drama unnecessarily to avoid actually having to make business decisions about the business unit. Employees are looked at as whiners and complainers and management’s disposition is always favored over any report made by an employee. The Comply Line is a joke. If an employee reports something, it get swept under the rug and there are no consequences. I think it will only get worse for my coworkers if the CVS deal goes through.

pros: 6% matching for 401k, decent PTO days, and work-at-home days.
cons: If you are coming into an entry-level position it's very difficult to advance your career and most likely salary will be on the lowest-side of range.  Annual merit increases will vary on many factors but will be around the inflation rate or marginally better than inflation.  Getting promoted can be difficult, you essentially have to wait your turn because there's very few promotions per year and they have to be approved all the way to VP level.  If you talk to current or past employees most likely you will hear career advancement is number one complaint about the company. Trying to apply internally to open positions could be frustrating because if the job would be considered a promotion you may not be considered. They also rely heavily on offshore developers which in many cases are very entry level and FTE devs have to rewrite their bad code once it fails in production.  It's a big company so not all areas operate like this but this is what to expect in many the IT departments.

pros: Moderate pay, same as most case management positions in the Columbus Ohio area.
cons: No structure, treat employees like a factory, upper management does not care about you at all, no cubicle walls, loud background noise, low raise, not able to case manage members because you are selling their case management program and have to meet productivity. Revolving door of employees and members enrolled in case management because you cannot do what they need. Have to get nursing licensure in at least 25 states, plans for all 50, with no guide or structure at all. No HR department that I’ve ever seen or spoken to; member advocates say they are HR and do HR job. Wealthy company trying to squeak by the legalities with as little financial input into case management program, or employees as possible. No critical thinking, no chance to use any nursing knowledge, or actually help anyone in anyway. No training department, you just spend the first month doing licensure.

pros:
- Relatively good benefits: 401K matching, still has a pension plan, bonus opportunities
- Many are given the opportunity to work @ home, at least part time
- Hartford, CT offices are nice, good on-site gym, good cafeteria
- Mark Bertolini, CEO, is an amazing leader, speaker and motivator; he is attempting to set Aetna on the right path
cons:
- Despite CEO's efforts, his leadership team does not know how to execute on his vision
- Management does not listen to those underneath them; they continue to follow "tried and true" processes and are incapable of changing the way they think or operate
- A culture of "bad news is not OK", "don't say 'no'", management elitism, and "blame the scape-goat"

pros: I am no longer with Aetna but my time with them was great until the last two years.  Coventry acquisition brought in a different mindset.  Not wrong, just different.  Wonderful people, hard workers, and very loyal.  Aetna may have the most diverse employee population in the industry and is quite proud of it.  I would give my overall experience an A- (remember 25+ years).
cons: As with many industries, out with the old and in with the new.  Acquisitions and pending acquisitions created a need to consolidate and reorganize (sometimes too often).  I lost count of the number of bosses I have had in my career.  The forthcoming Humana integration promises to be another where job security may be questionable.  Just know going in that there is a chance your services, although needed today, may not be needed tomorrow.

job_title: Customer Service in Blue Bell, PA
pros: Unfortuneately the only pros are the 401k match,PTO time  occassional view of deer playing  in the field and air conditioning.
cons: Not what I expected from.the interview .Absolutely no opportunity for growth,immature staff,multiple policies that overlap and contradict for members. Pay is very low given the demands and responsibility placed on employees. Prior experience and education are not recognized as everyone starts at the same rate. Environment is very cliquish.

review_title: Pluses and minuses, like in any large corporation
pros: The ability to work from home was a huge plus. The people I worked with on a daily basis were wonderful--highly productive, genuine, easy to get along with.
cons: Health care insurance benefits for employees were average (only high deductible plans to choose from). A large company that seems to go through reorgs and laying people off every year, especially toward the end of the year. This doesn't make people feel very confident and willing to speak up with ideas, or speak out when something needs to change, for fear for their jobs. There seems to be more levels of unnecessary management, and fewer doers (worker bees).

review_title: Unfortunately, people will throw each other under the bus within this company
pros: The company is well aware of the importance of communicating health and well being to it's employees. Plenty of information on having a healthy lifestyle is shared and available to all who request it.
cons:
Unfortunately, people will throw each other under the bus within this company. After having worked there for a number of years, I've seen more people sabatoge or throw each other under the bus than I have at most other companies. There are many people (including managers) who will be smiling to your face and praising you to others in front of you, but these same individuals will backstab the same people they are praising when the opportunity for them to gain or not get thrown out of the company during the next round of layoffs.

Some of my colleagues and I are strongly keeping our eyes out for opportunities outside of Aetna. Too much Hollywood type backstabbing occurs here for me to continue stomaching.

Unfortunately, very negative company that places an angelic face in the eyes of it's employees until it's too late for them to do anything.

job_title: Clinical Consultant, RN in San Francisco, CA
pros: I'm an RN with a broad background in healthcare from hospital nursing to Employee Benefit Consulting.  Aetna has been the company I've most enjoyed and who I most respect. My job was challenging, interesting and overall, I enjoyed the people I worked with.  My leadership team was highly supportive and I was recognized for my unique contributions. And last, I was in a work from home position and loved it.  I chose to leave to pursue an independent practice.  If not for that, I suspect I would still be there.
cons: 1 - My salary only changed marginally over the 5 years I was there. My department was offered stock options for the first 4 years than it was removed the last year which was disappointing.  2 - I worked in National Accounts where there was annual turnover in department leadership.  I'm not sure what has occurred in the past 18 months. 3 - Work intensity was very heavy during spring and fall/winter months making work/live balance very difficult to achieve.

review_title: Good job but wish there was more opportunity to be challenged and move up.
pros:
Good training program - you do not have to fear being fired due to incompetence. You will learn the business/industry.
Great work-life balance.
Good support system; peers and managers are very accessible.
Lots of young people in underwriting. Fun environment.
Lots of team happy hours, off-work events that aren't cliche or cheesy but genuinely because everyone becomes friends.
cons:
Some coworkers genuinely do not understand the business and it feels as though because of this management is hesitant to trust its employees with difficult tasks, even for those who are willing.
Not enough outlets in order to improve one's pay; it doesn't feel as though compensation is performance driven.
Official titled promotions are the only way to receive raises and can only happen once a year, so moving up in pay does take a while.

review_title: Entry Level Administrative Assistant at Aetna, Inc.
pros: Aetna is a financially stable company.  In today’s economic times, this should be a high priority when seeking employment. There are many opportunities for advancement and training within the numerous career paths. The healthcare plans offered are competitive within the healthcare industry.  Overall employee moral is high.  Employees are very supportive of one another and desire to see you succeed.
cons: The salaries Aetna's Administrative Assistants receive are lower than the local average.  Work from home opportunities have not been made available to all employees.  A true work/life balance would include this option.  With the demands of today's American family, this policy has indeed become a priority for job seekers.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Hartford, CT
pros:
Telecommuting is great for some people..but it i can also be  a challenge  for leadership  to build a team.and  to have people feel engaged. No one even tries here.
The training was the  worst..mentors too busy, acted rushed and like it was a big bother to help There were many  days there werent any mentors available and it was fend  for yourself,  find something  to  do.. The virtual classroom training and mentoring  didnt match up..so the mentor would be showing one thing, and the training  covering  something else..it was difficult  to  get a picture of the entire  process. The way you learned was to make a mistake and get jumped all over.
My advice to new hires is just get  through training if you can, the job it self is ok..Now that I am out of training and on my own..I really see how difficult the training process made the job appear.
cons: pto,training,insurance is average, not great, salary about norm for the industry

review_title: Low pay, high cost for benefits, but atmosphere is good
pros: Very inclusive company with a good vision.
cons: Benefits are very expensive and pay is way below average. 401k match is 5%. No pension.  I feel like Aetna was a lot more progressive and it really felt like the member was the priority before CVS bought them.  Now it’s all about the bottom dollar. And employees feel like just a number.

job_title: Long Term Disability Manager in Portland, ME
pros: There was a lot of support in managing your claims from the team, clinicians, and fraud department. The people there are really great despite difficult workloads and unrealistic expectations. The office space is nice, and you often had a view of deer and wild turkeys out the window.
cons: The caseload was impossible to manage in a 40 hour week, so everyone was required to work mandatory overtime. Even with the additional hours you were barely holding your head above water. Each week we would have a team meeting where the manager would point out how we weren't managing our claims efficiently. Moral was terrible, and every time someone left (which was constantly) their claims were distributed to everyone else. There was also no transparency...upper management were very secretive and would blatantly lie when asked direct questions regarding the company. Also work from home wasn't allowed unless the office was closed for inclement weather  - then it was mandatory even though you didn't have a suitable work station or telephone (you would have to use your personal cell phone to call claimants).  Opportunities were also limited. People were stuck in the same positions for years without advancement.

job_title: Inbound/Outbound Que Associate in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great resume job. The CEO of the Philadelphia branch is awesome and cares about the ppl working there. So much food places around you will go broke try the Falafel King truck right outside best food EVER !!!!
cons: Very childish atmosphere, to many women PLease hire more men once the hiring processs starts again. benefits suck, deductible is to high and so are out of pocket cost. Management is not knowledgable of the basics of PA work duties. When hiring new management pls make sure they do their hiring on an on a non basis,  meaning they do not hire family or relatives, because it ruins the team morale. Lower the workload for the phone reps they do every job case building, letters, and answering the phone we have co workers who specifically do letters and case building all day, phone reps should only be on the phone and helping out only when needed.

review_title: been a long road to a dead end
pros: I do have a job
cons: I have a job at Aetna.

pros: Flex schedules, in certain departments, work at home (after probationary period even if you were WAH fulltime)
cons:
The entire Medicare Complaint and Appeals area is VERY vindictive and shady. There are many CMS violations, fraudulently changing received dates, lying to members, "losing cases" changing times on faxes, the list goes on and on. Be very careful if entering into this department. I have witness many supervisors bullying employees into compromising data for their own reward. Aetna has a No Retaliation rule- that goes out the door here. Supervisors will throw employees right into a fire then add fuel. It is the most disgusting display of leadership I have ever seen. No one seems to know what’s right and wrong, running around like "chickens with their heads cut off". Watch your back knives fly from every direction over here. 
First you'll be told OT is not approved then the next day, and specifically holidays, you'll be expected to work a full shift without receiving overtime pay. All while management is on PTO. 
No work life balance on the appeals team. 
Expected to bring laptops on vacations/ weekends/ holidays and log on daily.

job_title: COB Verification Analyst in Newark, DE
pros: Great People to Work With. A lot of unity between the specialists.  Enjoy the Casual dress  code (With taste of course.)
cons: You can be micromanaged from multiple angles. There is a conflict between training curriculum and Quality audits that have Specialists up in arms. Be prepared to have conflicting guidance on a lot of things. Not every state does things the same.

review_title: Everything is relative dependent on the department you are in and the competence of the dept management
pros: Training, Technology, Telework, Flexible Work Schedules(start times and 4 day work week). Could be a great place to work if front line and middle level management were walking the talk of senior management
cons: Front line managers lack key competence. Progression/Career Advancement is dependent on who you know not what you know. Ability, skills or competence/expertise means nothing if you dont know and suck-up to the right persons.

review_title: Strong company, lots of workplace benefits
job_title: Applications Developer II in Hartford, CT
pros: I always had excellent managers. The workplace environment is professional and accepting. They value internal hires/promotions over external hires. Bonuses can be quite good. Flex time and PTO balances were really flexible and excellent benefits.
cons: Twice yearly layoffs without any prior notifications making it feel like scare tactics. Frequent company reorganization makes the landscape shift too much. Lots of inter-office politics. Internal hires are severely underpaid, the company refuses to ever give more than an 8% raise regardless of job change.  By the time I left I got a job for the mid range salary of my position at Aetna, which was 40% higher than what I was getting at Aetna. Health insurance was actually not that great.

job_title: Provider Service Specialist in Tampa, FL
pros: Aetna has a great at work education system. the benefits are good considering the high deductible plan which could be more affordable but they have all types of incentives to stay healthy. If you have a company that cares about your health and well being in my opinion its a keeper. In addition to the online education they have numerous opportunities to grow which helps you to believe you will have a future in the company.
cons: with all the great things aetna has to offer you still have to deal with corporate policies and procedures which at times can be tedious and un rewarding. when applying for jobs it helps to have someone in your corner but I seen to often its not what you know its who you know that will get you ahead.

pros: Telework allowed for great work-life balance! Decent 401k of 6 percent. Can't think of anything else but need minimum word count.
cons: Formal end of telework, bringing everyone back into office in 2017 just like Yahoo did. Below industry pay, too lean of an organization, layoffs and reorgs several times a year, every year, since 2008. The only thing that has kept me here was FT telework, but now it's time to go. They are very top heavy with layers of Executives, but they lay off the employees that work directly with the customers. They don't care about top talent. Beware!

job_title: RN Case Manager in Blue Bell, PA
pros: Nice, friendly people.  Good tuition reimbursement.  Good resources for CEUs.  Solid wellness incentives/benefits.  Supportive supervisors.
cons: Heavy workload.  Pay is only adequate.  Adding Labor Day, July 4th, Memorial Day as regular workdays, in addition to MLK and Black Friday.

pros: Pay is comparable for the Healthcare industry.  If you work on one of their campuses, its a very nice environment to work in.
cons:
Very biased toward ObamaCare.  Upward mobility is difficult if you are a work at home employee.

Management is top heavy, to many chiefs and not enough indians.

Do not become a work at home employee; you will not have a true voice regarding missed project deliverables and reporting.

review_title: Overall a good company/job in healthcare
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Blue Bell, PA
pros: I don't work weekends. Many managers care about the wellbeing of the employees. Work with members (patients) to help them improve their health while cutting costs- very practical/realistic areas of concern for members.
cons: Not enough emphasis on employee health/wellness.  Needs improvement re implementing healthier culture/practices got the employees benefits.  Ex= other companies provide standing/walking desks to all employees or have scheduled exercise throughout the day.  Whereas many of us sit in our desk chairs 8-10hrs/day. Job satisfaction can be highly dependent on who your supervisor/manager is.  Some are not competent in their position and not well organized as a group (managers/supervisors), which leads to staff confusion/frustration. Web basses job aids can be overwhelming (too much info & not well organized). This mirrors the cons of member benefits/programs as there is a wealth of info/resources however hard for members to navigate.

review_title: Aetna talks out of both sides of its mouth
pros: Good benefits, women are treated and paid equal to men, disabled workers are protected by FMLA with no retaliation.
cons: They pretend to be employee-focused and transparent, but they're not.  The CEO got the Board of Trustees to approve a minimum wage increase to $16/hour, but they turned around and started outsourcing a lot jobs overseas, including their helpdesk.  They also make many small layoffs, not enough to attract media and/or industry attention. So not as focused on their employees as they claim.  I worked for one of their subsidaries, and I bought into the whole "employees first" mindset, even going so far as to recommend Aetna to several friends. Then out of the blue my company was the target of layoffs and I do not know what criterion they used to measure who got cut and who didn't, or why they felt the need to make cuts in general.

review_title: Constant Mgmt Turnover & Lack of Training
pros: It's very difficult to find pros when there are so many cons in our department and team.
cons:
We lack mentoring and training. We have seniors within the department who won't or don't share or document knowledge.  The perception is keeping their knowledge makes them valuable but all it really does is weaken the team. It's unfortunate as it causes a lot of stress and wastes a lot of time when knowledge isn't documented and shared.

We also have a constant churning of management.  Within our team, some of us have had up to eight managers within the past three years; and, three within the past seven months. With the constant turnover it's very difficult to receive a fair evaluation. 

As salaried employee we are also expected to make up our time away from work for days where we work  less than eight hours.  BUT, we're also expected to be available for after hours calls and meetings but aren't compensated or paid for those additional hours.

pros:
I was a Coventry employee and became a part of Aetna through the acquisition. Here are some of the positives I found:
- Pay was good
- Benefits were not bad
- Good work/life balance
cons: I will just say that before Aetna acquired Coventry, I absolutely loved my job and would not have even thought of leaving. That said, Aetna came in and just start dismantling Coventry management and communication was poor. As a Manager, I had no idea what was happening with the integration or how my team would be integrated into Aetna. I was extremely discouraged by how Aetna handled the integration. You can't expect me to share your vision as a Manager when I don't know what your vision is.

pros: Work at home; PTO; 401K; competitive salary. Co-workers are amazing and care about our members. Too bad management does not.
cons: The things senior management talks about are not put into practice. All the current managers care about is how much work you can do and how much money they can make. Have not heard a word about customer satisfaction mentioned in a staff meeting in over a year. Just because our clients are Medicare/ Medicaid members doesn't mean that they don't matter, especially since Gov't services is one of the only consistently profitable segments of the business. Health insurance benefits are terrible, no opportunity for growth.  The only recognition you will ever get is from your co-workers.

review_title: Painful but a lesson well learned.
job_title: Network Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros:
1. Upper management does provide a good work/life balance.
2. Aetna does offer incentives for healthy behaviors.
3. Aetna does offer work at home positions and is friendly to diverse communities and new moms.
4. Aetna rewards employees that have been with the company a long time.
5. Various employee groups.
cons:
1. Poor pay.
2. Lots of red tape.
3. Favoritism among management and hires friends.
4. Senior Management does not support employees.
5. Senior management undermines their staff to order to solve problems instead of finding real solutions.
6. Layoffs...everyone is always worried about layoffs or terminations for no reason.
7. Promotions are for the chosen for matter how hard you work nor how dedicated you are.
8. Lack of  a true employee training program , lack of response to employee questions and constant technology problems.

review_title: Great company but losing its soul
pros: Smart, caring, hard working and dedicated employes.  Well respected business leaders who are positioning the company for future growth.
cons: HR needs to step up and play a bigger part in guiding the change the company is currently going through - they and their leader are conspicuously silent.

review_title: If Aetna buys your company, leave ASAP
pros:
Benefits
Big Name Company
Work From Home
cons:
Management -- no one seems to know what is going on ... 
Communication -- Management communicates frequently but usually says, "We don't know" or communication is not honest -- they say what they think legacy employees what to hear (like "We'll keep the best of the best") and they do something different (random lay offs).

review_title: I've been with the company over fifteen years at three different jobs.
pros: I've always thought the benefits were pretty decent, and so were the bonuses. I enjoy the flexibility of the work/life balance-I've never not been able to take care of personal things when they happen. Most of my teammates, managers, and people I usually interact with are women.
cons: I've found it difficult to look for another position casually. You have to have already made the decision to move on before looking, as you need to notify your manager that you are looking. They do not hold this against you, and it will not affect your position at all if you ultimately choose to stay in it. But, it would be nice to keep the search quiet as long as possible.

job_title: Member Services in High Point, NC
pros: .  The favoritism amongst managers and some employees is disturbing. The salaries are low and growth opportunities are non-existing. Employees are quitting two per week because of the conditions at this site. Most of the employees are looking for other jobs. You can't get time off without getting a bad mark on your file even if you have hours available and most of the employees are on some sort of write up. Upper management need to change the people they have supervising employees. Bring a group of managers that have advanced degrees and a minimal of five year’s experience. This company is being driven by incompetent people who still believe their management style from the 1980’s is still prevalent.
cons: Favoritism, horrible benefits, low pay, no growth opportunities, outdated computer system, inexperienced management team.

review_title: Terrible Company, Terrible Leadership and Human Resources
pros: None, their are no pros to working here.
cons:
They randomly reduce compensation.  I just got a 20% reduction in income.
HR and Senior leaders talk about transparency but don't practice what they preach.
Constantly look at ways to save money via take aways from employees.

pros: Fair hours, in office activities, very friendly co-workers, nice office in a nice part of dubai.
cons: Very slow progression of career (almost none). Management is very shady on strategy and future of the dubai office.
