The pay is not increasing at all, but responsibilities are skyrocketing due to people leaving the company and them not hiring any new employees to replace the ones who left. The company is split into two floors people on the 28th are treated much better, where people on 26th floor are made to feel unimportant or treated like stock. The upper management comes across as confused and indecisive which is frustrating.

job_title: Director Financial Reporting in Hartford, CT
pros:
Solid work from home atmosphere when need be
In general, people are very knowledgeable as they have been in positions for some time
On Site Health Facility
cons:
For a health insurance company there should be better health plan options for employees
Poor On-Boarding where you need to figure things out then blamed for not knowing
Supervisors do not understand work load of lower level staff
People have been in roles for 10+ years, and unwilling to change
(At least in Finance) Management failure to support ideas from below Director level
Putting people in accounting roles who have no accounting education or experience
Supervisors do not support, back-up, or mentor staff
Process on consolidating financial information - EXCEL IS NOT A CONSOLIDATION ANSWER
Do not fall for the CEO raising employee wages - it was only done so lower wage earners could afford Aetna's company health care under ACA requirements

review_title: Great place to start your career, but move on unless you are one of their "blue-eyed boys"
job_title: Underwriting Technical Leader in Alpharetta, GA
pros: If you are starting out in this field/industry, they offer decent training and a good company name for your resume.  They also offer a fully-paid retirement program and contribute to a 401k plan (although those may be phased out by now), a bonus program and a stock option program (for certain levels)
cons: Unless you are one of the chosen few, you can forget advancement beyond, say, a supervisor or lower level manager position.  They have continued to finance their "comeback" on the backs of their employees, e.g., increased the work week from 37.5 hours per week to 40 hours per week with no increase in pay, reduced health benefits and contributions to those plans, reduced retiree benefits, lowered their contributions to the 401k plan, and cut staff with no reduction in workload.

review_title: It's Okay- Used to be a GREAT company to work for
pros:
Vaction days you get are nice
If you are in good with management, its golden..
cons: You give 110% of yourself but their is no loyalty  from them.They will get rid of you  no questions asked if they have to reduce staff.... They tend to focus on getting rid of the older employees and anyone on leave... doesnt matter how great you  are as an employee.. One of the male managers has a wondering eye and when it came time to lay off.. he kept his blondes ... your hands are tied..if you file suit, you lose severance.. they know how to get around it... Ive seen too many great employees get the ax

review_title: AETNA is a thoroughly corrupt organization
pros: The facility itself is architecturally impressive, well-designed and well-built.
cons: AETNA is very tolerant of dishonest and underhanded business practices. The company's size may have a bearing on its disinterest in enforcing standards of morality and ethics, but this does not excuse AETNA's lack of concern for such things. There are simply to many examples to recount of duplicity and shadowy politics within this organization. If all one care's about is a paycheck, and has no issue remaining oblivious to what is going on around them, it is a decent place to work. If you have a functional conscience, working here may be tough.  Additionally, it should be added that the company makes extensive use of contracted workers from external clients, and that these individuals are treated worse, perhaps, than second-class citizens. They are brought on and disposed of at will, often excluded from benefits or special considerations, and have no say within the organization. Financially, I'm sure this works out well for AETNA but, again, those with any sliver of empathy or a sense of values will have difficulties putting up with it.

pros: Flexible work schedule; Work from home option; Reasonable benefits; If you can find an insulated niche, you can have limited success for a few years.
cons: Senior leadership is weak and disengaged. IT is viewed as an overhead cost not a strategic tool. The culture is fear-based. Poor work/life balance. Employees are treated like widgets. Benefits continue to decrease while costs to employees increase even as company profits rise. Little to no investment in improvements. Foreign vendors greatly outnumber employees in IT and that trend is continuing.

pros: Not many anymore; the environment has and continues to significantly change.  Even when they try to do something good, like provide a new one day holiday, they won't actually close the entire company, and make the entire operations area possibly work.
cons: We are no longer 'Aetna' and have lost the values and integrity that Aetna was based on..  Aetna was very progressive, but now, we finally acquired one to many companies, and we cut way to deep.  No one knows what they are doing, or why.  Every day is educating someone on how to do their job; but you know, they know it all.  We are now 'Coventry/Aetna'.  Coventry was a small company, and so micromanaged, secretive; and management has the 'god' complex.  Bow to me, be scared of me, because one wrong move and you are gone.  Welcome to the new Aetna.

review_title: Aetna is a fantastic place to work!
job_title: Senior Underwriting Consultant in Blue Bell, PA
pros: My experience at Aetna has been very good.  We have great benefits including good health care selections and excellent paid time off.  Management is given the tools it needs to make life great for all employees, and they use those tools generously whenever possible.  My coworkers and I like each other, management, and our work environment, and we are encouraged to maintain a healthy work-life balance.   Management is always trying to make our time in the office better, evidenced by frequent dress-down holidays (not just on Fridays!), departmental social get-togethers (picnic, tailgating party, holiday party), and team outings (bowling, lunch).  We function as one big happy family!
cons: It is difficult to think of a downside because I really do love my job, except maybe the fact that we're distanced from senior management (located in Hartford, CT).

review_title: Two Decades of Employment - How Bad Can It Be?
pros: As a member of the Administrative staff, I can say that if you have a brain and know how to use it, work hard, be respectful and professional, you will advance and succeed.
cons: Sometimes wonder about the skills and effectiveness of SOME senior management.  Also, there are still people working here who are just barely earning their keep.  Further housekeeping is in order.  Finally, WHY do we have to pay SO MUCH for our benefits??  WE WORK HERE - we should get SOME kind of benefits bonus for heaven's sake.  Even department store employees get a discount!

pros: With right leaders, you will be recognized, promoted and developed. I worked there for 4+ years and was promoted twice.
cons: Wrong leaders, you will be supressed and stuck. Also once you get to a certain level in the organization it is important to be at central office in Hartford. From experience, I wasnt and was a high performer but was still job eliminated. Why? Because I didnt have the connection as those others did working with senior leadership day to day. It can be a grind at times working at Aetna.

pros:
Flex-time
Overall people are very nice
cons:
Almost impossible to move out of the A1A care manager position unless you’re “in” with the higher-ups. Case load is extremely high and the expectations of what needs to be completed are unrealistic.  Very stressful to work somewhere when all of your coworkers are unhappy and complaining. Seems to be getting worse with the merger of CVS. 

Benefits are not great and the medical is way too high.  You’d think as employees of an insurance company we’d have great coverage, premiums etc but that’s not so. 

Upper management is more concerned with how things look on the surface instead of addressing the real problems to keep their employees satisfied and happy.

review_title: Fortune 100 company with a client centered mission that extends to employees
pros:
Process Improvement is entertained
Aware of Silos and begining to address those limitations
Competitive compensation
Diversity in managment
Work from home a possibility in many positions
cons: The same challenges found in any large company, the message from the top is diluted by the time it reaches the front line. Job Eliminations are handled by HR and the criteria is not available to the terminated employee-transparency has not been applied to this process.

pros: In the beginning, everyone was helpful.  First year provided many opportunities to learn and grow.  The job opened the door to a whole new industry.
cons: My direct report took a strong dislike to me and soon began to run me down.  It rapidly became apparent that she was determined to drive me out.  A credible reason for the sudden change was never given.  After 6 months of harassment, I finally caved - couldn't take it any more.  I was actually happy to be fired!  Huge load off my mind . . . soon found work with a competitor that was much more friendly and loved working for.

pros: Very good pay, great benefits - like 5 weeks vacation in IT match on 401k, decent raises, bonuses are also good, based on position, start from 4% and up, however you always get more, assuming you make 80K, and bonus for your position is 8%, you should get 6400$ but you get more like 9-10K, just because the company is nice!!!
cons: healthcare insurance is affordable but not so good, like everywhere else, high deductible plans, if you don't get sick you are good. Also, things are done in a weird way - not your typical IT projects, hard to explain. in addition, a lot of waste - really talented and smart people are being let go when projects end while not so talented people are being kept, I am not saying that because I got laid  off, I still work here at Aetna.

pros: Great benefits, low cost health and dental coverage. 6% match on 401K. From a nursing stand point Monday-Friday schedule no holidays or weekends. Salaried paycheck not hourly. Be sure to negotiate your salary.
cons: Where should I start? Working in a dedicated unit in San Antonio the customer dictates much of the business and how things should be ran. If you are thinking you can use your nursing judgement NOT. It is about pleasing the customer. Management is ineffective and does not support their staff. No work life balance lots of work but very little time for breaks frequently 10 hours days working from home eating lunch at your desk.

review_title: Great benefits but morale couldnt be worse since administrative change
job_title: Patient Care Coordinator in Orlando, FL
pros: The company have many benefits including yearly bonus depending on your review. They also have a "Wellness works" program where you can get an additional $1000 added to your HRA/HSA.
cons: The pharmacy is under new administration and they are paying more attention to quantity of calls more than quality. They have the entire floor taking imbound calls so if you work in a team where you have tasks or numbers to meet, expect to put your departments job on the backseat so you tend to other teams calls.

review_title: Incompetent Managers Attempting to Direct Poorly-Designed Program
job_title: RN Case Manager in High Point, NC
pros: The non-management personnel in the HP BAC operation are some of the most talented, creative, kind people in the world.
cons: The strongest skill of the managers in the HP BAC operation is hiding their incompetence from their off-site supervisors.

pros:
The ability to work from home full or part-time allows for a good work life balance. 
The company reimburses for educational growth.
Management is flexible with employee needs.
Good team collaboration.
cons:
Not a lot of room for growth. 
Although my annual performance does not have any negative remarks, it is unknown as to why I can't progress within the company.
Applied for multiple internal positions but have not had one interview. 
Stagnant in the same position. 
People with lower level degrees get elevated positions.

review_title: Not the employer it used to be
pros: Fantastic coworkers; working in Health Care in the current political environment can be exciting
cons: The company has consistently taken benefits from long-time employees. Over the years, they have taken away free parking, increased our benefit premiums, and most recently took 5 PTO days away from long-term employees who already had earned the days. They seem to be squeezing out the older workers and hiring more youth.  Also LOTS of temps are working here (no benefits to be paid). Senior management are invisible to the general population ... there is a caste system, huge chasm between the senior execs and the worker bees.

pros:
pto is generous 
some good people
wellness programs
cons:
since the early retirement offer to employees last fall anyone who declined has a target on them 
do not go to HR if there is an problem  they are not there for the employees  
do not apply if your are not a younger person that applies to those applying from outside and to those applying to positions internally 
 

to quote the CEO 
Hartford Courant - 06/22/2017
In his first public comments since Aetna announced it will move its headquarters out of Hartford, CEO Mark Bertolini says it will leave in search of "younger people, technologists, innovation"

pros: For the Mid South area (NC/SC/TN/some AR), the manager is phenomenal! She is super knowledgeable, consistent, fair, and communicative. The job itself is great if you have a type A personality and enjoy a combination of nursing and data entry. The work-life balance is awesome and it pays more than the bedside positions I have worked until now (13 years experience). By far the best job I have ever had!
cons: Don't think that getting away from the bedside and being able to work from that you don't have to work hard or have good clinical judgement.  Those that are unable to adapt to constantly changing workflows or lack exceptional organizational skills may find this position overwhelming.

review_title: “Aetna has less-than-desirable medical benefits, but it does train its employees.”
pros: The training and focus on process is refreshing to see.  I work in an environment which encourages productivity, but not at the expense of quality.  Management is dedicated to matching the staffing levels with the amount of work to be done, augmenting with contract staff when needed.
cons: The medical benefits offered in their consumer-directed healthcare options leave much to be desired.  Although the company contributes towards the high annual deductible through a wellness program, I'm somewhat leery about inputting lab test results into a 'confidential' website to reap the small benefit.  I would be willing to pay a higher premium for a standard PPO or HMO plan for more peace of mind.

review_title: All business. Not a caring environment just meet productivity standards or you will be terminated
job_title: RN Case Managet in Blue Bell, PA
pros:
Cafeteria. Good orientation except if you are having trouble. Do not work orientation around your needs
Employees are very friendly and are helpful
cons: Orientation. Very complicated computer program. Terminate  you after 30Days after telling you you have 90 days!  My holidays are ruined now without a job

pros: Good 401K match - 100% of the first 6% you contribute.  Very flexible with telework.  Diversity and Inclusion are stressed.  Executives have a vision for the future and are growing the business.
cons: There are good areas of the company but working in IT is not one of them as we are treated like a commodity - there is no partnership with the business.  There are layoffs in IT almost yearly.  There is a disconnect between the executives vision and how it is put in to action at lower levels of the organization.  IT is very processes and procedure heavy for things that deliver little to no value.

review_title: Stay on the right side of the politics
pros: Benefits are good -- could be better, considering they're a health insurance company. But no real complaints.  If you're ambitious, you can find other opportunities within the company.  Lots of opportunities to work from home,and great work-life balance.  The truth is, I'd go back if the director would quit.
cons: Inter-office politics are brutal.  It only take ONE manager to dislike you, and you could be black-listed.  LOTS of people willing to throw you under the bus to get ahead.  Not big on paying higher salaries when promoting from within.  Some people have to resign, find other jobs, and return later to get a salary that's competitive with the job market.  To that note: NEVER discuss you salary with your co-workers.  If they learn you make more than them, they really do their best to sabotage you.

pros: Used to be a great place to work. Decent pay, good PTO  and work at home. Again, work from home is about the only pro at this time.
cons: No autonomy. Micromanaged beyond reason. At first it was a dream come true working from home. The work load and stress levels have made this job just that. A job. It's a big place and easy to get lost in the shuffle. Communication with immediate supervisor is poor and people are often left in the dark. Dealing with customers who are generally unhappy with their benefits.

pros: There seems to be recognition of the need for a life outside work. This varies from department to department, but at least there's some support for it officially. For a big company, things are reasonably functional.
cons: It's stll a big bureaucratic mess hobbled by incompetent managers promoted because there's no promotion path for competent workers that does not involve management rather than any talent for managing, infighting between departments, overall planning that doesn't overrule the deparmental infighting and incompetent management, topdown management where the bottomline workers are kept in dark and fed manure, and brainless costcutting that  leaves inexperienced contract workers under incompetent managers to construct the data systems that are supposed to lead the company into the future. IT is universally regarded as a liability within the company.

review_title: In your 20s and 30s, Good Place to Work
pros: Good benefits, great people, loved the ability to work at home whenever I needed to and home office in Hartford was a terrific facility with an amazing cafeteria.
cons: The company is performing regular staff reductions and will continue to do so through 2015.  They're sending mixed messages through internal communications and town halls and the employees are noticing this.  We value you and want to invest in you, but we're going to eliminate 5,000+ jobs through 2015 and it doesn't matter what type of performer you are.  Criteria is years of service + compensation = goodbye.  Nothing personal...just business.  This why I would say it's a great place to work if you're in your 20s or 30s.  You're safer in that age range.

pros: Hours are flexible which is always great and convenient. After a while you earn the opportunity to work at home which has made work-life balance much easier. The starting pay I believe is higher than most medical insurance companies.
cons: There is no room for advancement, especially depending on the department you are working for. One department in Underwriting will promote their Underwriters every year until you hit the title of Underwriter, then it gets a little bit harder to get to the next titles after. Whereas other departments some take, I've seen from 5-7 years just to get to the next title. Also the benefits are not ideal. I thought working for an insurance company I would have stellar benefits. I made a completely wrong assumption.

pros: Aetna has a good culture, it treats employees as people not numbers. Lots of health and community based perks. Employees are in charge of how far and where they go in the company for the most part. This hands off approach may not be for everyone, since it can seem like management has no interest in your upward mobility. Once you understand that you are the leader of your career, they will follow you and support you in your journey.
cons: Pay is a bit low for the complexity of the work. Not all perks provided have value to all persons, would rather some perks be optional and higher base pay. Bonuses are granted quarterly. The criteria for bonuses are somewhat conflicting with each other, so very difficulty if not impossible to earn max bonus.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Hialeah, FL
pros: Aetna is a life changing work environment! The employees and management team are very genuine and supportive! The culture is very positive and it is a fun environment. New ideas are encouraged and implemented.It is a great employer with amazing perks. Open for work at home deal! Thanks Aetna.
cons: Job Security is a problem with this company. Unless you are in a leadership role or have a close friend inside that can support your transition to a new position your job is at risk. Lay offs and job eliminations are constant, at least twice a year.

pros: Benefits are good, as long as you don't actually need medical care. PTO is plentiful and opportunities to earn more throughout the year. Good work-life balance. I was able to work from home 2 days a week. No one ever leaves because pay & bonuses are decent.
cons: No matter what, you're always the little guy. Over a month ago we were told we would have to re interview and apply for our jobs and that there would be layoffs. Many had to interview for a job they had been doing for 10+ years only to be let go because someone senior decided it would be great to re-org us. Along with that, just an over all disorganization and lack of care, you don't feel wanted or needed. Now, definitely replaceable.

job_title: UM Nurse Consultant in Overland Park, KS
pros: The few: Work- at - home program, added programs in benefits.
cons: Huge disconnect not meeting front-line UM nurse workload complaints.  12 hr days, no one cares.  The Enoloyee Survey is a joke. I'm an experienced RN with 20yrs of experience yet feel completely disregarded , abused and under appreciated in National Care Mgmt UM in the Kansas OP office.  We take care of others but do not take care of our own employees.  If we want to transfer? WE CANNOT! It's banned in my division right now " for stability" sake.  So I either quit, which I do not want to do - I used to LOVE this job! Or I become bitter and angry. What a deal.

pros: Starting salary mid 70s. Desk job.
cons: You are an information gathering statistician assistant first, case manager second. Role of job: collect all possible information from people you call then spends a few minutes addressing any actual needs. Work at home is no longer a feature available as it once was unless grandfathered in. The more efficient you are the higher tasks you receive. Workload, expected productivity and performance necessary with the job are disconnected from reality. Productivity and engagement are heavily focused on--- if people don't engaged you figure out a way to make them, this is an expectation. Many cut corners to leave on time. Weekends off are no longer guaranteed as Saturdays are becoming an interest for days to work. The higher your salary the more you pay for insurance premiums. In summary-- your position longevity is dictated by your ability to justify the need for your employment.

review_title: It was a stressful job and
job_title: Implementation Manager in Blue Bell, PA
pros: I worked from home and that served as a great convenience while raising my children.
cons: Management was far removed from the needs of their employees. That was a common sentiment among most. As time passed, the stress of the job caused me to finally resign from a salary of $72,000. Happiness was far more important than money. Implementation Managers also worked through all holidays and most weekends with little time to family. It was the only way to keep up with the demands of the work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Blue Bell, PA
pros: None that I can think of.  People were friendly near the beginning.  Not so much once  you acclimate to your environment.
cons: Where do I start?  I would highly recommend not working here.  I was a mid tier employee and was micro-managed to death.  Incompetencies was a major theme among mid-tier to high level managers.  Don't encourage independent thought.  Wants you to be a drone even though I scored 97% averaged across 16 exams when I went through their training class.  70% of your work day would be dealing with office politics and backstabbing and the rest of the 30% of the work day you had to get your work done what you were hired for in the first place!  That's an example of poor time management.

pros:
A paycheck 
Some of the members were nice 
Some supervisors care about you 
Opportunities for nurses in other departments
Decent benefits
cons:
Health Coach Consultant jobs- run!  You’ll be paid very little to sit on the phone all day. Your nursing experience does not matter as long as you click in the right boxes on your computer assessments and literally sit on a phone queue ALL DAY.

Some people work at home. They’re lucky. Don’t count on ever working from home. 

There is zero opportunity for growth. 

You’ll pay more for parking than your annual bonus and raise. 

You’ll also be expected to obtain multi-state licensure without a corporate card and a month or longer check-issuing process. You wanted to spend your free time getting fingerprints done, though, right? You won’t get paid for that time-you’re salaried!

Middle management is a mess. Worst I’ve ever experienced. Not even sure what they do because our manager avoided talking to us to even say “hello”.

review_title: Educate your managers in all areas of communications.
job_title: Customer Service Provider in Arlington, TX
pros: Aetna is  great company to work for in other areas than customer service. The company has a history of stability. Its a great place to learn about the healthcare insurnce industry.
cons: The donwside to working for them in there call center, is no room for advancement to other departments or proper mentoring for  new employees that are top notch for the customer service industry when they come on board.... Management want you to answer call after call..... The process not allowing you as a customer service provider to take control you of the call and not be rush the client off the phone..(one in dine customer service, proper  resolution to challenges that may arise foro the client, especially in the claims billing area).......... The companies training department was one that can use an overhaul....... There were to many gray areas....

pros: Great pay, great benefits, management that is focused on productivity, collaboration and being supportive of each other.  Interdepartmental collaboration is a constant focus and we are always improving on what is already a fantastic service delivery system!
cons: Very little negative to say.  They are not doing anything the rest of corporate america isn't already doing right now in a tough economy.  Our benefits are not as robust as they were 10 years ago, our pensions have been frozen, benefits reduced, etc.  But, again, I have to emphasize that every other large company is doing that and much more right now so, relatively speaking aetna is doing a great job keeping up as best they can.

job_title: Systems Delivery Advisor in Hartford, CT
pros: Nice fitness center.  Ability to work from home when needed. Good Salary.  The top business executives seem to know what they are doing.
cons: IT projects require a lot of process to get anything done. It isn't analysis it is typing. Commitment to a future in Connecticut is weak, though I don't see them completely pulling up stakes and leaving.

pros: Decent pay, benefits, health conscious company. If you work in Hartford or PA its probably better than elsewhere. The option to work at home is great, although they are now cutting back on this.
cons: If you're in a smaller office, you tend to get overlooked.  Also whenever there are layoffs, the front line staff are the first to go, despite numerous middle managers who seem completely unnecessary.  They seem to be making strides at keeping talent, but historically haven't seemed to care much.

review_title: Worst Company I've Ever Worked For
job_title: Care Management Associate in Allentown, PA
pros: Working Monday-Friday and rarely weekends.
cons: Aetna is full of the worst incompetent, selfish, disrespectful managers.  They also discriminate against people with disabilities, I've seen it first hand.  All they care about is numbers, not the actual quality of your work.  When you need help, they leave you in the dust and disappear.  Management refuses to make mistakes right even when the company is at fault.  Co-workers are constantly stabbing each other in the back just to get ahead.  Unorganized and unethical.  Stay away!!!

review_title: Do you want to work for a health insurer with below par standards and benefits for the non-management population?
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in White Plains, NY
pros: None, I would not recommend Aetna as a employer of choice.
cons: In the five years in this position the highest merit increase received has been 1% with a overall scorecard rating of 4 out of 5. The gap between management and the non-management population in salary continues to grow. A person should never be appointed to a managerial position if his or her vision focuses on people's weaknesses rather than on their strengths. The aetna's middle layer managers tend to focus on what people cannot do, but never sees anything they can do, that will undermine the spirit of the organization and the senior management's initiatives and objectives that's a huge downside for this organization.

review_title: Warning: Aetna lies about remote benefits!
pros: Good pay, but it comes at a price. They give you too much to do, so you are forced to work overtime each week. If you don't work overtime, they will say you can't finish your work.
cons: Aetna claims excellent work-at-home benefits, but it is a lie! Once you agree to work at home, they will screw your over.  They will force you to relocate with little notice. If you don't agree to commute a few hours each day, they will be nasty and threaten your job. The HR department doesn't care. They are impossible to reach once you start working. The management is a revolving door full of untrustworthy people.

pros: Work at home  (which we are being told is being stopped)
cons: Unbelievable amounts of work.  Basically Slavery. This company"s managers are shady. The management lies and slowly finds ways to push people out of there jobs.  Managers are clickish.  If you do great work or they try to sabotage and undermine great workers. False reviews. Low Bonus, Salary is kept low.  Bullying of workers. Rude frequent comments to workers.  Staff is blamed for everything while "the favorites" are selected for special projects.  Job is ok but training is not sufficient.  The incompetent management and blame shifting is unbelievable!   The company is greedy and do not care about the employee, the sponsors (customers) and members.   The Sponsors request STATESIDE workers and Aetna Gets Around those requests and give the work to overseas workers.  Many American nurses lost their jobs here and the jobs were given to OVERSEAS workers.  Little to no opportunity for LPNs although many are 'grandfathered' into now RN positions.

review_title: Aetna...Great Company to work for...Fair salaries in question.
job_title: Disability Claims Analyst in Plantation, FL
pros: Aetna really does try to be fair to it's employees.  The do a lot of recognition and promoting.  Ron Williams is a down to earth person, not at all corporate stiff shirt like you would see with most CEO's.  I also love the fact that they they are now pushing work at home, which is so much more convenient for people with children or who have to commute far.  They are also pushing for a 4day work week which would also be great
cons: The pay sucks, well down here in Florida it does.  Especially now with the economy being down and out, they are not looking at it from the employees perspective where we are already not receiving fair pay but now it's hard to get back and forth to work with rising gas prices and all.

review_title: Aetna has absolutely no loyalty to employees they lay off !!!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Princeton, NJ
pros: Good company except when laid off.
cons: After ten years at Aetna in NJ , I was laid off. Working 3 areas in customer service , broker liaison, and the medicare health unit department that was eliminated due to lack of funds. I cannot find a decent job in this terrible economy as a middle aged person. I have been told they are only hiring within the organization and not externally . Therefore no jobs are available on the external posting website unless top management or the nursing fields.. This keeps me at bay from being able to post or looking like a stranger as if I never worked there in other positions or locations. There loyalty to laid off employees is HORRIBLE! This company has no fairness or sensitivity to people they lay off ! Aetna's awards and recognition for being a great employer are really not deserved due to this issue. Ask any of us!

review_title: Five years with this company, and felt pushed out.
job_title: Health Care Consultant in Sandy, UT
pros: A lot of great talent works here, the staff where I worked were kind and helpful to one another. Benefits were ok, liked talking to members to try and help them feel better.
cons: A lot of micromanagement, lots of metrics and little humanity. It really became just about the metrics and not about the members improvement or well being. Medical insurance was not great, very high deductible plan, challenging for people trying to take care of ongoing chronic problems.

job_title: Plan Sponsor Liaison in Hartford, CT
pros:
Working from home is great I can roll out of bed and get straight to work. 
They have a lot of wellness programs and discount programs for employees to utilize.
cons:
The workload is very heavy and management sets unrealistic deadlines that they expect you to complete your work by. With the heavy workload it doesn't leave time for you to utilize the wellness programs and discount programs offered by the company. 
If you take personal time off for doctors appointments, family emergencies, vacation etc...They often use it against you.
The standards set and beliefs of the company that the CEO emphasizes do not flow all the way down the chain of command ladder. 
They value customers over employees and never take your side even if the customer is wrong.

review_title: Great Company to Work For If You Get Hired Externally
pros: The company culture is actually very good. The workplace seems to be geared towards providing actual job satisfaction. Work-life balance is good, and they have a fairly generous PTO policy.
cons: If you join Aetna looking to be promoted and work your way up, you can. However, they will do everything in their power to refuse to also give you a pay raise that matches your new job's responsibilities. Aetna instituted a "pay raise cap" that tops out at 10% or 15% depending on which "professional classes" you're moving in to.  10 to 15% sounds like a lot, but if you're starting at a lower (entry) position, you can end up being 10s of thousands of dollars below market rate for a position.

review_title: It was good while it lasted.
job_title: Senior Financial Consultant in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Most of the people I worked with really cared about doing a good job for the customers.  I worked in a small group of good people within the large company. The salary and benefits were good enough, although they had been cut back little by little over the 18 years I worked there.  The office was conveniently located for me.
cons: Large bureaucracy and an upper management team that treats people as expendable commodities.  In order to reduce salary expenses, they are outsourcing as many functions as possible and getting the salaried employees to work a lot of extra time.  Some corners are being cut, so that "close enough" reporting is now the norm.  If you are not located in the CT office, there is not much room for advancement.

pros: Aetna is very good at work/life balance, the work is challenging and allows continuous learning, the benefits and holidays are competitive .  They provide 401K and ESPP to help plan for the future.  Their wellness package provides a very comprehensive stress management benefit  that is beyond industry standards.  Very big on activity related competitions with logging of exercise, meals, stress management time.  Good opportunities for advancement.  Also, many positions are work from home.
cons: The health and dental insurances are very expensive with mediocre benefits 80/20 with min 1000 deductible.  As a healthcare company, it would be nice to provide premium benefits to their employees.  They do have a tenancy to have layoffs every other year in one division or another.  With 48,000 employees this is expected but not fun to wonder which department will be hit.

review_title: Answer Team Consultant - Do not apply of this job.
job_title: Answer Team Consultant in Dallas, TX
pros: It was a great place to work depending on the department but when they started creating this new department and did not do the research and did not provide adequate tools and resources it became a place that did not value their employees. You are set up for failure.
cons: Rigid, mayhem, train wreck, extremely stressful. Stay away for this Answer Team Consultant position. It's a call center environment just created and not organized at all. No coaching or help once you are place live on the phones.It is Chaotic (a state of complete confusion and disorder).

job_title: Clinical Support Pharmacy Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The location on Cotton Center Blvd had a great cafeteria, gym, and overall work life balance.
cons: I would still be there if the company hadn't lost the contracts with the states our team processed the Prior Authorizations for that led to my team being disbanded and even my direct supervisor being let go. In addition to my certification expiring on October 31st, 2017 and not having my required CE completed as well. The con being not having a way for employees to obtain CE or at least an reimbursement program.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Job security, WAH, good work environment
cons: Good benefits but at a very high cost to employee.  Does upper management pay for their retiree medical?  I doubt it.  I've worked at Aetna for years, often fending off recruiters not only because of loyalty but in anticipation of my retirement benefits, only to find that now I can theorhetically retire, those benefits have been taken away.  I have a medical condition which makes individual insurance unrealistic.  The thanks I get from Aetna is to take away my medical if I retire.   So I have to stay.  So much for valuing and rewarding employees - my scorecard always shows that I exceed expectations.  Too bad Aetna didn't live up to theirs.

pros: Great networking events with executive leadership; Develop long lasting relationships with fellow program members; opportunities to work outside of Hartford; exposed to different fields of finance; good PTO and relocation opportunities; fun atmosphere.
cons: Favoritism is clearly apparent; low compensation compared to other leadership programs; terrible location; leadership focuses more on program activities/events then the actual job at hand; uncertainty of the future from CVS acquisition; more and more members are leaving for external positions.

job_title: Division Manager in New York, NY
pros: Aetna really cares about its customers. There is a real drive to find a solution for the uninsured. In addition, the company cares about its employees and puts a lot of effort into employee surveys and takes action from those.
cons: The advancement opportunities are very limited unless you are in sales or IT. Too many of the opportunties are tied to the Hartford office or a specific site even when it is not required for the job. The salaries for division managers and site leads is not sufficient given that they are the ones who are responsible for the implementation of initiatives and must get individuals to move toward that as a group. Also, given the experience and skills of these groups, more decision making should reside at these levels.

pros: They offer full-time or part-time work at home positions. Additionally most managers are flexible with work-from-home even if you are normally full-time in the office.
cons: Managers do not understand work/life balance. They expect people to work weekends constantly to make up for the fact that many employees are not well experienced and others have to pick up their slack. They believe hiring a bunch of onshore or offshore people will solve all problems. It seems they don't even care to ask for experience, simply f they know how to turn on a computer is enough to get them a job.  However management cannot understand why deadlines aren't met or there are hundreds of defects...

review_title: A good place to work but unless you're in certain sites advancement is limited
pros:
There is potential for other opportunities but most moves are lateral unless you have a particular skill or work in a particular site
Opportunities exists for professional development such as ERGs
cons: Benefits are awful.  One would think if you worked for a health insurance company benefits would be awesome, but that is not the case.  All of the plans are High Ded health plans, no copay options exist.  As stated before, unless you work in a particular region, advancement opportunities are limited.

pros: They encourage a work/life balance by allowing many employees to work from home full time or part time. We have a variety of great benefits above and beyond the traditional medical and 401K benefits. They have have an emphasis on health for their employees as well as our customers. There is the ability to move positions if you find that your current role is not a good fit or if you want to use your skills in a different area. We are a national and international company with a very diverse work force. I feel that we are definitely helping people.
cons: Paid time off and sick leave are all in one bundle so you can wipe out your vacation time if you need to take off due to an illness.

pros: Aetna has an amazing level of diversity (ethnic and women).  This diversity can be viewed through all levels of ranking.  It is one of the few companies I have worked for where I forget I am a minority when I walk through the doors.  Inclusion is important at Aetna and exercised in a way that is unparalleled.  Differences are embraced.  Collaboration between business units is noteworthy.   The company also offers flexible schedules for employees at all levels.  The organization is constantly observing a program or staff achievement that equates into some type internal celebration.  A majority of employees are offered some level of remote working if desired.  Bonuses are very equitable and can make up for lower than market starting salaries.
cons: Health care benefits are VERY expensive.  This is quite an irony.  Pay scales fall outside of industry standards.  ASK FOR THE MONEY AND VACATION TIME UP FRONT!  Annual salary increases are minuscule.  In addition, you will be offered only 2 weeks of starting vacation if you do not negotiate during the interview process.  There are no programs aimed towards career growth and upward mobility.  You must be your own advocate for career growth.  There are individuals that have worked in the same career for over 20 years.  This is common at Aetna.  Opportunities exist.  It will be up to you to find and pursue them.  CVS has acquired Aetna which could completely eradicate the amazing culture that currently exists.  Depending on the office location, some offices are at full capacity and therefore have limited seating. This can result in leaders working from cubicles.

review_title: A good place to work, however the changes are aggressive which has caused strife in certain areas.
job_title: Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Aetna supports work at home which is an excellent benefit.  They do tend to hire and promote from within which is also positive.
cons: Although change is a good thing, Aetna has been changing at break neck speed the last 3 years which causes issues between departments that are in different places of the process.  In addition, there are still managers that should not be in their position (Iack of experience, knowledge, etc).  However, that tends to be common in large companies.

review_title: Anything goes when it's time for layoffs!
job_title: Quality Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Great people to work with; company takes employee survey results seriously.
cons: When it's time for layoffs, the quality of your work and your metrics results don't matter. I was there 15 years, with results that exceeded anything that was asked of me. There is still a lot of dead weight that gets to keep their jobs.

review_title: If you want to know what it feels like to be under-valued work for Aetna.
pros: Lots of truly nice people to work with, all who care about the individual who are forced to use our products. Very flexible work from home policy.
cons:
Aetna values their employees less than any company I've eve worked for. This can be seen in everything from the dismal health insurance to they think strategically about long term investments.

Poor understanding of what culture means and how to define and instill it into the work place. A wheel does not make culture.

pros: The size of Aetna a pro all by it self. There is so much you can do at Aetna, your career choices are almost endless. The management is wonderful, salary is competitive and benefits are perfect. I would recommend this company to anyone.
cons: If you do not like a fast pace environment you might not like Aetna. The work always gets done no matter what the deadline is and if that means you log on at home to get work finished that is due the next morning that is what you have to do.

job_title: Eligibility Specialist in Moon Township, PA
pros: Lots of Overtime during AEP. The only way I was able to pay for expensive dental work and get out of debt. Wish they offered OT outside of AEP
cons: Where do I start? I like my supervisors but all the teammates I enjoyed are no longer here. Now IB get to deal with "grown ups" who don't want to act like it and throw tantrums when things don't go their way. I am a teleworker and now they want to end teleworking due to one question getting a low score on an anonymous employee survey. IMO they wanted to get rid of teleworkers and just needed an excuse to do so. Wish upper management were honest. Told us there would be no changes, I go away on vacation for 10 days and come back to find half my team gone due to layoffs.

review_title: Case Management is a Three Ring Circus!
pros: Salary is definitely within the market value for area
cons:
IT systems are terrible.  
Work environment is like small coffins.
"Experienced" staff  are lazy with pretty much have no productivity. 
But they are icons in the company and never will be managed.
Daily unprofessional behavior from staff members with no intervention from managment.  
Health Benefits SUCK! 
Aetna has the highest out of pocket, deductibles and pharmacy costs. The insurance coverage should not be listed as benefits but as an employee burden!
One week we have a meeting telling the staff....."everything is going to be fine."  The next week 600 plus layoffs.

pros: if you get the right job, you can do nothing and live happily ever after. more important to not make mistakes then to actually do anything correctly
cons: if you get the wrong job, you can kill yourself putting in 100 hour weeks, and if one of the things you did was a mistake, you will pay for it in your annual review (and your future salary)

pros:
Opportunities to move to other departments and businesses

Flexibility in work scheduling (my experience). I am able to work from home weekly, can leave early to get kids and log back in later etc. 

Company is serious about mission to positively change health care in the US
cons:
Really bad at developing talent; you are on you own. Want to get on the fast track? Align yourself with someone who was anointed by a manager with some "pull". 

Have to network your way to new opportunities. If something is listed on the internal job site, probably the hiring manager already has people in mind and it's listed as a formality. 

Health benefits could be better

review_title: Good company but very disorganized department
job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The benefits are pretty good and so is the salary
cons: The Medicaid IT department in Phoenix is a mess.  Very long hours, constant changes, no processes or procedures in place.  Not a lot of knowledge in the department.  Very bad management.  Work from home is now disallowed.  No training, no direction, constant rework.  This is all a shame because Aetna is a good company.  90% contractors.  People do not work together or even talk to one another, very bad environment.

job_title: Applications Technical Specialist in East Newark, NY
pros: 401K, and I truly can't think of anything else.
cons:
The people that have been there for a long time are partial and bias. They only celebrate their special occasions. If one if them have an issue with you all of them jump on the bandwagon and stop speaking. The supervisors are lazy and do little of nothing. They act like they are some kind of big wigs and you mean nothing unless you are kissing up to them. They promote their friends and buddy's. They talk to you any kind of way and expect for you to take it with a smile and when you complain about it they make up an excuse lke its a culture difference or he's young or she's just trying to understand you. They have lied abut everything from the pay up to when you will be allowed to work from home. They just say it's a freeze on everything and when you call human resources they say it's up to your department. Its pathetic and insensitive. 
They should all be ashamed of themselves.

pros: First let me start off by saying my review is about the mail order pharmacy in Plantation.  Aetna is a great company. The people who complain the most are the one's who do the least amount of work and/or take advantage of our lenient attendence policy. The supervisors and managers are all great people and the emoloyees are treated  well.  The benefits are ok. PTO is above average  compared to other companies. The onsite cafeteria is decent.  The mail order pharmacy has lots of activities for staff such as luncheons etc. Monthly awards and recognition program. Overtime offered during peak season.
cons: Childish employees who act like little kids and whine & complain every chance they get.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The company is solid and benefits were fairly good.  Would think they would be better being a healthcare provider.  There is a lot of work so do not see layoffs in the future.  CEO is a great speaker.  Compensation was good.
cons: The IT department in Phoenix was horrible.  Very bad management.  No work/life balance.  Very large turnover.  There are a lot of contractors working in the IT area.  There is no real teamwork there.  You really do not get a chance to get to know anyone.  Was a horrible work environment.

review_title: It's not what you know, but who you know
pros:
Flexible hours in my dept
Good co-workers
Some opportunities to learn new skills, etc
cons:
Manager obviously had favorite people - he only talked to me & my co-workers if he needed something done or we didn't do something correctly or quickly enough. 
Management style was to throw people into new situations (with no direction) to see how they would handle it - he thought everyone should be able to figure things out without any help. 
Also many at the management level lack actual people skills.
Never showed any appreciation for job well done - only pointed out flaws and provided "constructive criticism".

job_title: Inside Sales Individual Advantage in Blue Bell, PA
pros: Connecting with like minded co-workers who are also trying to make the best of it under trying circumstances
cons: Office Culture: They like to display the facade of cultural & corporate political correctness while implementing a very condescending attitude toward their work force. This was demonstrated by the way management would interact with employees who they were responsible for managing on a higher level, the crappy group health insurance benefits offered the employees from a company that is in the business of health insurance.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Bernardino, CA
pros: Large company with great benefits and growth opportunities in varies areas of the organization. Great learning opportunity, pay was very fair.
cons: Missed some of the small business easy decisions and went thru multiple mergers which each time wanted to change everything, just so eventually it reverted back to best practices that worked for the business.

pros: Good PTO; wellness benefits ; flexible schedule and work from home. Stability  Tuition reimbursement up to 5k
cons: Aetna has the worst health insurance coverage I've ever had. High out of pockets and premium.  No opportunity for advancement because. No career development from leadership. No time for yearly reviews. No promotion. Low quarterly  bonuses . Supervisor encouraged not to give out 3s or 4s on reviews. It's all Numbers numbers production  and quality . You are not a human. High burn out department. And you only promoted if you work unpaid overtime and kiss serious butt.

review_title: The Aetna Way is a great ideal--
pros:
Senior Management has strong values, and the corporate motto of keeping the customer at the center of everything they do.  This is achieved through Integrity, Quality Service and Value, Excellence and Accountability, and Employee Engagement.
They are supportive in terms of ongoing internal education and have a strong methodology for development.
cons: The review process often does not reflect the actual work that is being done, and must fit into certain matrixes that do not translate into the real world.  Also, if an employee does not agree with their review, there is no opportunity to appeal.  When there is a conflict with a boss, HR suggests that the employee "suck it up".

job_title: Case Management Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Cheap benefits, perks like earning rewards and geared. toward better health , good time off , nice co workers . Time off is nice, 12 hours per month.
cons: Low pay, over worked, too much paperwork and old equipment. Supervisors give you past due caseloads and expect you to fix them and if you don't you get in trouble. They try o sell you on a 4% bonus but they don't tell you that there are MANY stipulations to earn it. So when you think your going to get your bonus they tell you you didn't do what you need to and participate in extra activities to get it. The pay is horrible compared to other mco's.

review_title: Aetna offers a lot of opportunities for employees who are willing to work hard for advancement.
pros: Flexible work arrangements (including hours as well as the ability for many of the job functions to be able to work from home; job advancement, & competitive salaries
cons: Healthcare benefits are on the low end of the insurance market for it's employees, job security is a thing of the past (several rounds of job eliminations the past couple of years); certain job functions are understaffed so employees are getting burned out

review_title: Aetna was an okay place to work.
job_title: Health Care Consultant RN in Sandy, UT
pros: Allowed to telecommute, timely raises, okay benefits. I believe the intent is to provide a good product.
cons: Lots of change, pressure to do more with less resources, minimal chance for promotion. I worked in a place where micromanagement was the norm, and metrics were the only way you were measured, not by any other means. Being given minimal time to take a bio break or get a breather. Had to spend many hours after work catching up, of course I was salaried, but there was no other way to get the very redundant work done.

review_title: My experience to date has been great! But all of a sudden the views on work at home has taken a drastic turn.
pros: Work from home and great manager and peers! Pay is very good. There are lots of job openings across the country.
cons: After the employee survey the CEO Mark Bertolini has changed his mind on work from home. He feels we will not be innovative without being in the office to collaborate. I was hired due to my 18 years insurance and proven track record experience and hired as a Work from home employee. Now the message is all managers will be assigned back into the office with employees to follow.  WFH is why I joined because the commute is 1.5 hours one way. I feel like now we are being retaliated against for the employee survey. Great job Marc Bertolini.

review_title: Aetna, a culture of workplace bullying and harassment.
pros: Certain departments have flexible work schedules. The Wellness reimbursement as well as tuition reimbursement was generous. The relaxed work attire was somewhat nice - when employees didn’t abuse it.
cons: The employer brand image and perception of culture that is marketed and sold to candidates is not the experience delivered. There are serious issues with harassment and workplace bullying. Poor leadership and management reflects highly on the floor. Absent leadership has allowed atrocious behavior. Management chooses to ignore the behavior- ignored behavior is confined behavior. If you take your concerns to HR, the leadership will subtly retaliate against you. Aetna’s Code of Conduct is a one way contract - you abide by it, they don’t.

pros: All of my colleagues in my particular department are wonderful! They all value teamwork very much and it shows. Location is another positive for me since my job site is not too far from where I live.
cons: Everything has average 3 ratings across the board. The pay is just alright. The management is okay but they could be trained better. Work life balance could improve by offering more health incentives to employees. Values and culture is average/okay, because nothing really unethical stands out in my opinion.

job_title: Audit Project Manager in Hartford, CT
pros: Great benefits and work life balance.  You can get promoted quickly. Once you get in it is easier to move to different teams. Absolute heaven when compared to my public accounting days.
cons: Everyone gets rated a 3/5 when it comes to review time.  You have to pay for parking and the positions up top are filled by friend of friends and not people with experience. The pay is much less then the other insurance companies in the area.

review_title: Aetna, not a bad place to work
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Blue Bell, PA
pros: At Aetna you're treated fairly and there are plenty of opportunities to advance. I have a great boss that has helped me when I've needed time off,  they undestand that you have a family and that things happen when you need time off.  They really tap into other talents you may have to create a better work environment.
cons: The health benefits are pretty poor for being a health insurance company.  You would think that they'd give you a health plan with a low deductible, but the premiums and out of pocket are failry high.  The turn-over is somewhat high, but it's not due to the company, it's due to the lack of compntency of the people that they hire.

review_title: Work towards joining the sales field, your job is easy, pass the work onto everyone else.
pros: They provide you with excellent training for your job.  You are definately not just thrown into your job and asked to do something that you have no idea how to do.  I think that this is a great place to gain experience for someone who is just coming out of school.
cons: The sales field has free regin to do whatever they please.  We waste excessive amounts of time working on dead end projects because the sales field has their heads in the clouds.  They are disengaged in the proposal until the day that it is due and then expect you to jump through hoops for them.  If you dont drink the Aetna "kool-aid" watch out.

review_title: Aetna takes advantage of it's employees and is primarily about public presentation vs. reality in action.
pros: The folks in middle management and working staff are intelligent, good people who work together well and support each other, for the most part.  Work at home possibilities.
cons:
There are limited growth opportunity, 
Aenta takes advantage of employees from a work-life balance perspective, 
Senior leadership is very self-serving and not team oriented.  
There is an extreme lack of resources to support the business:  both from a technological and staffing perspective.  
Application the "Aetna Way" when convenient. Diversity really doesn't exist as they would like you to believe.
Promotions frequently based on politics and not necessarily capabilities.

review_title: Great company...for the investors and senior management.  OK for everyone else.
pros: Employee Resource Groups are highly encouraged and touted.  The Office of Diversity works hard in regards to public relations with the employees.  The people here are mostly positive and easy to work with.
cons: As many companies now, there are an inordinate amount of people under single team leads, which can negatively effect meaningful feedback.  There have been round after round of layoffs in the past 5-6 years, so unless you are production or a CSR you'll be worried about security.  Medical benefits are offered, but aren't as good as you'd hope - the high deductible plans are moderatly priced, but these aren't HMOs.

pros: Telework/working from home, no one in the company makes less than $16/hour, some positions allow the freedom to work anywhere in the country as long as there is a branch office nearby, plenty of opportunity for growth if you choose, completely flexible schedule, job security (I have been with the company many, many years), great benefits and 401k matching, employee discounts for Microsoft Home Office Suite and Verizon, among others.
cons: The company is almost "too" customer service oriented, so much so that they don't really give the employees a choice when they suddenly tell you that you will start taking incoming calls and be trained on a phone piece, in addition to your normal duties. However the flexibility of the scheduling and working remotely in addition to the feeling of having a very secure job outweighs that.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Blue Bell, PA
pros:
Overall its a pretty good company to work for but some departments can be more challenging than others.  Some older technology mixed with newer components overall things work pretty well together.  However most applications are very complex due to the combination of technology and industry requirements.
Pay is competitive and work life balance can be good if you learn to manage everything at the same time.
cons:
Some levels of management can be challenging to deal with at times.  The IT department had become extremely process driven.  Over the last few years they have taken steps to address this issue to some extent.  
Work life balance used to be much more skewed ,but over the last few years this has gotten better as well.

pros: For a big corporation they are always evolving and trying to make improvements for the better for our customers and for our culture. Great PTO. Benefits are comparible to other companies. Work from home option for some positions. Great work/life balance. Open door policy for managers and they are really supportive. Collectively a great team and supportive of the team.
cons: Still somewhat of a divide between legacy Coventry and legacy Aetna employees. Sometimes positions are force filled. Hiring or promoting just to have a resource. Training is a struggle.

pros: job security.  they fire no one.
cons: they treat the lowest paid employees like peons.  they dump more work on you during the busyest time of the year.  most regions are all for the work at home yet our management for our region is dead set againsted it.  He admitts that he is old school when it comes to w.a.h.  With the price of gas he should embrace it, especially for us lower paid employee's that are limited to how much of an salary increase we get.

pros: Job security is great. Many employees have been here more than 5 or even 10 years.
cons: The company evaluates everything based on revenue generating power. If your department function is not directly making revenue. The the department owner would use the most cheapest way to run the department which means no OT salaries, no even free meals provided for OT employees. But when it comes to the annual review, you will be told "you're expected doing well." So trying to work hard to get promoted is almost impossible. The management is constantly changing but nothing really change to the bottom employee. The benefit is great as long as you don't use it except for PTO. It's only benefit from Aetna.

pros: Annual bonuses and the ability to telecommute were definite pros to working at Aetna.  Enjoyed working with my fellow co-workers.
cons: Constant layoffs around the holiday season and at the beginning of the year.  Constant reorganization.  Lack of communication from management to the lower level employees.  No room for advancement.

review_title: Company with great vision and smart people
pros: The people who work for Aetna are solid. They are true experts in their fields. They’re held to high standards internally. Aetna invests in training their employees and exposing them to material that is relevant to their jobs; be it seminars, trainings, etc. it’s a large company so there is a lot of room for growth
cons: Compensation is an issue for employees who have been around for a while. There is an annual merit increase and your eligibility to it depends on performance, which is okay; but my manager told me they have a limit on the number of employees they can give good ratings to because of the limited budget for merit increases so increases are low.

review_title: Great place for opportunities if interested in work outside job role.
pros: Very flexible work environment. Leadership can be very supportive of employees. Really liked the casual telework option which allowed me to work from home and the office as needed.
cons: Politics...can be advantageous if you like to dabble in it. Can be a huge disadvantage if you steer entirely away from it.  Not unusual in a large organization.

review_title: Major corporation in every way possible
pros: There is a solid 401k, there are also stock options, the health plan leaves something to be desired, comparatively (especially considering its an insurance company), but that is largely irrelevant considering their plan to move to A.C.A. plans. They're are plenty of fitness programs and incentives used In an attempt to offset the out of pocket costs of the plans made available to internal employees.
cons:
HR is completely out of touch. All matters are handled by each we employees immediate supervisor which is often and easily a conflict of interest. 

If you have trouble with the concept of being a number and figuring everything out on your own, this may not be an ideal fit.

job_title: Medicaid Case Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Salary is decent and working conditions are good.  This is especially true if you are lucky enough to be a work-at-home employee.  There is a degree of autonomy in this position, with the right supervisor.
cons: Be prepared to operate in a culture of blame.  Problems are more than likely the case manager's fault and the case manager should have fixed whatever the problem was.  It is not unheard of to be chastised for one issue, even though the previous case management was stellar.  Mistakes are highlighted and successes are under-recognized.  The occasional "Thank You" email is supposed to suffice in keeping staff morale high.

pros: Decent hire-on salary, tuition and CE reimbursement
cons: I used to think it was just our department that was a mess. Turns out it's the whole company. People being promoted that aren't a threat, instead of people who are genuinely good and natural leaders. The whole work experience depends on your direct manager---there have been some pitiful ones. Ones, plural--constantly changing, moving, re-arranging. No regard for conflict of interest or HR "policies," there have been many shady and illegal happenings that never get investigated.

pros: Decent employee health insurance.
cons: As a manager/supervisor, HR is more of a hassle than a helper. You are responsible for all things employee related. Financial "caps" are a serious struggle for employees that start below a range; an ongoing battle for 2 years. Too big for its own good. Too silo'd. Lack of unity.

review_title: Great Company, Amazing Culture and Even Better Benefits
pros:
-Flex hours
-Work from home on unwell days or appointment days w/ manager approval
-Lots of opportunities for professional development
-Huge company with lots of opportunities for networking outside of your team and department
-Subsidized gym and personal training
-Cafeteria with chefs inside one of the phoenix buildings
-Great benefits; Although they're not as great now that they merged with CVS
-Annual Bonus
cons:
-They lost some of their perks/benefits after merging w/ CVS like the $200 reimbursable well-being program
-More red tape after merging w/ CVS like not being able to hire interns during the school year anymore because that just happens to be a CVS policy
-More of "now we can't do this" because of CVS policy

review_title: Great big company to work for w/work life balance.
pros: Aetna excels at work life balance in that they encourage people to work around their life, they will make effort to allow working mobile, off peak hours, whatever to get work done.  Aetna makes big investments for the future of the company and employees, for the long run so project work is very well thought out; they will only do something if they can do it "right".
cons: Compensation and bonuses aren't that great.  If you value getting solid experience in a large company with excellent systems and processes then good place, but you most likely won't be compensated very well for it.

pros: Work from home opportunities are plentiful. This is a real plus. The benefits package is decent but not spectacular.
cons: Long, long hours, no work life balance. The Consumer Business area is cutthroat, finger pointing. There is a lack of collaboration and communication among the leaders. They delay making important decisions and keep cutting the budget while expecting the employees to deliver whatever they decide in the moment no matter what. The senior leaders' idea of leading is to blame the directors and managers, demand more hours, and demand a solution, with an artificial deadline that is not based in reality. This area is toxic.

pros: Work from home, Schedule, Hours, technology
cons: Unbelievable amounts of work. Basically Slavery. This companys managers are shady. The management lies and slowly finds ways to push people out of there jobs. Two faced managers,are cliquey. If you do great work or they try to sabotage and undermine great workers. False reviews. Bullying of workers. Staff is blamed for everything while "the favorites" are selected for special projects. Job is fine. The incompetent management and blame shifting is unbelievable!The company is greedy and they purpose my overcharge members for the plans that offer nothing. This place is constantly getting sued most recent my they were sued by DOJ for violating antitrust laws by trying to merge with Humana ..which was of course blocked.

review_title: Great place to start my career
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Hartford, CT
pros: Coming out of college, I didn't know what I wanted to do with my business degree. Aetna gave me the option to rotate through several roles to find out where my skill sets and interests lie. In addition, the benefits are great (6% match, plenty of healthcare options, tuition reimbursement of $5K/year)
cons: Since the acquisition, CVS has been taking a top-down approach to all decisions, not garnering feedback from the Aetna SMEs/business units. The long-term vision of the company is strategically sound, although I have no confidence this leadership team can accomplish that due to poor management/leadership style.

review_title: Lots of lip service and hypocrisy at the top
pros: My particular team comprises genuinely friendly and enjoyable people, our immediate leadership is very family-oriented, we have regular work from home days, there is a good amount of money allotted for career skills education and training, and of course—free snacks in the kitchen. However, I know from colleagues in other locations this is not the norm across the organization.
cons:
The company claims to be a progressive leader in wellness, espousing the importance of whole well-being (“physical, social, emotional, and financial”; “body, mind and spirit”). However they are a health insurer that offers only their worst, highest-deductible health plans to their own employees.  I have a $10K deductible for myself and my daughter. Mental health services, chiropractic services, acupuncture, all of my prenatal appointments (I just received my second ultrasound bill for $1K) are considered non-essential and are therefore not covered until I meet my deductible (as yet unclear whether they’d be covered even then). Every single colleague I have met whose partner is fully employed with medical coverage has chosen to be on his/her partner’s insurance. Not Aetna’s.

Aetna claims to score exceptionally well on gender equity throughout the organization, yet offer ZERO paid maternity leave to their employees—forget about paternity leave. They also don’t have a single HR resource to support or advocate for women navigating the very confusing and complicated process of applying for disability (6 weeks at 60% pay) and federal FMLA leave (12 weeks of job-protected unpaid leave during which you are considered an inactive employee and will be paying 100% of your health care premiums). I actually have yet to meet any HR rep within the company who advocates for the employees. Period.

Furthermore, they employ a forced distribution curve for annual performance ratings, a practice which only demoralizes and demotivates high-performing employees and encourages mediocre, just-enough performance from everyone. If busting your butt, repeatedly going well above and beyond, and producing top-tier work that’s applauded by executive leadership only gets you a 3 rating (i.e. average, “meets expectations” performance; a 2 rating requires you be placed on a performance improvement plan which can lead to termination) then what are you trying so hard for? 

I have personally experienced (and heard about from other managers) a high incidence of low-performers within the organization—hugely costly. I also know via my peers that it is incredibly difficult to fire someone. 99% of the time those low-performers just get moved around to different departments.

And then, of course, you have very high turnover for top talent. Not the best recipe for transforming the healthcare space.

And... the merger with CVS has only made everything even less favorable for our employees. Our benefits are starting to be stripped away—for example, no one even uses the awards and recognition program anymore either because they’re no longer allowed to (only managers can give points now) or because the points are relatively worthless (1/5 the value we used to get pre-merger). I am confident this will only worsen once all benefits are completely integrated in January 2020. 

There is currently no upward mobility—countless promises of promotions, raises, and even just full-time status that have never been delivered. Our team is replete with contingent/contract employees who are 1-2 years later still waiting for full time status promised to them shortly after hire.

As a manager, things are especially difficult because there is very little benefit I can offer my direct reports (no promotions, nearly nothing raises, only paltry, meaningless bonuses). Its also virtually impossible to hire—even to backfill for employees going out on leave and those who leave us permanently!!—because we are almost never given an open requisition and often have them taken away when employees leave us.

These operational practices are damaging to your culture and ultimately unsustainable.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Hartford, CT
pros:
Aetna is one of the most inclusive and wellness-focussed companies around. 
There are plenty of opportunities for personal and professional training and growth. Senior Leadership have a good vision for where they want to take healthcare.  
In IT we are finally getting to move toward up-to-date technologies, DevSecOps and using Agile.  The company is exceptionally good at what we do.
cons: There will always be bureaucracy in a huge company, so you have to go in knowing the this is not a super quick moving little company.

pros: Learning is great, Work Flexibility offered, Lot of other small perks like buying good through Aetna marketplace, Gym and fitness discounted membership, encouraging employee to stay healthy by reimbursement benefits $500 per family
cons: Salary Rise is very poor, no bonuses, frequent senior leadership org changes, No proper PMO structure, Lot based on Vendor team, highly political/performance based on Favouritism

job_title: TX Star Kids Medicaid in Arlington, TX
pros: Flexible, health incentive,  pot lucks, no weekends, no late nights
cons: Nepotism, Bad communication,  department is full of cliques and drama.

review_title: Change Constantly Is The Aetna Way
job_title: Case Manager (RN) in Sugar Land, TX
pros: The convience of working from home and not having to report to the office. They also have a good PTO plan so you almost always have time available for vacation and personal issues.
cons: Constant changes and everyone on a different sheet of paper. Management finds a new area of concentration and harp on getting that done and by the time you get acclimated to doing what they ask they change the policy to doing it a totally different way.
