The pay increases are based on your evaluation scores that you receive from your manager and they tend to score people that are in their clique high than a work that is actually performing at a higher performance level.

job_title: Pharm Tech in Kansas City, MO
pros: I got a lot of great mail order experience in different departments. I loved the employee appreciation months. The pay got better the longer I was there. I had a wonderful supervisor.
cons: They laid me off after I had been there for one month shy of 7 years.  And it was the day after a blizzard, which I had made it to work for the day before.  The managers don't seem to care about anybody, just the numbers and productivity.  I gave excellent customer service, but that did not seem to matter to them. All they care about is laying people off.

pros: Work at home capabilities, good salary, PTO is comparable or slightly better than competition.  CEO  seems to care about employees.
cons: High cost of benefits,  leaders lack knowledge to do their job, workload is too high. There is always pressure to do more to answer to worthless reports. Managers always looking for a win--win, even when doing so goes against policy.

review_title: BRUTAL!  YOU ARE A NUMBER...not a human being!
pros: Medical coverage from day one.  Discount at CVS Retail Pharmacies.
cons: Horrible management.  High turnover.  Inadequate, terrible training.  Very STRESSFUL environment.  I promise, if you don't have mental health issues now, you will after working for this company.  You will never meet your supervisor because they will be in an office halfway across the country from you.  Just when you think you halfway know what you are doing, you will get moved to a different supervisor and have to learn an entirely new plan to support with minimal training, if any at all.  There are no opportunities to advance because the metrics are unrealistic.  Worst company I have ever worked for.

review_title: Overall positive experience in opportunities but size of organization and conflicting priorities create increased work.
job_title: Director of Operations in Blue Bell, PA
cons:
Constant pressure to do 'more with less' as they compete against WellPoint and United on cost per member but need to invest more in systems to improve this markedly.

Impacts to staffing done through outside consulting group and may not have fully understood resource values or how the operations really work.

Talk work life balance, but do not enable it.

For a healthcare insuracne company, employees pay a higher share than most companies that buy from Aetna.

If not located in Hartford, opportunities for advancement are more difficult.

review_title: Able to be a Strong Patient Advocate (RN) but working for Big Business mentality
pros: Like what I do on a day to day basis and have the ability to work at home.     Compensation when figured into an hourly pay is okay, it's fair.  Work-life balance is okay there is some flexibility.  My immediate supervisor is very good.   Overall I am a happy Aetna employee.
cons: Big business, job security is always in question.  Squeezed for more and more, disposable employee culture.  Work in crisis mode till burn-out.  Employee health insurance benefits are very expensive and coverage limited.  Aetna can write a great benefit package but they do not provide that great package to their employees.   I always wonder if the C-suite has the same benefit package.

review_title: Had the potential to be a great company but consistently makes decisions to offshore and lay off employees.
pros:
Training budget
Flexible schedules
Allows work at home
cons:
No career building
No growth opportunities
Consistently make the wrong decisions and never learn from the negative outcomes

review_title: Aetna was so much better before CVS
job_title: Utilization Review Nurse in New Albany, OH
pros: You can work at home.
cons: They only offer High deductible HSAs and they reduced the 401k match from 6% to 5 %. They took away the tuition pay back and the day after Thanksgiving is no longer a company holiday so most employees will have to work that day. No more MLK day either, instead they give you floating holidays and who knows when they will take them away. The dental insurance premium doubled from when it was Aetna. The raises are only 1 % per year and you don’t get one the first year you work there. I wish Aetna would have just stayed Aetna without CVS.

review_title: Excellent place, proud, great product line to work in
pros: The product I support is AMAZING to work in. In my role I get the chance to reach out and be exposed to MANY high ranking employees. Everyone is very competent and never say no. PTO is never denied, even when busy, overtime is great, work from home is granted to every member of the unit. Love it! Benefits are better than our competitors, UNH has higher cost medical, lower 401k match, higher deductibles. Heres a tip you get $600 off a year for, not using tobacco and passing metabolic syndrome. I pay $11 a check.....
cons:
Pay for gym- cheaper than my other gym- Anytime fitness
Acquisitions on the rise, would rather see in-house development
Conservative Approach to Underwriting- Take more risk- win more bids

job_title: Technology Manager in Blue Bell, PA
pros: It's a job and the people are generally very friendly.
cons: Management views employees as a necessary expense for doing business; little or now employee loyalty is the result.  They also initiate a number of initiatives to improve employee morale and assess advancement opportunities, but these initiatives are insincere.  Often, these initiatives are reviewed against metrics regarding participation and completion rates (ex: 100% of employees reviewed), but little or no attention is givne to the quality of information exchanged.  And, little or no followup.  Lastly, for being a healthcare company, their employee health benefits are the worst I've ever had.  They often "experiement" with new HC benefits programs and force them on the employees.

review_title: Very good employer for work-at-home employees, for the most part.
pros: Pros: The opportunity to work at home in many (but not all) instances, paid time off, daily flexibility
cons: Insurance deductible is so high it renders the policy all but useless, unless you get very very ill. Training leaves alot to be desired so people are rarely on the same page and customers get told conflicting information. So many jobs have been outsourced to India, and training for these people is even worse, they make the same claim mistakes over and over which the US employees then have to correct. We also bear the brunt of customer frustration over these errors.

review_title: Aetna, a tough place to work, but worth it overall.
job_title: Concurrent Review Nurse in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Multiple positions across the nation, opportunities to transfer.
cons: No Balance of Life-Work hours for salaried employees. We work a minimum of 60 hours a week just to keep up (barely) with the demands of our departments. No acknowledgements, thanks ever from Senior Management for working over and above required 40 hours a week, routinely.

job_title: Case Manager (RN) in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Loved working at Aetna as did my colleagues.. We all miss working there to this day.
cons: The company terminated our whole department before Christmas. Some of us were transferred to other jobs, which was  great. but if it wasn't a good fit you were stuck there for a year before you could change.

pros: Work from home. Work from home. Work from home. Work from home work from home work from home. Work from home. Work from.
cons: Changing work week for nurses, initially hired as Monday thru Friday and no holidays, now want to make nurses work anywhere from 6 to 7 days a week with little incentive. No overtime.  Will not listen to nurses who actually do the job already short on staff.  Will not consider a weekend team of nurses.  Passive aggressive threats to force nurses to "volunteer" or will have to be mandatory.  No planning just bad ideas that the upper management implements and the lower level employees have to follow.

review_title: A good place to work where employees are treated fairly and are generally happy, if slightly underpaid.
job_title: Underwriting Consultant in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: Employees are treated fairly.  The company is transparent and has a good reputation within the industry.  The work/life balance is good.  The company places strong emphasis on values and integrity; consequently, employee morale is generally high.  The company's financials have consistently been strong as Aetna has provided a good ROI from a profit, revenue, stockprice, etc. standpoint.  Aetna definitely feels like a "best of breed" company.
cons: Compensation is somewhat lacking and below average for the industry.  Aetna stresses efficiency, so company  perks can sometimes be limiting.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Higher than average wage, lots of overtime, steady m-f schedule , great co workers
cons: Unknowledgeable Supervisors/Managers, too many tasks to complete during shift. Too much stress and not enough training on how to handle issues. Rare chances to post out of position due to shortage of employees on phones. Worst of all so much favortism , most coworkers would like to leave dept but hourly wage keeps most of them stuck there . Very low morale.

review_title: A throwback to legacy, old-fashioned America
pros: If you're an insurance actuary, this will be nirvana...
cons:
Atavistic throwback to mid-century American corporate culture...phlegmatic, rigid and hierarchical
Stocked with many 2nd and 3rd generation Aetna-ites and/or Aetna lifers
And stocked to the gills with 50%-60% actuaries who are 2" wide and 20 miles deep
Getting hugely roughed up with self-inflicted acquisitions, Obamacare and failure to keep up with "best practices"
The worst HR department I've ever seen, bar none...

pros: It's decent salary that's all. No compassion.
cons: Things are not right at the top, so how could they possibly  be right at my level?

review_title: Great company with a bright future
job_title: Provider Complaint and Appeal Analyst in Fort Wayne, IN
pros:
Continually plans and stays ahead of the changes in the industry so not taken by surprise. 
Good health and 401k benefits. 
Compensation above industry standard.
cons:
High stress at times with little compensation for the amount of stress expected to deal with on a daily basis. 

Seems to not be concerned with impact of stress on life outside of working hours with indefinite mandatory overtime. Offers programs to speak with someone to manage stress but unwilling to change anything on their end.

pros: Work from home, in your pajamas
cons:
SLAVE LABOR OUT OF YOUR HOME!
Constant monitoring by keystroke and Skype, for a "professional job".  Told by a manager that she needed to be notified when I left the house during work hours. Not able to take vacation when requested, as constant coverage of other employee's work is required. Only 1-2 people allowed to take holidays at a time on the team. Had to pick between Thanksgiving , Christmas, or New Years, and 
that was based on the supervisor's favorites. 10 hour days on the computer. Mandated weekends for nurses recently required, without a written policy.
Low salary, poor or no bonus.

review_title: Good Company.  Direction to move forward in your career is not clear
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cranberry Township, PA
pros:
Benefits:
The 100% 401K match up to 6% of your salary is a nice benefit.  The company also offers discounts on your medical policy premium if you meet certain qualifications.  There is a HSA or HRA Fund (depending on your type of policy) that the company adds funds to if you hold a medical policy.  There are also wellness programs to get additional funds to use towards paying your member responsibility on claims. 

Work Environment:
Monday-Friday business hours.  Hours can be flexible depending on your direct management and position.  If you have the capability of working virtually and there is inclement weather, your manager can give you the approval to work from home.  There are also opportunities to work at home anywhere from 20% to 100% of the time.  There are constant changes within Healthcare so that means constant changes in direction and responsibilities.  You may work on projects for a month or multiple months and they end up taking a complete 180 degree turn.  Putting all the time and effort into the projects without seeing the fruits of your labor can be discouraging, but it's important to look at it as a learning experience.

Culture:
Aetna encourages giving through food drives and clothing drives.  There are interactive activities to get people involved in giving and to promote culture within each office location.  They even match monetary donations you make to a certified 501(c)(3) organization.
cons:
Promotions:
There is a general lack in promoting within a current position.  You can show up to work without ever calling off then meet and exceed all quality and production standards for multiple years without receiving a promotion.

Mid-Year & Year-End Reviews:
You are responsible for writing your own reviews.  There is little direction from management on how detailed you should be when writing your review.  Whether you put everything you work on or a brief overview it does not seem to matter.

review_title: So much great talent, so poorly deployed.
pros: Very talented people in some departments/capacities.  You'll learn a lot. Compensation can be lucrative. Lots of jobs pushed to "work-at-home" environment, which seems to work well for those with many years of experience at Aetna.
cons: I don't have anything against the company. It'd odd... over the course of time, it seems to me that Incompetent backstabbers seem to be the ones who rise to the top at Aetna. They usually don't last. TONS of turnover at senior levels.  Benefits mediocre.  "Work-Life Balance" is a joke.   Work environment is about the same as a can of sardines -- very tightly packed.

pros: Large company with ample room to move around and form an entire career.
cons: Executive leadership has never been more egocentric.  Decisions are being made based upon how it will be viewed in one's legacy.  What is most business wise has fallen to a distant second in critical decision processes.  The Board has also never been more disengaged.  The stock run up since 2010 has been nice; the Board has so enjoyed the riches, but abdicated from their fiduciary responsibilities.

review_title: More of a disaster than I was expecting
pros: Talented people, opportunities to learn
cons: No plan for career paths, lack of good management, no process for workflow, managers don't listen to employee issues, doesn't care about good user experience for products, bad insurance coverage, managers too far removed and don't want to get involved enough to understand what the day-to-day workers deal with

job_title: Business Systems Delivery Specialist in Middletown, CT
pros: Great benefits, work/life balanace, nice gym facilities and outdoor trails, community services sponsored by the company - bbq's, games, service days. One will get new projects every now and then. Good for technical skill building if you are new to the workforce. They hire lots of interns and new grads from CT schools. Most of them continue to work at Aetna after their internship is over. Middle management is good in their leadership skills.
cons: Large company - lots of layers to ger something done. This is a norm in a large company. If you expect things to be done in a day.. this is not the place to be at. Most projects are months and years long before you see a product.

pros: The rotational program (in some departments) is a great way for employees to gain an overall well-rounded experience in the health insurance industry. Job rotations help increase exposure to various aspects of the business, thus helping employees develop professionally.
cons: The salary level is several thousand below the rate offered for similar positions at other insurance companies. The company probably would use their positive company culture as a defense to this claim but, honestly, that doesn't put bread on the table.

pros: flexible schedule, nice co-workers, time off
cons: Ageism, nepotism.  Always trying to get older employees to take early retirement.  If you are over 50 stay away.  I was put on admin action because my stats were not up to standard.  i exceeded my 70 claims but was told i was not doing enough "weighted claims".  Always promised to help you, gave it to you for a day or two and took it away.  They are good at covering their corporate a---  in my training class 5 members were related to an employee, two daughters, cousin sister.

pros: Cheap premiums (but still high deductible)
cons: Everything. There is nothing great that came out of CVS acquiring Aetna. They lowered tuition reimbursement, they lowered 401k match, they took away 2 paid holidays, they took away OT. They only care about their numbers they meet and don’t care who gets stepped on in the process. They want us to fight for their customer but don’t fight for us. You have to come in when you’re sick or you get an occurance. My own family deductible is $6500 a year, and I WORK FOR THE COMPANY who owns the Insurnace. Raises and bonuses is a joke, that’s even if you get one that year. Carpet, desks, and chairs are old and dirty. I could continue on how they treat their employees but I hope just based on that information you look for other employment.

review_title: Can be great if you have a good manager.
pros:
Opportunity to work from home
Tuition reimbursement
Opportunities for professional development
The company values are great and are talked about a lot
cons:
The company values are often not upheld
Medical benefits are terrible
Frequent layoffs
Managers that really shouldn't be in management (constant screaming and swearing at people, inappropriate/unprofessional comments, etc.)
Depending on your manager, you may be expected to work a minimum of 12 hours per day plus weekends if you are exempt (no overtime)

pros: The CEO is visionary and determined to lead the reformation of the health care delivery system, something the country badly needs. The company is also trying hard to change the way it does business in order to keep up with all those changes.
cons: Restructuring and reorganizing felt constant when I was there. The strategic direction is a change, but a few levels down from the top it is a lot harder to implement.

pros: Lots of ee benefits available to choose from. Parking was convenient. Cafeteria right on site. Gym onsite. Doctor's office onsite. Ability to meet lots of different people in many different positions.
cons: The company seemed to be cutting back on paying for things in many ways. Most years, they'd pay less of your medical premium, while you paid more. Employees with more than 25 years service lost a weeks vacation. Had to pay for parking.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Moon Township, PA
pros: Steady hours are provided with no mandatory OT, the benefits aren't horrible, and wage itself is tolerable (recently raised everyone to a minimum $16.00/hour)
cons: more stressful than you may think, a lot of disorganization, severe lack of training/informing about new policies, training is only done after audit error is assigned, complete lack of incentives to excel (seems to be a dead end), PTO is offered but very limited on time to take it (only 3 people can be off on a day and as soon as a month is made available all Fridays/Mondays are taken so if you want to use a week of PTO for vacation, you typically must know 6+ months in advance, and hope you are quick enough the day the request schedule is posted)

job_title: Director, Strategy and Operations in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Emerging niche in an important industry. Flexibility to work from home when not traveling. Partnered with forward-thinking health systems.
cons: Management very disconnected from the market.  Group was supposed to operate independently from Aetna corporate, but this never happened.  Client-facing managers and directors were assigned to Aetna corporate bosses who refused to meet in-person and led from behind.  Young, eager employees were not respected - every new manager and director with less than three years at Aetna left due to frustration, and only career-Aetna employees stayed, furthering the generational divide.

review_title: Not a great experience. When you are not an executive or higher up management, you are treated as so.
job_title: Wellness Consultant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: You can work from home with full autonomy. Great benefits if you participate in their wellness program. Regional position so, a bit more flexibility to work how you’d like.
cons: Salary was almost non-negotiable even though I had proof that new counterparts were making $25k more than me with the same experience and job description, just a different title because of the different regions.

pros: Work at home, lots of independence in your job.
cons: Poor management, if you were competent worker and knew what you were doing you were overloaded and the slackers were allowed to continue to be non-productive.  The right-hand didn’t know what the left hand was doing. Different departments unable to work together to achieve a common goal. Given an early retirement, just another way of laying you off because you make too much money. No adherence to the so-called work life balance. It’s ridiculous to have to use PTO when working for a healthcare company to go for a doctors visit when you are a salaried “exempt” employee.  Not allowed to flex time, this varied from department to department depending on who your supervisor was. I could go on and on.

review_title: Aetna cares about you as an employee!
job_title: Medical Claim Examiner in Tampa, FL
pros: They care about their employees, they have great advancement opportunities, it is a wonderful company to work for. Aetna encourages its employees to excel in areas such Collaboration/Teamwork -Constituent - Focus/Service Excellence -Diversity- Innovation -Leadership and Operational Excellence/Profitability halping you to be all you can be :)
cons: If you live in Florida chances are you will need to move up to Hartford, CT where its headquarters are located and f you want to be part of Top Management or work directly with the Marketing department this is the city where you will need to work.

pros: You will have an opportunity to learn a variety of skills and potentially move to other positions once you are with the company.  Some departments/areas are better for these opportunities than others.  Also, some managers will support their people more than others. Probably not that different from other large companies.
cons: There is a marked lack of coordination/communication between departments even when they are all trying to accomplish the same goals.  Not all departments, however, are trying to accomplish the same goals. In some areas, metrics rule, and the path to the end result is inconsequential. The technology and infrastructure is not always the best.

pros: Schedules are strictly Monday - Friday, benefits are okay, plenty of PTO time provided and management communicates with staff regularly.
cons: PAY!!!  Although there was recently an increase for staff, it is still not enough.  Furthermore, employees need to be recognized when they have exceeded the talent required for a specific location.  The right employees should be in the right places, meaning, a lawyer should not continue to work customer service or eventually they will leave. Finally, the need for workforce management is essential in a call center however, the availability to take time off or participate in a company event is only distributed sparingly.

review_title: Used to be a good place
pros:
Work at home opportunities, training is sufficient. 
If you're out of college good place to start, get experience and move on by 30 yo. This is the best advice a person can give you about working there. Cause by 40's they lay you off
cons:
Used to be good raises and bonuses. Not anymore. It's 1% and you get the you're lucky to have job speech. Very motivating. Place has changed over the years. Not what it used to be at all.  

CEO needed his 14 million salary to be 45 million in one year and then lay off people and then no money for projects and salaries and then AETNA buys another insurance company.  okkkkkkkkkkk

review_title: Good company, outdated programs and policies
job_title: Utilization Management Nurse Consultant in Richfield, OH
pros: Work at home schedule, excellent pay with 6% 401K match, no weekends or holidays, bonus yearly, raise yearly until you hit the top of the pay scale.
cons: Terrible documentation systems which are always slow running or crashing.  Poor communication.  Misuse of educated, clinical personnel in roles where non licensed people could do some job functions.  Focus is on reports and legal/quality vs really helping people. Emphasis on productivity and tracking every move you make creates paranoia among employees.

pros: Good company once in.  Good growth potential. Ability to move forward. Inhouse always has first option for openings.
cons: unforgiving if one wants to return.  No longer recognize prior experience, no longer offer pension plan. Salaries were cut 15% in Jan 2013 and are no longer competitive with the market place. Inequities in salary for same job of an existing employee. In todays environment if one wants to return the expectation is to accept a pre 2000 salary even if it is not consistent with current salaries of same job.

review_title: If Only They Followed Their Own Professed Values
job_title: Senior Provider Data Services Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: Diverse, opportunities to move up, decent benefits except medical, pay is okay
cons: OUTSOURCING to foreign countries, Management makes choices/decisions quickly without thinking about the total effect, management doesn't listen to employees, Work at home is limited in availability, little or no money spent on employee team building or activities, the values professed are often set aside if it suits management's needs, often unethical decisions are made to benefit reporting

pros: Work from home for the last 7 years, but there taking that away.  HR placed new hires to work from home immediately and now everyone is being affected by HR's actions.     Use to be an employee company, now employee's are just a number.
cons: They hire outsiders to come in and "clean house" with no knowledge of the functions, cutting jobs and thinking the employees that still has a job can pick up the slack.   In all reality, those who still have jobs and over worked already and now your demanding them to do more.    Keep the people who has shown dedication and loyalty to the organization.

job_title: Grievance and Appeals Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros:
HR is easy to get a hold of and work with.
PTO is accessible to use
cons:
Management sees you as a number, they offer no work life balance, they only care about themselves, rules do not apply to management. Supervisory is not capable to make a decision on their own to save a life this is very frustrating and pointless to have a supervisor.  They make no effort to care of know individuals on the team and no incentives. 
Health insurance is expensive and horrible coverage.

job_title: Senior Software Developer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Job security. Good training. Many internal jobs. Telecommuting encouraged. Little overtime. Comfy chairs. Decent monitors. Fun outside activities. Little covered parking. Quiet workplace. Big desks.
cons: Red tape. People never leave, even when they should. Healthcare IT can be tedious and boring. People rarely respond to e-mails. Many "fires" exist only in the minds of executives, even when they are not a big deal. Computers are slow, and outdated. Difficult to get new hardware. Red tape is very difficult to deal with. Too many departments that do to little. And even within their sphere of expertise, knowledge is lacking. Crappy VOIP phones.

pros: Overall the organization is a good place to work.  There are a lot of opportunities for growth.  Senior leadership does a good job in communicating the annual goals of the organization. The work at home policy is fantastic and it allows for greater flexibility in the work/life balance.
cons: As some others have stated, some managers only care about numbers.  Promotions and favoritism are quite prevalent in the various departments.  Not all managers are receptive to new ideas.  Unfortunately, due to the changing environment of health insurance, there is a constant state of restructuring.  The inevitable outcome is lay offs which have been occurring at least once a year.

pros: Pay some of the "benefits" such as wellness perks bonuses.hours of operation being strictly m-f with options for OT. can be life long career
cons: Cost of benefits expect to see a min of 300 a month for a family of three , office politics, the HR help desk is rude and inconsistent

review_title: Wait for the full completion of the CVS merger
job_title: Customer Care Consultant in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Will randomly buy lunch for the whole team
cons:
Benefit package - not beneficial 
Compensation - average
Leadership - inexperienced and misguided
Goals - unclear
Direction - lacks
Communication - minimum and consistently inaccurate
Reorganization - 4 times in one year

pros: There are many different employment opportunities available. Work at home options are great. Great 401k match. Casual environment. The CEO implements an open-minded attitude. Workers are friendly, and teams tend to have a family-like feel to them.
cons: The salaries at Aetna tend to be low, unless you are in management. Their business strategy seems to have been to offer early retirement to the experienced workers, and snag those struggling in the tough economy at a low salary. The low salaries cause a poor turnover rate, and this hurts teams that have jobs with steep learning curves. Communication between teams is poor. There are many occurrences of inefficiencies that cause resources to be poorly managed.

review_title: Full of promises that are never kept
pros:
Flex schedules
PTO
SOME of the people there were awesome.
Paid holidays
cons:
TERRIBLE health benefits- for a HEALTH INSURANCE company, you would think they would offer their own employees decent benefits..um, not so much.

Occurrences- got a sick child? Are you snowed in? Did you just get admitted to the hospital with a serious illness? Does NOT matter. You will still get an 'occurrence'..get a few of these, and you're outta there.

Ancient systems- um, AS400 needs to go and the other systems are just awfully slow and painful to use.

Some of the supervisors are just clueless.

pros: Great benefits! Great team! Great leadership! Great opportunities! I tremendously enjoyed my time and learned an immense amount of information.
cons: There is entirely too much work pressed into too little time. While I know that the people that I reported to were not in the game for fame or self-importance, I couldn't help but feel that more than once way too much was promised for delivery in an unreasonable time frame.  The pressure is at time daunting.

review_title: Flexible,  Member Centered MCO but with Limitations
pros: Flexible work arrangements and meaningful work.  There are a lot of different programs designed to improve health outcomes for their members and to keep their employees healthy. Annual bonuses are a plus.
cons: For-profit entity. Relatively new to the Illinois market. Case loads are difficult to manage with the amount of documentation that is required after visits with members. Compensation seems relatively low compared to competitors. Very high healthcare deductibles.

review_title: Good Pay if you can stay
job_title: Escalations Supervisor in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Good pay once hired on, decent benefits. Clean building.
cons: Have to wait over a year to be hired permanently, if at all.  Sever low wages until you prove yourself worthy to be employed. Horrible working hours. At the mercy of direct management if they WANT you to have a raise or not.  Management was afraid to handle bullies on the floor. Constant turn over of employees. Frequent turn over caused a lot of confusion with wrong information being given constantly. This made multiple repeat and angry callers.

review_title: Changes are making a lot uncomfortable
pros: Work/life balance most of the year is very good besides during the busiest time of the year. Work from home can really help with this because I'm not super close to my office. For the most part my team is filled with hard workers. My manager and director are super supportive of my aspirations and give me new challenges when they arise. If I could give my team and through director 5 stars I would.
cons: CVS chipped away at our benefits. Personally speaking, I will be losing out on at least $5,000 worth of fringe benefits (primarily student loan repayment / tuition reimbursement for current classes) next year. We also lost out on $200 in wellness reimbursement, $500 in HSA contributions for doing challenges. In addition to changing our 401k contribution from 6% to 5%.  They pushed back announcing all compensation changes until May. So come May, they may drastically increase our salaries to compensate for the changes in benefits...but I have little hope. Also in the first few months there have been layoffs of colleagues have been in the company for a long time. It's just making things pretty uncomfortable all around.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Fresno, CA
pros: They are accepting of all types of personalities. If you have had a problem fitting in, in a professional office setting then Aetna is a great place for you. Some mangers are excellent at attending to the needs of employees, with regards to work life balance and advancement.  Pay is okay.
cons: Some managers only care about the numbers. Lots of uncertainty because of Health Care legislation right now and layoffs continuing to happen. No upward mobility due to hiring freeze which is not scheduled to end until 2011. Stock has took a dive since CEO took over

pros:
- Work life balance is ok for most
- Benefits are OK
- Conscientious effort to attract new, diverse talent for aging work force 
- Perks such as tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment, health screenings, Apple watch discount
cons:
- Low pay
- Health plan is not good  (My wife's company offers Aetna. I did a comparison for family health insurance. Aetna was only slightly better in terms of deductible and Out-of-pocket max)
- Can easily be pigeon-holed into current job role
- Aging workforce, lifers
- Low opportunity for upward growth. Traditional culture for advancement, facetime at HQ

pros: Can’t really think of any.
cons: Salary is just so-so, rigid micro-managing supervisors, horrible working conditions, dishonest hiring practices. I was told in the interview that I’d go into the office the first day and pick up my equipment and then all my work would be telecommuting and meeting with my case load in the community. Several months later I’m still stuck in a tiny cubicle without even a partition between me and all the other employees who talk and have loud phone conversations all day. The work day is complete chaos with constant interruptions. They dangle the telecommuting carrot frequently, but only those who are the supervisor’s pets get that benefit. There is absolutely no flexibility, nor is there any respect for employees and their needs.

job_title: UM Nurse Consultant in High Point, NC
pros: logging off and going home
cons: no management support, grossly mismanaged operations. rampant favortism. high turnover staff. no life work balance working 1-2 friday eve a month, 2 eve a month. 2 sat a quarter (with no day off during week), 2 major holidays a year.  expected to work long hours on regular basis to meet tats. high deductible insurance plans for employees. hostile punitive tat environment. punitive environment. too many chiefs not enough indians. team leads support sups not nurses. poor mgmt follow up, love to say we are working on it

review_title: Sincerely mission-driven and great leadership opportunities
pros: All of the work is tied back to the strategic mission of creating a better healthcare experience. Truly feels like an innovative place to work and make a real change happen. There are many opportunities to expand your career with stretch assignments. The leadership training is well designed and effective. Most of your colleagues will be committed, resourceful, respectful, and motivated.
cons: If you're looking for traditional work life balance where you clock in and out of a local office 9-5, this isn't the place for you. Hours and work locations are flexible, which can be great, but can also mean lots of after hours email, travel, and isolation.

review_title: Nursing Staff Treated as if Sweat Shop Labor
job_title: RN Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: None come immediately to mind.
cons: The company pays salary based on 8 hours a day. They continually inspect your availability due to lack of trust. They knowingly short-staff the nurses so the job can't be done in 8 hours. I routinely work 14 hours a day... somethimes 16 just to keep up with the workload. They don't pay for the overcommitment nor do they recongize the need for more staff to balance the workload. It's not an environment of respect for the individual's doing the work.

pros: Decent pay, ok benefits, good amount of vacation time, great co-workers.
cons: Not sure about other areas, but in regional business, we've had to worry about layoffs every year.  Aetna is a very top heavy company with probably hundreds of VP's, directors and heads of departments, yet can't manage to save jobs for front line staff when they need to cut costs.  I've noticed satisfaction with the company depends on whether you work in a large or small office.  If you're in a small office, you tend to be unimportant to Aetna.

review_title: Use only as a stepping stone- do not make career move
job_title: Care Management Associate in San Antonio, TX
pros: All the extra money comes with position. The flex schedule - and close location.
cons:
NO diversity - horrible management- they don't have good employee relations and horrible pay
  this place is only for one ethnic group to be successful. If you are a minority don't waste your time or talent. They will get in the door and then trick you and you will 'NOT" be successful.
You will be overworked and underpaid all the time... do NOT do NOT waste your talent - this a horrible place to work if you are a dedicated person /employee

pros: Inclusive environment, good benefits and flexibility. Decent pay, a bit low for typical applications development positions.
cons: Extremely political work environment, it is exhausting.  IT employees are treated as consultants and not respected at all.  Layoffs unfairly and disproportionally hit IT. Too much process and red tape, budgeting process is a mess, it is impossible to ever get anything done.  Technology is antiquated.  No desire on behalf of the business to partner with you.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Plantation, FL
pros: 401k, PTO 15 hours a month but that's pretty much it as far as the pros when it comes to Aetna
cons: They do not care about their employees they don't care if you have a life after you leave your job they don't want to pay you ,we're understaffed we're overworked they don't want to give us our bonuses they don't want to give us raises, they expect you to give a hundred percent when they're not giving you anything in return this company has changed in the last two and a half years since New Management took over and it is the absolute worst

pros: I have worked for Aetna for 14 years. Yes I have had my ups and downs but Aetna had always been there to help me through whatever it is I was going through professionally. There is a lot of opportunity if you are willing to work hard for it. Work at Home is great. Managers are great. The company takes very good care of their employees.
cons: I do not have any complaints. If I had to write one it is that they see more potential in me then I see in myself at times.

review_title: Wasn’t a bad gig until CVS took over
pros: Decent job. Get paid pretty well for what you do. Some company perks.
cons: Ironically the health insurance is awful. The only choices are super high deductible plans so you’re always paying for everything out of your pocket and I sometimes can’t afford to go to the doctor. Benefits got worse after CVS bought us. Not as good of a place to work anymore after the integration.

review_title: You can put down roots here
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Blue Bell, PA
pros: Aetna is a stable and solid company. Salaries and benefits are decent(not great) If you show up and meet the basic requirements of your position, you can enjoy a good work life balance with out a lot of "politics" Obviously, in a company of this size different areas/departments have differences, but in general this is not a company with a high pressure culture. For many years Aetna was kind of "stale" with many ingrained, old school employes but this has changed in recent years.
cons: Aetna can be some what burecratic at times

review_title: It's difficult to identify who is running the company Aetna or an acquired company
pros: the hours are great and its a casual office. Resources are plentiful making doing your job easier and accurate.
cons: There doesn't appear to be a main contact for HR issues. It is difficult to identify whose HR's rules you are to follow. You are told that you are following Aetna rules but your performance is judged by unwritten rules from a company that was Acquired. And the acquired company is more interested in protecting and advancing their employees rather than all employees.

pros: Overall, the people that support Aetna are fantastic.  Many front line people within sales, account management, and service, have a sense of purpose and are driven by the mission to serve its members.  Aetna has a great work life balance - as nearly 40% of its employees work from home.  I also believe that Aetna is poised to take on any challenges as it relates to healthcare reform and is working towards ways to differentiate themselves by providing tools that engage its members and providers in a positive and meaningful way.
cons: Being one that had a positive outlook at Aetna, it has unfortunately been shaped by some negatives.  First, the compensation is not competitive with the market - which is why I left.  Benefits were ok - as medical insurance premiums were relatively high compared to both current and past companies.  However, where I am most concerned is with how the current expansion into Canada has gone.  This has left some employees without access to benefits and has placed significant burdens on individual contributors well being.

pros:
You create your own promotions by searching for lateral jobs within the company.

You get to listen to quarter meetings on how the company is doing so that you can be mislead into thinking you will get a bonus and pay raise that match the company's pay-for-performance guidelines.

You get to create your own work performance reviews which no one reads but your manager..( sincerely... many department is capped on the amount of money for raises and bonuses and the number of 3 and 4s they can give out).

You can leave this job at any time and pick up a higher paying job doing similar work almost immediately..

The company thinks it is ok not to give you a pay raise because you are in the 75th percentile for your job function.

You will be judged on a 5 point rating system in which a 5 is NEVER given out ( not exaggerating..management says that in order to get a 5 you have to accept a promotion??).
cons: Terrible health insurance (not even taking into consideration (I WORKED FOR A HEALTH INSURANCE COMPANY), pay raises are capped to a max of 5%, so is the number of 4s per team (talk about a morale booster when you have always been a 4 to be told you are getting a 3 and management cannot do anything about it).  No continued training to expand upon skills, no time to do any of the tedious training because of the workload. Senior management does not care about you unless you do not perform (the lack of recognition makes me feel great because no mention of my name means that I did great), they get the huge bonuses and recognition..I get to keep a job..

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Like most companies, they  want more work for less pay. Benefits package could be better. Only offers HDHP options with significant cost to mid-level employees.
cons: Free healthcare for entry-level employees. Major focus on wellness for mind and body.  Company practices the message presented and leadership goals are driven by making better decisions everyday for our members.

review_title: Great place to work, employee friendly, good opportunities
pros: Flexible, good attitude from management, people are good to work with as well. They allow you to work from home and the hours are very flexible. Senior management needs to be a little bit more organized and communicate more. Employees are usually in the dark about what other groups are doing.
cons: Kind of disorganized. Flexibility also lends itself to having problems getting work done. Employees work from home and sometimes it's hard to find them. Be a little bit more organized and communicate more. Employees are usually in the dark about what other groups are doing.

pros: Work at home opportunities, good people
cons: Aetna restructures constantly and change can be good, but they have cut the organization so thin, that employees have NO work life balance, the expectation is that you work at least 12 hours a day, there is no training and no support for new employees from management.  Inexperienced management that could care less if you succeed or fail so long as they don't look bad.  Turnover is perceived as a good thing, rather than the loss of intellectual capital that is important to the customers.

pros: Benefit package is great.   Hours are good. Wellness programs are awesome.
cons: New management not very helpful to the department.  Alot of favoritism within a department of a smaller group.  Not very racially diverse in some departments.

job_title: Quality Management Project Manager in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Pay and benefits lower than other payoffs,  Trust in Leadership had waned with all the changes that had occurred in 2012 and beyond.  Immediate Supervisors were hard working.  Work life balance obsolete by 2017.  Early Retirement benefits excellent!
cons: No work life balanced evidenced as advertised.  Heavy workloads.  Average Project Manager, Mid-Level Management easily worked on average 60 hours per/week without improvement in site when I had taken Early Retirement.  Many in Quality Management long time employees retired (30-35%).

pros: Aetna provides reasonably good compensation and benefits.  Senior management clearly has a strategy for the company and communicates better than most executive teams to the organization. Integration of Coventry acquisition will be a big test.  Most of the people I work with are top notch.
cons: Aetna culture is still dominated by its Hartford commercial insurance mentality and while senior leaders talk about taking risk, it really does not happen.  Most staff functions like HR are now self service so line management carries the burden.  Emphasis on advancing women and people of color makes career advancement even more challenging for the remainder.

review_title: It's a shame that there is no job security
pros:
Work At Home
Opportunities to do different work if you work towards it
401k matched 6%
cons:
Lack of serious training
Benefits are consistently diminished each year
Bonus is not reliable
True promotion from within rarely occurs
Downsizing every single year
Stress from a highly regulated industry with huge IT demands and little IT budget.
Reorganizes major departments nearly every season.  Changes people's positions with little consideration of the employee.  No one knows who does what, and no one feels committed to their jobs.

job_title: Dental Customer Service in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Great learning experience, I certainly received a reality check in lots of different areas. I was very happy to make a positive difference in the lives of so many policy holders.
cons: Poor training from people unqualified to teach. Seniority counts for nothing outside vacation scheduling. Mgt promotes based on who they like personally. Salary increases based on team leaders favoritism. Entry level mgt the worst in categories of inappropriate gossip. If you become employed there, keep your mouth shut, and your personal business private. Opportunities for advancement almost nonexistent. Ageism is a serious issue.

pros: Nice pay and bonus program. Good work hours.  Great perks when you start.
cons: Poor Management, Poor leadership. No support on complex issues. Supervisors were always away from their desk and had a lazy work ethic.  Only received one big bonus in the beginning after that things always came up in your records to keep you from getting additional bonuses.

review_title: Great people and really good benefits!
pros: I really enjoyed who I worked with and even though I had several supervisors over the years. I had a really great one for the longest time. The benefits are really good and they try to help encourage staff with rewards. The working environment was pleasant.
cons: Could be very overwhelming and too much work to do. Had to put in extra time to get the job done but was paid well so I didn't mind doing it sometimes.

job_title: Customer Service Consultant in Bismarck, ND
pros: Get to learn about a broad range of issues on health care and there is good job security. The working hours are fair. There are opportunities to advance and there is a work at home option also. Aetna is becoming a leading in the health care industry which can make you feel confident to work for a company going in the right direction.
cons: The work repeats itself over and over again.  (Doing the same thing over and over.)  Some times the the work is intense on the brain as the job is to help with customers problems and that is sometimes challenging.

review_title: IT Project Managers and Business Analysts stay away.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Hartford, CT
pros: Flexible work schedules including work at home options is a huge perk, which is a big reason Aetna has been able to hold onto their top talent.
cons:
Lots of lay offs in the past at the worker bee level, but the same old IT management remains. Lots of changes to methodology but no real roll out strategy leaving many lost in the shuffle.  
They eliminated the Professional Dev Mgrs, and expect the Senior Program Mgrs to just magically develop leadership and management skills.  Very low morale, no managers developing their teams, no promotions for two years, and nobody holding these managers accountable.

job_title: Rehabilitation Consultant in South Portland, ME
pros: Aetna provides a positive and encouraging talent management process and support for  employees. They have many telecommute opportunities in claims, information technology and marketing. Stock options are available for employees at a discount.
cons: When production or other performance difficulties are identified, the human resource and management function is limited with the help it can provide. The employee evaluation process identifies where standards are not being met but provide little support for meeting those standards.

pros: Aetna is a great place to work. I was only there for a year, in the short time that I was there, I learned a lot about Medicare and improving my customer service skills. The pay is great, typically starting out at $16/hour. Training is for nearly 4 months, so they don't quickly rush out onto the phones. If you are stuck on a call and don't know what to do you can always call out to a fellow coworker who will be able to assist you. The PTO is great an the bonuses are always a plus.This is not your average call center. Benefits start immediately.
cons: No cons, great company to work for

job_title: Medical Social Worker in Portage, MI
pros: Pay was reasonable and co-workers are dedicated.
cons: Unrealistic expectations of employer regarding work expectations.  Caseload was over double of what was presented at interview.  This resulted in high turn-over of professional people as quality work was not able to be provided due to caseload sizes and lack of systems to be able to deliver needed services. Culture and values statements were not being practiced by mid and upper management.

pros:
Office building looks great from outside but nothing around there except Costco. 
Shuttle bus from the station but runs only 7:00 -19:00. Too far from the Farnborough station.
cons:
The management and supervisors are ignorant and rude. There is a presence of racial discrimination and the company ignores it and even the HR pretends that they don't see it .
Poor IT system and office facilities.
Hard to believe this is a global insurance company.  Lots of employees in this office are not highly educated. Many of them have no uni/colleage degrees. 
Not enough parking space although the office is located in the middle of nowhere. 
People come and go all the time. I have seen 12 people left the department in the period of a year but the management seems they don't care at all.

pros: The company has a good strategy and will probably do very well over the next few years.  Flexible schedules including work at home.
cons: The company doesn't value IT employees.  There has been at least one round of layoffs, and some times more, every year that I've been there.  At least 80% of IT got a $0 raise this year.  They also have a policy in which you can't bring on new IT hires in CT.  If a hire is to be made, it needs to be in a lower cost state.

pros: friendly people, stable place to work, generous benefit package, if you can get stock its performed very well over last few years, strong leadership team at top levels but middle managers / senior teams are pretty much a joke.
cons: has somewhat large bureaucracy to deal with, middle level / senior managers don't know what their doing and usually are not that skilled, culture depending on location can be depressing and feel like its stagnating, moving up is a difficult proposition given the hierarchy and the fact that some people stay there for life.

pros: Stable, long-term employer with solid presence in the business community.  Expanding customer base with a solid system interface for claimants and employer-plan sponsors
cons: A cumbersome claim system that does not facilitate claim reviews - the claim system was created for external customers at the expense of the claim processors.  Too great an emphasis on timely claim decisions, which results in a claim denial rate that greatly exceeds industry norms due to "inability to obtain information".  Organization places too great a burden of proof on the claimant.  Surprisingly poor medical benefits for a  medical carrier.

pros: promotional opportunities; 401k match; successful track record and longevity as a company; work at home opportunities for some positions; disability-friendly company; values diversity and inclusion
cons: below market salary; understaffed; high stress; long hours; favoritism; office politics; cutting benefits such as PTO and pensions; organizational inertia; bureaucracy

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Sandy, UT
pros: Starting wages are good, benefits are pretty good.  Small for a call center, which is nice.  The people are friendly.
cons: Office morale is low.  Attendance policy is ridiculous and strict.  You get PTO but there is also NO way to use it for sick time or for unplanned events with out getting an occurrence.  The support is not there for questions during a phone call.

pros: Opportunity to participate in interesting committees and projects.
cons: HR actually lied about the benefits when I was hired.  I didn't find out until after starting the job that the benefits were much lower than that which was promised.  Also, following an integration we were given a much larger volume of work with no extra staff and told this situation was only temporary, but no additional help arrived.  My role was expanded numerous times over the years, but without any increase in title, salary, or benefits.

review_title: Aetna offers incentives to adopt and maintain a healthy lifestyle. There are many opportunities to work from home.
pros: The company is concerned about the health and wellness of its employees and offers many incentives for eating well and being active. Internal job movement is encouraged, and employees can submit their resume on the Intranet and be contacted for job openings that match their skills set. Over 20% of the company's employees are teleworkers.
cons: In the field in which I work, Aetna does not have many opprotunities for advancement. However, there are many opportunities to grow if I choose to leave my field and stay with the company.

review_title: Tired of treading the retail hamster wheel?
pros: Pharmacists are very friendly,helpful, knowledgeable(re: biotechnology pharmaceuticals) good interdepartmental communications; frequent lunch and learns/continuing education; scheduled breaks and lunches; flexible scheduling options; large sized staff facilitates shift switching should unforseen emergencies or family needs arise. Weekly QA meetings to improve accuracy/customer care end points, and to improve learning of products.
cons:
Phone system needs improvement; pharmacists sometimes called/consulted on questions that should be directed to reimbursement. MD offices sometimes do not understand that pharmacists do not know the insurance specifics coverages/co-pays)in this setting; opposite to that expected at the retail level.
Commute time may be a little high if one lives in a county other than Orange

review_title: The company started off being GREAT!  Over the past few years you become a number.
job_title: Sales Support Specialist in Hartford, CT
pros: Good Pay, great systems and communication.  we had a full cafe and a gym on site.  Very good security too.
cons: In the sales dept. you will get walked all over by people if you allow it.  Management beign friends with your peers can also be an issue when it is time for rewards.  Medical benefits are poor for being a "Health Insurance Company".

review_title: It is a great company to work for.
pros: I have met some good coworkers and encouraging management here. Other Pros: 401K, PTO, Tuition reimbursement, Wellness Programs, growth in your career.
cons: Reorganizations are happening more now.  No, you are not laid off but you may be put in a job that you would not apply for.

review_title: Not the worst job I've ever had...but not the best!
pros:
- Steady job
- Not mind-blowingly difficult
- Comprehensive training program
- Seemed like you could advance to middle management fairly easily (woo hoo!)
cons:
- Boring, boring, boring!
- Pay was so-so
- Health benefits sucked!  Deductible was well over $1000, avoided getting care several times because I didn't have the money considering how much I was making.  HSA my @$$.
- Very bureaucratic
- Got several e-mails bullying employees into voting against health care reform (and this was during the Bush administration) - not cool.

review_title: A good solid company but communication has faltered with the numerous organizational changes over the last few years.
pros: Aetna is a well intentioned company with solid integrity.  It treats its employees moderately well although the constant attrition of benefits is a challenge like every company these days.  It still has a family feel in many offices and offers telecommuting opportunities in many departments.
cons: The current mantra is "creative destruction' and, from within the company, it seems more destructive than creative.  Core businesses seems to get short shrift although results are still required.  Its odd.

review_title: Difficult trying to get anything done
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Hartford, CT
pros: Work at home policy, decent benefits.
cons: Impossible to work efficiently.. Large corporate environment which takes months to get anything done, pace is slow and slower. There are several very talented people left however they are scattered among thousands of offshore/onshore consultants which have their own agenda. If you try to bring in a new new technology you will find push-back from the inexperienced consultant developers which outnumber you 9 to 1.  If they don't know the proposed technology they will do anything to avoid it.  They will typically write awful code and management which has no clue about technology beyond a few buzzwords doesn't know any better. Layoffs occurring about every 3 months lately and promotions, merit increases are nil which doesn't inspire much confidence for future of this company.

job_title: Prior Authorization Representative in Tampa, FL
pros: Pay is good, I love the type of work I do. Coworkers are good
cons: Management or lack of like to micromanage. Alot of employee management friendships. It's not what you know, its who you know! Plus, they are doing away with our whole department. Sending the work to the states we provide service to. I wish they would offer the few great employees with good work ethic and production to work fom home or something.

review_title: It's not what you know, it's who you know or who you're doing
pros: Steady paycheck, paid vacation, insurance  even though it stinks,  sometimes overtime.  Steady paycheck
cons: Too much favoritism,  people get promoted because they're friends or related to someone or in a relationship with someone.  Supervisors don't really have any authority,  upper management has no idea how to manage a pharmacy, so they constantly change the prosesses because the changes they've made aren't working. But of course they will never admit it!!

job_title: Provider Relations Department/Office Assistant III in Princeton, NJ
pros: Outstanding family/ work balance. Excellent benefit package. Diversity acknowledged. Respectful co workers and managers, who listen to your views and ideas. Room for advancement. Aetna gives the opportunity to work from home.
cons: Being a temporary employee with the company.

job_title: Senior Underwriting Analyst in Hartford, CT
pros:
- Great work life balance
- Benefits are OK
- Perks such as tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment, housing and more. 
- Employees are encouraged to get away from their desk from time to time 
- IN office culture is very good
cons:
- Low pay
- Health plan is not good 
- Sometimes feel pigeon-holed into current job role
- Low opportunity for upward growth.  Just title changes

review_title: Best large coporation I have ever worked for
pros: Great place to work.  Supportive, team environment and culture.  Focused on getting better at everything we do.  Emphasis on improving quality versus reducing costs.  High performance culture requires bringing your A game most of the time.  Very smart people all around to listen to and learn from.  Experienced and thoughtful management team.
cons: Lots of meetings.  Consensus culture not a fit for everyone.  Tend to overanalyze some things leading often stringing out decision making.

pros: The people who work at Aetna are extremely dedicated and are truly concerned about delivering quality and useful products to their customers.  I believe the people who work at Aetna are the most valuable asset of the company.  I also think that the company's embrace and promotion of the teleworking culture has been really well received by the employees and has allowed them to retain some great talent.
cons: The recent turn to the use of outside vendors has reduced the overall business knowledge in the IT domain, which in my opinion has increased the cost of delivering quality systems.

review_title: If you're not an F.O.E., your career is going nowhere
pros: Modern and clean work environment. Nice air conditioned offices. Updated technology.  Good online tools for doing your work.  Flexible work schedules.
cons: Weak leadership. Incompetence is tolerated if you are "in" with the head of human resources. Not safe to speak your opinion or share ideas that don't directly make HR leaders look good.  All the good people leave to join other companies.

review_title: Like Grandparents, you have to respect their accomplishments but it would probably be better if they passed on soon.
pros: Executive management is strong and admirable.  Work-At-Home and Location flexibility is modern and promoted company-wide.  An army of hard-working data entry and customer service representatives who keep the day-to-day actually functional.
cons: A bloated middle-class of middle-management which prevents the executive leadership's quality steering from having any effect on direction.  Their IT is about two generations behind in every area too, including crucial areas like data science and predictive analytics.

pros: Good Benefits. I LOVE the fact that they will cover $200 every year toward health improvement workout equipment etc. Its how i got my recumbent bike(stationary and small weight set). They care about the employees physical health.  They care about diversity in the workplace. I work for a program where we run into other case managers from another insurance company i cant name, but they had hjigh turnover and lack diversity.
cons: nothing big.I love my team.. another team had a supervisor that was disconnected from her team and it resulted in bad morale for that team. it improved when she left the company.

pros: There are some good people there.  If you report to a bad manager, welcome to hell!
cons: You will be harassed, insulted, lied to, and have corrective actions filed on you and refuse to say why or how to meet their phony 'goals'.  HR will do nothing, and they only care to find if there are easily provable ILLEGAL actions.  There are, but you know the legal system - esp with Corporations vs employees!  Almost nothing is off-limit for the sociopaths in that company.  They won't allow you to take PTO (and won't pay when you leave) and will make sure you don't get the pittance of unemployment.

review_title: Insurance Specialist /Case Managment Associate / Contact center representative
pros:
Big company with huge clients.
Easy to learn how work under pressure on daily basis with no exception.
50% of flexibility.
cons:
Management issues.
Hard work and commitment to the company's values are not enough for you to progress in your career.
Daily fake promises from management to keep your hopes and waste as much time as possible from your life and professional career.

review_title: good if you can get attention
pros: flexibility with work load, friendly people, good training, good opportunities when communicated.  can turn into a career if one is focused on such however it is just a job.  if you can catch a manager's eye and prove that you're an asset, they'll help.
cons: terrible medical benefits, work politics come into play more often than expected, no flexibility nor considerations for promotions.  someone could get the same promotion as you and you may have worked harder.  obvious favoritism does occur.

job_title: Case Manager in Blue Bell, PA
pros: The people I work with are some of the hardest working team oriented get the job done bunch I have seen anywhere
cons: Pay is mediocre. Time off is constrained by who signed up when due to chronic lack of adequate staffing. Again Poor staffing has been a constant since I came on board 2 years ago. People come and the smart keep right on going. The training is fair.  I have been reading some of the comments and maybe it is just my job description by my training if Fair at best.

pros: Large company with opportunities if you look for them
cons: Restructuring cuts were made without looking at talent -- were blindly made based on job-position only. A lot of talent was lost to competitors and the remaining staff has trouble focusing on their job instead of updating their resumes.

review_title: Somewhat of a professiona; yet laid back place to work depending of your supervisor
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Arlington, TX
pros: Shfits usually end at 6:00 pm and off weekends
cons: meeting daily stats appear to be more important than actually educating and helping the members with their health insurance concerns

pros: The company cares about their employees, in addition to their customers.  They do strive to have happy workers.
cons: While there's a lot of emphasis on wellness, mindfulness, and balance, the goals set to achieve financial success with less resources, make achieving these as a lifestyle a bit difficult.

pros: Learn a lot about the healthcare/medicare insurance industry.  Have the opportunity to resolve complex insurance problems.
cons: I received several job promotions but you can not advance higher than a supervisor role in this department. Even after years of  promotions and time with the company, my final salary only reached $40,000.   If your goal is to remain as a supervisor or if you plan to take  your experience to another company then you will be satisfied with this job.

pros: Flexible work from home schedule, 401k matching, PTO and wellness programs
cons: Poor healthcare options, Constant reorganization (yearly), outsourcing/onshoring, hard to advance career due to reorgs, increased workload over the past few years with no additional pay, CEO decision to merge with CVS (will greatly benefit himself not employees). BE CAREFUL - I had to use STD earlier this year due to unforeseen circumstances. I was just starting out in a new dept and was only back working 8 weeks and mid year reviews were underway. I was told I was having performance issues and was given a mid year rating of 2. I continued to do my best to change their less than favorable opinions of me but the negative treatment/feedback followed me for 6 more months. I was full time WAH but was told I needed to come into the office 3 days a week and start creating a detailed plan of my daily work. I’ve been monitored like a child on a daily basis for reasons I still don’t understand. I have been at the company for over 10 years and never had performance issues. I was reconsidering leaving the company due to the unfair treatment but I recently received another offer in a different dept. They attempted to sabotage the offer by telling the hiring manager negative things about my performance. It was a good thing the hiring manager wanted to hear my side of the story and ended up moving forward with the offer. I believe they saw through the nonsense and thank goodness they did. I am hoping to have a fresh start and prove I am the hard worker I’ve alway been.

pros: The top level, corporate vision of the healthcare world and its future is energizing and inspiring.  Corporately, they are actualizing much of that vision in real-world pilots, acquisitions and mergers.  Definitely a company to watch, even if the merger with CVS goes through...  Apparently, Aetna's vision is shared by CVS leadership.  This is the future of healthcare.  Much reason for healthcare "consumers", all of us,  and workers to be very optimistic.
cons: As with any very large organization, the vision and energy at the top does not always cascade to front line departments operationally.

review_title: Prepare to be overlooked and play lots of office politics games
job_title: Quality Analyst in Moon Township, PA
pros:
They used to have massage therapists and therapy dogs come in for stress management... if your supervisor allowed you to schedule time to take part.
If you did well on your review, and hit all of your "marks" or "KPMs" you could be given a yearly bonus (but it gets taxed to hell and back).
You could wear jeans and dress casually.
Some departments let you set your 8 hour shift (6am - 2:30pm, 8am - 4:30pm)
cons:
For the "town halls" you are encouraged to ask/submit questions, but if your question is controversial or something that's not "happy peppy look how great we're doing" expect it not to be asked
Reviews are ridiculous. You (without any instruction or guidance on how to) have to use an online system to prove that you've done a good job to deserve a good rating (which could get you a raise). Your supervisor can disregard this (and delete it) and write their own comments, and only their comments actually matter. You're told that the highest score you can get for your yearly review is a 3, which is a lie, there are higher scores (like 5) and with them come higher pay upgrades- just you won't get them, obvious suck ups do. 
Prepare to play lots of office politics games, it's exhausting how bad and very obvious it is.
Prepare to have any contribution you make, trend you've researched, or work around you've discovered be downplayed or ignored, or even better attributed to your supervisor and not you.
Prepare to get the bare minimum of trainings but be held to a standard as though you've received the most thorough review. Prepare to be trained in a system and then not use until a year later without/with barely and refresher.
Your supervisor rarely knows what it is you do, they are just there to overlord/babysit you.
People who have been there for 20+ years will try to tank you to make themselves look good, even though they are close to retirement and are out of touch with technology 
For a health insurance company, the employee health care plans are a joke.

review_title: Company culture changed over the years from "Mother Aetna" to "no More Mother Aetna, " post merger with US Healthcare.
pros: Excellent educational opportunites with in house teachers and an educational wing in Middletown.  But since the Middletown lease was up and all who worked there were etiher asked to work from home or move to the old ING building, not sure if the educational wing as also transplanted in Hartford.
cons: If your relationship with management is not good, move to another department.

pros: Management was friendly, and bonuses were offered for making stats. In the right department there were many ways to move up.. The company itself is a great company, the provider relations call center was not.
cons: The call center was very unorganized, everyday something was changing about how things were going to be handled. It made times longer because it was very confusing. Took some retirement from those who had been there for 20+ years.

review_title: I love working my job and the people I work with.
job_title: Claim Benefit Specialist in Gastonia, NC
pros:
Work/Life Balance.
Monday-Friday Schedule. 
Flex Time. 
Meal Waiver. 
The ability to go in as early as 5:45 or as late as 9:30, work your 8 hours and leave, as long as you don't take a lunch and have your meal waiver signed.
cons:
No sick leave. 
You will get an occurrence on and unplanned absence, which is bizarre because you can't plan sickness. 
Could use a little more training time.

pros: Salaries are competitive. Bonus plan is better than most. If eligible for stock options, shares issued are generous.
cons: Like any large organization, getting resources to complete work can be challenging. There is much confusion about where the company is going regarding accountable care, consumer services and traditional plan sponsors. The rejection of the Humana Acquisition creates more uncertainty about the future.

review_title: CVS takeover changed the company culture
pros: Good company with name recognition
cons: The culture at Aetna has been regressive since the CVS takeover. Aetna was a very progressive company and had lots of benefits for employees and really focused on work/life balance. Now, things have gone downhill fast and there's a reason there's been a mass exodus of upper management over the last few months.

review_title: Great way to get Healthcare or Insurance Experience on your resume
pros:
Fortune 500 Company
Reputation within Industry as a leading force
Well Recognized Name
Strong Brand
Resume building
Gain experience within the health and insurance industries
cons:
*Does not promote competent people

*Supervisors mostly have no previous management experience

*WORK/LIFE BALANCE IS NOT PROMOTED

*EACH DEPT ONLY CARES ABOUT THEMSELVES AND DOES NOT WANT TO HELP THE OTHER

*"Tuition Reimbursement" is a bait and switch. They have a school they claim they pay 100% tuition reimbursement and advertise it all the time. But what they dont tell you is that only one section in the entire company gets this privledge.

review_title: It's a job, not a career
pros: Telecommuting, PTO, healthy lifestyle compensation, very supportive of alternative lifestyles, promotes furthering education, friendly peers.
cons: Limited mobility, very low salaries for majority of workers, bonuses/raises do not exist, revamping benefits and taking more and more away, for a health insurance company the benefits are beyond ridiculous, no incentive to stay til retirement (if you're given the opportunity prior to job elimination), many co-workers push off work on everyone else. Mid-level managers are useless.

pros: Yearly bonus, good 401k plan, nice wellness program, nice company website with lots of information for employees, $200 reimbursement for fitness equip
cons: Despite career framework, difficult to promote your employees.  Expect long hours with no gratitude. Difficult to navigate HR issues. After 12 years of work at home,  pulled back in to local office despite not having any employees in that office. Executive management not forthcoming; hidden agendas. Management expects improvement and innovation with no means(funding or FTE's) to accomplish it. No work life balance. Political backstabbing.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Mid Florida, FL
pros: Good benefits package and ability to earn bonus. There is a relatively good support mechanism in staving off the monotony of the position.
cons: It can be relatively disheartening when your manager obviously plays favorites, and not with those who are most deserving or have the best performance. There is a tendency for back-stabbing and gossip, which can have an effect on behavior in the entire surrounding area. You can advance through mediocrity as long as you can be appropriately obsequious to management.

review_title: As a long-time Aetna employee, I would say that your Aetna experience totally depends on the department/management team.
pros:
Great management team in place that listens to employees; for a 150+ year old company, they are keeping up with technology and a variety of communication strategies to make Aetna the plan of choice in the country
Ability to work at home
Flexible schedule (i.e., 4 10 hour days, not just 8-5)
Great health insurance choices
Money in HRA/HSA for personal & family wellness initiatives
cons: Corporate staff does not always listen to the field staff that are actually out in the trenches trying to serve our membership.

review_title: A good company to work for, compassionate employers
