pros: They offer good PTO time, decent insurance, 401K,, very understanding with personal situations, Healthperks, cafeteria with decent pricing and food and various opportunities to comingle with other employees to provide a family atmosphere.
cons: Long hours, training is not up to par, some of the salaries are not equal to the abilities of the employee and there are instances of favoritism that should not be so apparent in a job atmosphere.

review_title: Aetna is a great company with impressive core values.
job_title: Senior Underwriting Analyst in Hartford, CT
pros: The organization is very receptive to process improvement, took development, and constructive criticism.  They are quick to take action in response to employee feedback and demonstrate the core values in every day decisions like company wide minimum wage of $15 and insurance subsidies for folks who do not make enough.  They provide a great work-life balance and offer many WAH opportunities.
cons: In some of Aetna's smaller departments they are slow to provide promotions.  While users can develop their own tools, many of our systems are slow to get updated or replaced which can often cause gaps in workflows.

review_title: Good if you like long hours
pros: With the exception of the somewhat costly health benefits, the other benefits -- especially related to health and wellness, as well as financial health -- are outstanding.  Also, the pressure/long hours varies by department.
cons: Most management expects long hours.  The idea of "PTO, or Paid Time Off" is a bit of a joke, as employees generally check e-mails and work during days off.

pros: Teleworking Option is a great resource. It saves in travel time and great for ones that live in areas that there aren't many big companies. There are strict rule about behavior that aid to there being a environment that fosters more trust. There will be no sides taken the rules are the rules. Excellent opportunities for bonuses.
cons: Wish there were more opportunities to move around but keep the Telework option and sometimes it seems that the job postings are for certain people that are already in mind and not a regular job posting.  Scorecards seem to be very complicated. Medical benefits could be a little better (High deductibles)

pros: Base compensation competitive, but they are not clear on communicating targets to achieve bonus.  Even when the bonus payouts are calculated, it's a secretive process with much fluctuation.  Directors or managers are rushed to put in dollar amounts, but these ultimately get adjusted by the most senior leadership.  For 2012 bonuses, employees were told that the decreased bonus distribution (ranged from 25% to 50% of what we were to get) was tied to Aetna stock price.  Then when Aetna achieved the market stock price, employees were told that there was an "internal" number/goal and we "fell short of that."  This logic  not was communicated when we set individual or team targets at the beginning of the year.  So, even now at the end of the first quarter employees are not clear on what it will take to earn a bonus in 2013.  However, it's very clear the company found 5 billion dollars to acquire another company and the CEO and his top tier  received full bonuses.  This has deeply impacted morale at the company.
cons: lack of consistency across product lines.  Riding on the coat tails and eputation built on commercial business, and trying to carry that momentum to government sector.  There is not strong leadership over government programs, and the company allowed lower level leaders construct RFP's and contracts that are going to be costly.  It seems the company will do anything to expand it's government sector, but at great cost to quality.  The training is nearly all virtual, and the IT support for the software, especially for clinical segment, is weak. The vision you get of Aetna for commercial products is the not the vision you see for Medicare and Medicaid product lines.  Aetna seems to be trying to acquire that, but the company they have acquired (Coventry) is not that strong itself.

pros: Flex time/Work at home.  Pay was decent -  hard to make as much elsewhere.  I worked at smaller division of Aetna, so not part of the mainstream corporation.  PTO is decent and annual bonus was usually paid to maximum or overfunded at times (except 2 yrs during recession).
cons: Difficult to find positions in larger corporation once you are acquired as a smaller division within Aetna.  Raises are supposed to be merit based, but "pool" for raises is so small that you end up giving the best performers maybe only a 1/2 a percentage more which doesn't add up to much! There is no measurement of workload - only need to get it done and since you are working from home unspoken expectation is that you get used to working at least 10 hr days, usually more during busiest times of yr and many work on wknds so you come into a heavy Monday if you don't do some work on wknds yourself.  Very Meeting focused culture -many of them not productive.  Difficult to tell who does what due to so many layers./depts. Rest of corporation not interested in smaller division needs so harder to meet customer expectations at times.  Company culture is mostly work at home and that suits many people, but others get away with not doing much somehow.  Very stressful during busy time of yr - people start getting nasty at times and feels like you can't please anyone.  Compliance heavy environment - makes doing anything difficult.  It is widely felt that annual employee surveys are a waste of time - mgmt does not really have clear action plans to improve things, but they are good at comparing benefits to other companies and then reducing anything that might be "better" at Aetna!  I think company feels working from home should make up for most shortcomings like high workload and medical plans with high deductibles.

job_title: Clinical Case Manager in Plantation, FL
pros: Very competitive salary, good benefits, dedicated team, charismatic CEO, great location, option to work from home offered (although not always feasible or available)
cons: High workload leading to long work hours, difficult to get promoted or move up from within (perhaps due to the nature of the business but finding a promotion has been very difficult)

pros: Ability to work at home. Learning, knowledge of new information and subjects.  Good coworkers. They are caring and supportive and willing to go the extra mile for each other. Salary is good but work hard and long hours including a LOT of mandatory OT for it.
cons: Rigidness.  No compassion. All about the Dollar. Poor leadership. Leadership who has no clue what Aetna policies and procedures are but will make up their own.  No respect. for employees. favoritism appointees of incapable workers and we all feel the results of this down the road.... Many co-workers with stress related disabilities.  Inability to take paid vacation time.

review_title: Talk to talk, but they don't walk the walk
pros: Good salary - if you have a good manager, you are rewarded.
cons:
Things were great when I started here, but then we got all new managers and it's been all downhill since. Company values and code of conduct are supposed to be important and upheld. However, it seems if you are high enough up, you can violate those and get away with it...so the values and code mean nothing. Also, picking favorites who are not qualified to take on their extra duties are chosen.
Also, worst health care benefits I've had.

pros: Great benefits,  flexible schedule, employee health incentives and benefits. Many avenues to move up and around in the company, you just have to work hard and prove yourself. Positive employee engagement around all business segments.
cons: Not an entry level job. Fast-paced to meet deadlines and submission. No guidance in the technical aspect, must reach out for assistance by networking or searching for someone. Must bring your own knowledge and structure to the table. There is a lot of work and little creative learning time.

review_title: Aetna is a  relatively good place to work
job_title: QA Trainer and Auditor in Blue Bell, PA
pros: Excellent workforce opportunities and careergrowth resources. HR was responsive to fairness and took care of  the employees even when organizational re-structuring was needed and severance had to be the case.
cons: Fairness in promotions was not always consistent. Sometimes management seemed to fall back on politics and or favoritism rather than true ability or performance record of the persons applying for the position. Company size masked alot of "goofing off" of some chosen for promotions.

review_title: Decent place to work but few FTE opportunities on IT side.
pros:
Very flexible work arrangements including part-time telework, decent benefits, good training.
The company has restored its reputation in the marketplace.
cons:
IT side is very metrics oriented which makes meeting the metric more important than doing the right thing in a project.

Consultant model followed within IT so even FTE's must charge project hours to meet the utilization rate metric.  Employees must work overtime to make up for vacation time and required training or risk missing the metric.   

The majority of IT workers are consultants so it is a constant knowledge transfer mode, some areas are 90% outsourced.

pros:
Ability to gain expertise in a highly-matrixed environment
Opportunities to move both laterally and vertically should you be qualified-desire a change
Progressive thinking in a move to a Consumer based product/service organization
Excellent succession move in elevating Karen Rohan to President-very shrewd operator
cons:
Too much focus on "prep to prep to prep"-its exhausting and adds no value
Paranoia on internal deadlines-being first is not always being right
Quarter to quarter orientation-dilutes longer term focus on internal program investments
Finance is the tail that wags the dog-wrong orientation-they are a service org, not the other way around

job_title: Data Entry Operator in Austin, TX
pros: Became an employee when company got acquired by aetna. Benefits were way better than the original employer. Medical insurance is very cheap. Yearly bonuses and raises, with a minimum pay of 16 an hour. Clocking in and out can be done anytime and they assume you will be truthful. Many positions are work from home.
cons: It's difficult to get a job with aetna. After being informed that my position was being elininated, I applied to multiple internal positions that I was qualified for (customer service rep, etc) but I was never considered.

pros: Lots of upward mobility, good pay, and good benefits in building (massages, lunch specials, healthcare, gym, etc...)
cons: Management varies wildly from department to department. I worked two different positions while I was there. I hated one so much I thought of quitting. The next one I loved. It was all in the managers I worked with.

pros: Supportive,engaging and transparent (as they can) management.  Great sense of team- other employees are very helpful. Good work from home program. Free on-site fitness center.  Good pay ,benefits and incentives. Company encourages and rewards  healthy lifestyle choices with money!
cons: The work spaces( both cubes and offices) are small. There is no cafeteria , and the restaurant in the building  is rather pricey. That's not Aetna's fault since it's not their restaurant,but it is somewhat inconvenient if you forget to bring your lunch on bad weather days.

job_title: Case Manager in New Albany, OH
pros: Work from home, no commute or dress code
cons: Work 60+ hours / week, no work-life balance. Your value is based solely on productivity metrics, not for your professional experience/expertise, teamwork, or other “non-numeric” (soft) skills. Management unwilling to help answer questions/provide support.

job_title: IT Business Analyst in Cranberry Twp, PA
pros:
Great work/Life balance
Team oriented IT group
We are encouraged to take training to better our skills or learn new ones.
You're rewarded/thanked for hard work
401(k) matching 
stock purchase program
cons:
A lot of contractors that can be hard to understand
Some projects are top heavy with project managers
health care plan could be better

pros: Great work/life balance; opportunity for growth; if your willing to take on new skills then lots of opportunities
cons: Unknown security with merger , raises are 2-3% and if you jump to new job maybe 5% as internal. They keep you below mid 50 and keep you on lower end. If external employee, they pay more to get the new talent.

review_title: Fast and intense but very rewarding. Learned and developed skills. Benefited from great mentoring.
pros: Good compensation. Exposure to high impact work and projects. Knowledgeable and competent senior management. Industry leader. Innovative culture.
cons: Health and retirement benefits not very generous, relatively. Though better than most peers, some of the red tape of large public company slows down some decision-making at lower levels.

review_title: depends on your business unit & skills  - can you find a niche?
pros:
if you are salaried & have a good manager, things are as good as they can be. It is a rapidly changing environment these days in this sector. However, if you have a dud as a manger, or are paid on an hourly basis, be prepared to return to kindergarten: Customer service reps literally have to get permission to use the toilet.

Assuming you are salaried, and have a decent manager, some units can be great to work for. It really comes down to how effective your manager is.  

If you can find a niche and do it well, you can prosper here as long as you know that each year your role will keep expanding...
cons:
Company is known for its IT spend, however, most of that  is dedicated to window dressing i.e. what the outside sees if they are looking in. Internally, best description is a home with a nice façade, but is actually a bunch of rooms cobbled together with spit & rubber bands. 

Health benefits are QUITE expensive,  only high deductible plans are offered. At times, seems there is too much of a big brother atmosphere, what with nurses/pharmacy management/etc  calling & sending correspondence to you.

There is a disconnect between some of the directors and reality - decisions are made without consulting those that actually have to do the work/ implement the change. Unrealistic deadlines are the norm given the slim staffing levels,  and impossible to meet with only a skeleton crew. 

Company purchases salary market data but it is not used past initial hire: if you stay with the company, typically merit is at 2-3%. Taking another job internally will not get you to market rate as salary increases are maxed out at 10% or less. The longer you stay, the further behind you will lag. The only way to "correct" your salary is to leave the company.... 

There is  a prevailing belief that IT personnel can be swapped/interchanged without impact. The truth is, it takes quite a bit to understand one system & its interfaces with a myriad of others, and you MUST  understand the health insurance business and its processes, then move on to understand how this company fits those parts together. It ain't pretty.  This fact has been ignored despite chronic missed requirements & defects. Most IT is on visa or offshore 

 Lay offs can be expected across all sectors at least annually,  or bi-annually.

pros: I have worked at Aetna for 9 years. There have been some good training opportunities. Also, the company is so big that there are many jobs internally available. I also like the work at home opportunities. 40% of the company works from home.
cons: very large company with very inefficient practices. Things that should take 5 minutes take weeks with all the forms and approvals and run-around that is necessary to make it happen. I feel like 80% of my time is spent on dealing with the machine and 20% of my time is actually doing work that is of some value.

review_title: Very challenging position that provided me the opportunity to use a wide variety of skills on a daily basis!
job_title: Senior Claims Benefit Specialist in New Albany, OH
pros: A diverse working environment that promotes integrity, collaboration, and accountability in its employees that builds upon the concept that individuals should be compensated for their hard work in order to be an industry leader.
cons: Personal growth is difficult to achieve given the lack of time provided to excel in your role and exceed performance metrics without experiencing some levels of frustration.

pros: For the type of work you are doing they pay pretty well. I found that my peers and co-workers created a good work community.
cons:
The management is very poor in their leadership and management style, specifically at the supervisor level. Their job is just to control for results rather than inspire high level great work. 

There is not much opportunity for career. Not much opportunity for moving into other roles.

pros: Salary was good and I worked with some great people.  Unfortunately customer service was managed by unqualified CSRs for the most part.
cons: Constant layoffs keep people worried about their jobs.  Each department was it's own island and very little cooperation from one area to another.  Often times promotions were done via popularity and not most qualified.

job_title: Clinical Care Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Great experience having gone from community mental health counseling to the world of insurance / Medicaid case management.  Supportive colleagues, direct supervisor was knowledgeable and approachable, and good pay overall, solid 401k + benefits.  Work at home flexibility was very nice, interacting face to face with Members and providing resources, help, and approving home care services made me feel like a valuable asset. a great step for me in terms of career development.
cons: Limited growth opportunities, job becomes very tiresome and exhausting.  Management provides some superficial support, but often has lofty expectations which are constantly changing and becoming overwhelming.  High discrepancy in terms of performance/competency of case managers within the department.  Once you find out your actual value, becomes readily apparent that 'value' is not fairly dispersed; promoting from within to another position is draconian and does not yield competitive market rate; result = poor good employee retention and preference over new hires who know nothing but are getting paid in spades "just because" while you are woefully underpaid.  Last, but not least, caseloads are extremely taxing and not evenly dispersed.  Some case managers cover nice relatively 'easy' neighborhoods and members who need much 'less' (i.e. nursing home Member needing to be seen once every half year) while others are left doing the "dirty work" of the Medicaid population -- out in dangerous, rough neighborhoods where medical and psychosocial needs are extreme; thus resulting in much more legwork as a case manager to link Members to resources, treatment, discharge planning, service reviews, etc.  Management appears to be oblivious to how mismatched and unequal this is.

review_title: Not as amazing as they claim to be
pros: They promote a friendly environment. Frequent food days, celebrations, scavenger hunts, ceremonies, etc. to boost morale. Most of the supervisors are nice.
cons:
Management is very inconsistent. You can get an attendance point for calling off (which is completely fair) but then someone on another team can call off and somehow slide by without getting a point. It depends on who your supervisor is. Some of them are buddy-buddy and play favorites, others are fair across the board, and others yet are very uppity and like to micromanage. Favoritism is abhorrently obvious. 

You are given way too much information to use on your calls, and have to be able to navigate several computer systems to find information, while keeping the hold time and after-call time to a minimum. You get dinged by QA for not following the ridiculous "Quest" mantra that they drill into your brain from day 1 of training. If someone calls in to simply pay a bill, you will get marked if you don't somehow empathize with them, paraphrase the issue, and summarize everything. Often times this causes members to become frustrated because they want to get off the phone. You are expected to take ownership of the call no matter how difficult it is, and you are not allowed to have time off the phones to research and call the member back. Task management and grievance teams are useless and will send your notes back with a coaching saying that you were wrong. 

Another glaring issue with this company is the lack of communication between the departments. Members are frequently transferred to you by a misinformed rep from another department and then become irate when you tell them you need to transfer them again. Reps in other departments are hesitant to take calls and sometimes will outright refuse to take them. When you call a mentor or helpdesk for assistance with an issue you sometimes end up with a very rude person who berates you for not navigating the massive policies instead of helping you. And this happens again and again, with nothing being done to fix it.

pros: The only good thing about this company is that they offer work from home positions.
cons: This is the biggest cluster of a job. There is no organization, no rhyme or reason for anytjing. ALL of the management staff are horrible. Caseloads are double what they should be. It's nearly impossible to get a definite answer to any question. The moral is very low and it's just not a good place to work. Very stressful. HR doesn't even take discrimination reports seriously. They tell employees to talk with management although it's management dicriminating! I would never recommend anyone to work for this company.

review_title: Ron is very strong and competent leader. However some of the other leadership is fine, nothing extraordinary.
pros: Great 401 (k), defined balance pension plan and other benefits (except medical, which is just OK).
cons: Company overall is conservative and slow-moving. Focus on execution is strong but agility and creativity are not strong suits.

review_title: Very positive, would like to return to the company after a few years in public accounting!
pros:
Great hours (you can set them), option to work from home for a lot of employees.
Not too grueling (from my side)
Company gym
Great cafeteria
Company campus is well served by public transit (a lot of bus links from neighboring suburbs = save money on commuting)
cons:
Can be a very sleepy place to work (which can be a major upside for some people)
I've heard that it can be hard to break from middle management to senior management.

pros: have some opportunity to WAH (depending on manager).  Changing to new virtualized technology.  compensation was decent.  Company paid 85% of health insurance premium.
cons: layoffs.  Not certain of full impact from Obamacare.  anual merit increase in the 2% range even if your work is average or above average.  So why work above average.  Placing more and more work on staff remaing after layoffs.  Good old boy network to get promoted and new secure positions.  Sr managers proctice nepotism over achievment.  Dead wood protected and kept onboard.

pros: Opportunity to work from home, also I was able to work part time while my kids were young.  The company provides lots of training to maintain a good work life balance.  There is a strong emphasis on getting and staying healthy.  Benefit package is good.
cons: Large corporation with all the red tape that goes along with it.  CEO makes 800% more thank I do, which is discouraging.

job_title: Clinical Care Manager in New Albany, OH
pros: Flexibility, work from home, nice coworkers
cons: I work for the Aetna Better Health of Ohio plan - "Aetna Medicaid" as we are often disparigingly referred to by the other plans- and so I can only speak to my experience working with them.  They are under the Aetna umbrella but undeniably the stepchildren and kept at arm's length.  There's the sense that we employees for this plan are being punished because Aetna doesn't make much of the people we serve.  Our population is more challenging and the requirements of our job more strenuous but our pay (by estimation) is about $10,000 per year less than parallel positions on the commerical side.  The pitiful insurance package applies to all but at least their pay is more than mediocre.  Our program is "new" though there was an extended time to prepare for roll-out and they use that as an excuse to have not effectively trained any of us.  As a matter of fact, we didn't meet any of our managers until the second week when someone went to get one because people were so upset at having been dropped in a room with no supervision and no explaination of what we were to be doing that people were on the verge of revolt.  We have minimal guidance and have had to all but outright beg for direction from our superiors.  The guidelines, on the rare occasions they are offered, change frequently and information isn't effectively disseminated so no one is ever sure they're doing the right thing.  When I contact my supervisor to ask questions I feel like I get an attitude for not knowing things they've never taught us.  Every day there are group instant messages and emails among the large group of us who were hired together, all of us trying to figure out how to do our jobs, and how to get what our members need.  Additionally, there have been continuous problems with getting the equipment we need to do our jobs.  Several months in and most people still don't have desk phones or printers.   Have I mentioned doing field visits with a flip phone from 2004?

pros: I learned so much during the 10 years I did this job there.   My immediate supervisor Darlene Bigden and the manager at the Denver office, Carla Haugen were awesome  to learn from and work with!!
cons: After being a precertification nurse which also included admission and concurrent hospital stays, and getting great yearly reviews for ten years, a decision was made to have only RNs do those reviews. This resulted in 6 of us losing our jobs.

pros:
Great mission 
Opportunity to telework 
Variety of work
cons:
Little advancement 
No clearly defined roles between leadership and rest of team 
Unfair compensation practices
Team members are interchangeable yet salaries vary drastically 
Typical corporate politics

pros: The culture at Aetna is great.  Very diverse workforce.  Pay is good. Job security is good. Opportunity to move within the company is great.
cons: Current health benefits are terrible. Merritt increase's can be low depending on company results, generally 2-3%.  Annual bonus is weak.  Everything depends on the entire organization.  If your segment does perfect, but company performance is not on plan, then your bonus will reflect that.  Work life balance is not balanced.

job_title: Utilization Review Nurse in Kansas City, MO
pros: Work at home, good pay, flexible schedule, once you hit three years your vacation time is great. Co workers really help you
cons: Little promotion mobility, upward movement, unstable staffing, assignment changes constantly, upper management blocks you from internal transfers, salary is hard to change with internal transfers even if you've advanced your education.

pros: Easy access to highway, close to food locations for lunch.
cons: A lot of politics, a lot of drama, managers do not like to promote employees, only promote "preferred employees" not by skills set or experience, but by who knows who.

pros: Can be flexible - though there has been a constant threat to do away with this flexibility at any time.
cons: Health care plans are awful. Its really hard when you need to use your health insurance and you hate your employer, bonus and annual raise process has changed this year for the worse - despite high profits and better than expected earnings, most employees were given min/no raise and very small bonuses, feel like you are always waiting to be job eliminated

pros: Benefits, Training, Knowledgable supervisors, advancement opportunity, great staff to work with. It's a great company to work for. The best I have worked for yet.
cons: Dental benefits if choosing a DMO you have to travel a ways to get the provider. It's cheaper but fewer dentists unlike the ppo plan.

review_title:

pros:

review_title: Great place to start off career with new skills, learn negotiating with clients, and develop time management skills.
job_title: Underwriting Analyst in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Laid back atmosphere with friendly people.  Always have enough time to complete your work and know deadlines in advance.  Get to learn Excel programming on independent projects and how to use various systems.  Learn how to organize, prioritize, and effectively use limited resources to meet client's needs.  Learn how to negotiate with tough salespoeple and develop communication skills.  Great training programs both online and internal company trainings with constant new systems, products, and processes to learn.  Get 3 weeks of PTO plus the usual holidays.  Have lots of mini team events like luncheons, birthday lunchs, appreciation days, and holiday parties year around with great food.
cons: Methodology in using systems and processes is not unified amongst different teams and regions.  Deadlines from salespeople with their requests fluctuates widely and sometimes there are very intense days where you don't have enough time to finish your tasks.  Sales people are not as educated on systems and processes that underwriting uses.  Some days there is nothing to do.  Work type becomes extremely repetitive and boring after a while.  Alot of filing involved and lots of complex systems to learn and remember.  Initial learning curve is very steep and have to constantly ask mentor questions since on the job training doesn't teach you alot of things that come up in the job.  Easy to get overwhelmed and confused in the many small little tasks.  Pay is pretty low as initial job requirements don't require skill in any particular field.  Company advancement opportunities are limited beyond current position to managing.  Once you figure out the workflow there is very little variation.  If looking for a business/analyst type job with creativity this is not the ideal job.

review_title: A good place to start out of collage.
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Hartford, CT
pros:
The interview is very easy because no technical questions were asked the entire time.
The work schedule is flexible.  I was able to show up whenever I wanted and leave whenever I wanted as long as I attended the meetings and I got my work done.
Every one is allowed to work from home, wether you need a couple of hours, a couple of days, or full time at home (from any state in the US).
Aetna offers free classes to help with personal/retirement finances.
cons:
Almost all of the people who actually do all of the coding and testing are based out of India.
Almost all of the project management, developers, and QA people are either consultants or from the outsourcing companies.  The team I last worked on started with 4 employee developers and 20 offshore developers.  When I left it was 2 employee developers and 24 offshore developers.  This makes collaboration and maintaining code standards near impossible.
IT at Aetna is a lot like working for a consulting company where the business department will ask you for a change to some application, you will cost it out, and then it is up to the people from the business department to decide if they want to move forward and pay for the change.  This means that there are no improvements to the code / infrastructure unless it is directly coming from a business department (or the application breaks).
There are few perks to working in any of the offices.  There are no free food / drinks, no free gym, no free recreation room, or useful services (to someone under 30)
You have to pay for parking in the Aetna owned parking lots.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Hartford, CT
pros: Tons of positive energy, actively seeking input from employees, Lots of resources and perks. Too soon to tell if it is real.
cons: It's healthcare, therefore regulated and chaotic by nature. Big company to change- energy at the top and energy at the bottom, but a lot of machinery to change in the middle.

pros: Paid training, Paid Time Off, Bonus Potential (performance-based), Pay, Wellness incentives
cons: Employees as well as Management can be unprofessional, HR is not  in the office- you must call an 800 number to file any complaints, PTO freezes/blackouts occur, Insurance benefits are not good.

job_title: Account Client Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Benefits are competitive and some of the other departments have leaders that practice transformation leadership.
cons: The Small Group Management team are clerical employees that were promoted to Leadership positions with this team. The Supervisor and Director are uneducated and lack leadership skills. They have different rules for different team members. They micromanage their employees and do not empower them to excel. I am currently pursuing an EEOC complaint against the supervisor who  is ignorant and does not have a college degree. The Director pulled her profile from Linkedin because she did not want everyone to know that she was a clerical employee without a degree.

review_title: Executives & leaders strongly support mission and values
pros:
Continual focus on making decisions that align with corporate mission and values, ensuring new initiatives are in the best interest of customers and members.
Strong work / life balance, with numerous wellness programs available.
Flex time and many telecommute roles (depend on level & responsibilities).
Culture is welcoming of diversity - in thought and personal beliefs.
cons:
Continual restructuring and job eliminations.
Given CVS acquisition (late 2018), culture and company structure may change over time due to new CEO.

review_title: If you are happy with just being the status quo, this is the place for you
pros: You will find some great people to work with and all are very intelligent. Employees get to review the manager and they rely on the manager/employee relationship.
cons: Lots of repetition of the same work that others are doing. Don't look to get promoted, they like to keep people where they are. Lots of consultants (aka, former employees). No communication.

job_title: Provider Service Specialist in Hartford, CT
pros: Flexible schedule, no problems taking time off, also great being able to work from home, great wellness programs for employees to participate in and be compensated and salary is ok can be better
cons: Management does not communicate well, alot of the times is who you know versus what you know ( alot of favoritism ) expect 80 hours of work and weekends for 40 hours of pay, and training for new employees is really bad,and they keep laying people off.

pros: Flexible work options. You can come in between 6-9 in the morning and leave accordingly.
cons:
Horrible benefits. Micro managed. Anytime you speak up you are basically penalized because you are in a production environment and they don't allow downtime
if you want to give feedback if you have a problem or can think of a more efficint way to
do things. Your boss will say, no one else has made an issue of
it. That's because everyone else keeps their
head down and does their work because they've leaned nothing ever changes and your production numbers will suffer if you do anything but process, even
if it's to make the workplace better. 

They have horrid turnover

review_title: Potential Opportunity at Aetna, but chaotic right now.
job_title: I/T Executive in Blue Bell, PA
pros: Pay and Benefits are very good.  Working conditions good.
cons: Culture has shifted from very focused and directed to many separate fiefdoms.  Enterprise planning and execution has degraded over the last 3 years.  Overall quality of employee work product and professional standards has degraded. Very uneven levels of top management level ability and leadership depending on the organization.

review_title: I thought I would retire from Aetna but that did not work out that way.
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Blue Bell, PA
pros: I moved up the ladder from application developer to middle manager. Salary and bonus were usually good. The ability to work from home was a nice perk.
cons: Work-life balance was always a challenge and taking time-off  Each year there was a fear of being laid off - even for good performers. Time-off policies changed over the last couple of years which capped off the ability to earn more time off.

pros: Many positions are workable as a work from home basis.
cons:
Managers are required to work from an office for collaboration reasons - yet the teams don't all work from the same office (and often work from home). The manager ends up sitting with other managers in an office for no reason.
Reorganizations seem to happen yearly - daily it feels as though your job may be on the line.

pros: There are several benefits offered that are not offered at most employers. They try their best make sure employees that are displaced from the lost of an account are moved to other existing accounts.
cons: The female managers are extremely catty.  There are directors and managers that manage employees and maintain personal relationships with them outside of work. This is an EXTREME conflict of interest.

review_title: Going down hill since CVS Health purchase of Aetna
job_title: Business Project Program Manager in Hartford, CT
pros: Aetna was a great place to work for many years the salary and opportunities for advancement were good.
cons: Since CVS Health purchased Aetna, all the advanced technologies that were implemented have been reversed. CVS does everything with paper trails, the hard work that Aetna did to advance in technologies have been ignored to follow an antiquated process that slows down progress.

review_title: Good company for everything except cash
pros:
*Flexible work at home options
*Great training classes
*Good career opportunities
*Good communication, they really go out of their way to make sure employees understand the goals & challenges of the company
cons:
*Raises are lousy, they are always highlighting that they "pay for performance" but don't tell you that you'll only get a 3-4% increase, even if you get the hightest rating on the scorecard.

*Promotions are rare and if you do get one, they combine it with your "merit" increase...on my last promotion received about 3.5% for yearly raise and promotion increase

review_title: no great  benefit for working for health care  provider

review_title: Makes promises to get you on, and then change their tune once you're hired.
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Fresno, CA
pros: I will have to say for a call center their hours are great. Monday through Friday, always with weekends off (for most markets unless you want to do OT). However there is very little over time to actually be had by the Individual Market. If you're used to getting paid less than $15/hr this will be a nice plus for you since they also offer ok benefits and at least a 401k plan etc.
cons: When I was interviewing with Aetna both supervisors told me that there would be the opportunity to work at home, for lots of OT if I was willing to work it, easy opportunity for performance based bonuses and great opportunity to move up- that they promote from within ALL the time. Well, fast forward to five years later. There hasn't been a work at home position since I started,  I am making maybe a few dollars more than I started (with getting a cost of living raise every year), rarely make a bonus (or the lowest tier bonus) because their performance metrics are almost impossible to meet, and I have had rarely any opportunity for promotion. (Both times it came down to myself and one other person, and the other person always won out due to experience). I consider myself someone who is extremely efficient, and have been told that I am one of the top CSR's in the dept. The  problem is that management is GREAT at lip service and giving you extra work to "make you look better for talent management" which really boils down to more work with no extra pay. I was super excited at the possibilities for working with this company, and am known for my skills and positive outlook- but after 5 years of continuous hard work and no recognition it's time to move on. I'm starting a job with another very well known company and I can't say enough how excited I am to LEAVE.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Wichita, KS
pros: Great benefits and paid time off. The hours are flexible and there is a great working environment.  Also a great work life balance
cons: Management is not the best they put expect a lot of work and provide little training,  Insurance is good but the premiums are high and the deductible could be a lot  better. Company is being converted from Coventry to Aetna will be a better place to work once that happens

review_title: "THE VISIONARY" day to day is not seen by employees
pros:
Working with some of the best "clinical staff "
Staff works very hard, under lots of stress and still KEEPS GOING.
cons:
Maybe Mark B. doesn't really KNOW or has ACTUALLY SEEN the process that the clinical staff goes thru each working day. The workflows, for some reason are quite tedious, and in my opinion extremely time consuming, from a standpoint where we could be utilizing our talents more efficiently. This is in comparison with some other "healthcare companies". 

Retaliation, still in minds of some employees, if there is any challenge, or questions. So most just go about the day, and chalk it up to , THIS IS HOW IT IS, so do the work.

"Metrics" are essential and necessary, BUT, at the expense of EXCELLENT CUSTOMER SERVICE, absolutely not !!!

Changes being made and or opportunities should be given to ALL clinical staff, from CM,IO /QA, UM .  Yes, it can be done.

review_title: Good place to work but little chance to get ahead careerwise
pros: Aetna pays well and the overall benefits are good.  The company is really trying to do the right thing when it comes to helping people learn more about how they can stay healthy and live a better quality of life.
cons: There's virtually no chance of upward movement/promotion. The company only gives lip service to professional development.  New positions and  job openings are most likely to be filled externally.

review_title: A Review of a Career at Aetna
pros: Flexible work hours, recognition for hard work, their locations and offices are usually in good neighborhoods, they pay well and recognize your skills with dollars
cons: they expect you to really work hard which is ok but they also will push into your family time if they believe you need to meet goals that require additional time

pros: Weekends off that's about the only draw to the job for me but ultimately wasn't enough.  Pay wasn't too horrible.
cons: You are trained in a room separate from everyone else for 4 months, then are thrown in the middle and split up from your training class, put in the middle of people who have been friends and co workers for years, if you don't fit in you don't get along.  The actual job is challenging in itself to remember all of the terminology.

review_title: Startup Feel in a Mature Company
pros: Aetna is putting a lot of emphasis on technology with the changes in health care.  This creates a great environment for creativity where forward thinkers can excel.  Truly an environment where you can see your work making a difference to the business and company's future.
cons: Like most jobs in technology, there can sometimes be long hours.  Other than that, I do not think there are any negatives.  Great place with great people.

review_title: Depends on perspective, but I had a good experience working for Aetna.  Well compensated with good benefits.
pros: I enjoyed being able to work with my clients with no barriers.  Plenty of time allowed to work with clients vs. some places allow only 10-20 minutes per call, we had 30 minutes +.  Work load was manageable.
cons: Differing management styles, while even on the same team. Technology was old and limiting.  No opportunity for advancement.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Hartford, CT
pros: Aetna is a solid stable company where you can change positions and even careers without leaving the company. They offer work from home, varied hours and opportunities to volunteer.  At one time Aetna was the best place to work,
cons: Home office now located in city, concerns they sold off other divisions which put all their eggs in one basket.

pros: Good benefits. Friendly people. Initially management very eager to welcome their employees
cons:
Cannot trust management; initially management held weekly "feel good meetings" on updating staff on new developments and discussing their work smart strategies. 
One of these strategies is to work smart -field case managers were repeatedly told they would be working from the territories surrounding their own home. A significant number of case managers were assigned territories several hours from their home with no explanation or apology. Management's response to employess was to suck it up.

job_title: Senior Software Developer in Blue Bell, PA
pros: Aetna is very creative in designing new products.
cons: Average benefits - Sr. management is interested in being an industry leader when it comes to products, revenues, profits, etc., but Sr. management looks to be competitive with benefits, not the industry leader.  Limited health care choices, which does not reflect positively on a health insurance provider.Long hours, reactive in problem solving.  Project budgets and schedules are always reduced but projects are usually over budget and behind schedule.

review_title: A very good but not the greatest place to work.
job_title: Program Manager in Blue Bell, PA
pros:
Good training resources available if you are self motivated to make use of all that is available.

Better than average benefit package; includes both 401(k) AND a pension plan.

Good place to learn about the healthcare industry.
cons:
Some areas have long work hours and this is all through the year.

Take home salary is above average, though some benefits like pension, tuition assistance and health care contributions make up a good chunk of the overall benefit package.

pros: It's really big and the benefits are fairly good
cons: It's all about the bottom line, so it takes forever to get things approved. Also the structure is so complex with business analysts and project managers, nothing gets done quickly, you get pressure to trim features from your projects just so the BA and PM can claim success.

review_title: Unorganized company that doesn't take good care of its employees.
job_title: Account Manager in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The company provided good salary.
cons: No proper training in any position. No support from management. No individual voice given to employees. No opportunity for growth within the company. Oddly enough, the health benefits offered and this "health insurance carrier" were not good at all for its employees. Employees are not a priority to this company.

pros: Aetna is a known brand and a growing company in evolving industry having completed two major acquisitions over the past 5 years.  Some areas of company are evolving faster than others due to strong leadership.
cons: Very conservative promotion of early in career talent.  Because company is saddled with MLR, ability to make enough profit to appropriately reward employees or take certain financial risks is limited

pros: Great management based on which department you reside in, flexible hours, 401k, WAH capabilities across US, and great values if followed they way they are written.
cons: Not many cons however management needs to step up and follow their Aetna way they created. The constituent deserves better as well as employees.  HDP stinks real bad need a better health insurance market as an employee.

pros: Flexible Work, Schedule and type.  Pay is on par if not better than others
cons: Old technology trying to work in the modern world.  Change does not happen fast..  Trying to think they are something they are not

pros: Great benefits and decent chances to promote
cons: conflicting leadership styles, inability to provide proper tutelage for employees, and inconsistent communication between the manager (and director) level and the frontline staff.

pros:
Pros:
- excellent health incentives and health reimbursement options for employees 
- excellent pay
- great team dynamic 
- free employee parking 
- telework option 
- telehealth
cons:
Cons:
- favoritism is apparent and blatant in my department. When a few employees are on the “favorite” list, it makes others not feel appreciated for their hard work 
- some departments work in silos which makes joint collaboration difficult

job_title: Senior Infrastructure Specialist in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: The company cares about the employees and gives them the opportunity to improve their health. Within the IT organization there are opportunities to grow your career. Employees have access to their managers and are heard.
cons: It is very hard to move up within the the organization, regardless of performance or talent

review_title: A great place to work- just don't let the whiners drag you down
job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in Allentown, PA
pros: Good benefits package (OVERALL) excellent supervision (I was in four different jobs while I worked there) and a company that seems to truly care about their employees well-being. There are all kinds of haters, and I could never understand why they hated it? They just wanted to complain it seemed.
cons: The actual insurance is not that great (irony, right?). The pay is par on scale, but (as always) could be higher.

pros: The company is very focused on maintaining a work life balance.  The company policies go above and beyond what you would expect.  Policies such as giving employees a $200 wellness reimbursement per year, having semiannual team outings covered by the company, and maintaining a laid back environment are all positive value added policies for the employees.  The companies management staff is also generally very laid back and nice.
cons: Sometimes Aetna can be too laid back.  The compensation package is generally less at Aetna than other healthcare insurance providers.

review_title: Unorganized for such a large company
job_title: Inbound/Outbound Queue Associate in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Coworkers were fairly nice, but there were some that were standoff-ish. Building is clean and new.
cons: Management is unorganized and seemed unprepared for growth. Tasks were given at a rapidly increasing rate, while keeping the same expectations for completing the previous ones.

job_title: Care Manager in Jersey City, NJ
pros:
-Work at home capability 
-Raise (merit increase) and bonus annually 
-Genuinely some good colleagues
cons:
-Management is disorganized and overly demanding 
-The more responsible you are, the more is dumped on you to carry the load of others that aren't productive
-Management is forever in meetings, rarely available for staff
-Communication between departments is limited to management which makes completing something relatively easy quite difficult
-Company would rather hire Temps rather than permanent staff, leaning on permanent staff to train each new team member

review_title: Great job but reorgs made it difficult
job_title: Learning Consultant in West Sacramento, CA
pros: Flexible work schedule, challenging work, great education benefits
cons: Constant internal reorganizations lead to significant knowledge gaps and poor management. Last year my job remained the same, but I had 5 different managers, each consecutive manager had less knowledge about what my job entailed.

pros: Flexible for working parents.  Currently hiring.  Stock price has been way up.  Bonuses are reasonably secure and awarded annually.  Pay is pretty good.
cons: Constantly changing.  Industry uncertain due to Washington DC.  Company suffers form something of an identity crisis as a result.  Strategy constantly changing.  New leadership brought in and turnover seems high.  Several repeated reorganizations.  Often have layoffs happening behind the scene n in small bundles so as not to alert the media.

job_title: Senior Underwriting Consultant in Hartford, CT
pros: Steady employment for many years. Great culture.  Excellent managers. Competitive pay and benefits, particularly the dollar for dollar (up to 6% of salary) matching 401k program.
cons: Salary increases could be low and slow unless employee wants to, and is fortunate enough to keep being promoted.

review_title: Micromanagement + no resources for employees to do their work
pros: Decent work-life balance and fairly nice people.
cons:
This company believes in short-term cost savings with no regard for long-term professional gain.  

They don't have basics like tissues or coffee in their offices; to get a company-issued phone is practically unheard of and they expect you to use your personal phone and data.  They don't treat employees like they value them or their work.

review_title: too much outsourcing, left with no action or answers
pros: Pays decent, one team member great to work with
cons: Too much outsourcing, non consistently with HR and benefits, which do not communicate with payroll too many mistakes, IT all outsourced do not follow procedures for properly identifying alike names, which causes lack of raise, abuse by non compassionate supervisors. It's all a click environment sadly

pros: Good pay, benefits and bonus.
cons:
There is no work-life balance here. I was always working weekends and putting in mandatory overtime. 

I started working here in 2014 when Coventry was still a separate Med D sponsor. Aetna bought us out and things were fine for a while till CVS came along. Everything has only gotten worse since about 2016. 

If you enjoy being micromanaged and treated like a robot, by all means, Aetna is the place for you!

review_title: Getting better under Mark Bertolini, but still a ways to go
job_title: Claim Benefit Specialist in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
They seem to be taking a new active interest in creating avenues for employees to give their feedback. Who knows if they listen to it or do anything with it, they still need to improve on their communication. 
I think they are positioning themselves correctly by being more open to things like social media. With HCR, the market will shift to a consumer driven one, and we need to be accessible to customers. 
They have many different employee resource groups that I learned a lot from!
cons:
I really enjoyed my job, but I had to move to help care for an ill family member. They used to have an office in my new city, but they closed it and sent everyone to work from home. Of my unit of 20, I was one of two who worked in the office. 
Frank Cobbin, one of the leaders in my reporting line, is more concerned with percentages and numbers than employees. Currently, more people in his reporting line work from home than he likes.... so he stopped allowing telework positions. He stated that people didn't want to take promotions if it meant returning to work in the office, and that the people in the office missed out on learning opportunities because they sent their best and brightest to work from home.

In a town hall he agreed working from home was great for employee retention and it was something people considered a benefit, much like insurance, because of the added value working
 from home brought. This company doesn't offer the richest benefits otherwise, and flexible work arrangements were one of the few incentives.

I was one of the top performers in my unit, even though I had only been there two years. I always went above and beyond my job description, and my supervisor never had anything but amazing things to say about my work during our one on one meetings. I wanted to keep working there, my manager and department wanted me to keep working there, but because of upper managements inflexibility and seeing employees as numbers instead of people, I had to end my employment with Aetna.

pros: I like the flex time so you are never late, I like that I can do my job with a supervisor standing over my shoulder
cons: The health insurance sucks,  deductibles and coinsurance is too much.  I been working her for 6 years and every year Aetna cut our health care benefits.  We are forced to use online pharmacy for chronic illness and there is no discount.  If you go on sick leave aetna stalk your doctor with faxes and letters.  My doctor is tired of getting letters from Aetna. Aetna work at home program is only for the selected few.  Oh and supervisors here aetna can not keep one turn over is high.  The  managers that they do have lack training some have never paid a claim.  Aetna recently in last 3 years hired kids to work smh, all day long the kids walk and talk like on a picnic.  I been working at Aetna for 6 years, and watch how benefits are taking away.  Aetna use have private food vendor in the past years come in  and sell food, but now aetna cafe which is not good and price is very high.  Aetna had a gym that was free to everybody but not it is a fee to use.   I work in the claims department and it is so unorganized and nobody can answer a question.  I  believe the  claim flow is organization is crazy.  Aetna seem  to think cross training is the way go, but cross training make lot late claims, paid wrong claims, and inventory high.  I like my job but tired of having to work other plans and than our plan is behind. I feel like aetna does not care about employees being happy, cut our benefits, took away food vendors, and no  leaders on floor.  Oh I almost forgot you have take a lab test to get discount on your medical premium too much control for me.

review_title: Geared towards people with a college degree
pros: If you search for it, movement is possible to a small extent, I like flex hours, however this is not available in all departments,
cons: The company is geared towards people with a college degree, unfair pay increase practices when accepting a "promotion" within the company, no matter the difference in pay between positions they will only pay you up to 5% increase in your current pay. So even when I complete my college degree and was "promoted" into a different position that was listed as a $30K more a year than my current Aetna job, I would only get that if that I quit and then went back to the company. MAJOR  letdown considering I have been with the company for a decade and quitting would mean a substantial loss in PTO.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Various schedules to choose from, personable and down to earth supervisors, pleasant peers, adequate working environment
cons: Quality audits are not consistent and score varies too much based on which auditor listens to your calls, job can become tedious and repetitive quickly leaving one feeling unfulfilled and complacent,

review_title: Excellent work at home RN  clinical care manager/American Health Division
job_title: RN Clinical Care Manager in New Albany, OH
pros: Flexibility, great support staff, the best orientation ever! , generous raises and ongoing educational opportunities
cons: I have no negatives, You must be very independent and enjoy working alone at  home on computer and phone.

review_title: A place to hang your hat for awhile.
pros: Quite a diverse culture and Sr. management pushes for fairness and communication; opportunities are there in a professional setting, it all depends on your manager.  Work at home options are available.
cons: tremendous politics with Sr management, direction may get lost because of that.  There is concern that team and support is just rhetoric as there is a lot of position shifting and outsourcing that is continually occurring.

review_title: Good People,   Good Strategy  Strong Management
pros: Overall strong strategy and reasonable communication from Upper Management .  Strategy directed towards consumerism is sound. Resources directed to ACO areas makes a lot of sense.Work balance is good and encournged to take time off and to grow through . Plenty of training opportunities
cons: Continued layoffs and tough to move around.  Insure that metrics for how effective middle management is from an innovation and alignment perspective are in place.

pros:
Flexible schedule, telecommuting available, good management. Good support structure to resolve any issues that arise with repercussions.
Room for movement to other parts of the company and encouraged.
cons: Salaries are a tad below average. The software training is a little lacking at times, you must figure out things on your own. Telecommuting full time takes away presence with management as well.

review_title: Toxic corporate culture that inner circle protects vehemently
pros: Nothing you can't get at any other major corporation
cons: Dysfunctional leadership that doesn't communicate. People at all levels are fired regularly throughout the year for trying to change the status quo.  Recently they tried to launch a Consumer Division, and the entire leadership team in that division is dangerously passive aggressive; they have expelled some key intelligent leaders that were trying to do the right thing and be innovative. Watch out - don't take any jobs until after the Humana merger, and hope things will change.

review_title: Penny wise Pound Foolish; It's all about the "New "
pros:
IF you have a team of knowledgeable people & a manager experienced in virtual team management, Work from Home opportunities.

Benefits are on par with competitors
cons:
Despite obtaining market information, long-term employees salaries are not kept current - posting to another position does not even allow you to gain back market value: salary increases are limited to a maximum. If you were kept beneath market for many years, even a change of position will not bring you up to the current market value! 

End of year 'performance ratings' are a joke. Your Manager can rate you as a top performer, but when "calibrated" your rank can be reduced to fit an artificially pre-determined bell curve. This is real problem if you are a member of a small team. Merit raises are based on the rating number, so instead of really rewarding talent, it is actually viewed as a  mechanism to hold payroll aka SG&A down. 

Despite job scope increasing each year - no promotion, no significant increase in salary, no increase in staffing- ever. Always do more with less.  Little investment in employee morale, or the opportunity for virtual teams to meet once per year face to face. Managers do not have sufficient funding to hand out meaningful discretionary awards to top performers, and often dip into their own wallets in order to show appreciation.

Artificial Dead lines are given without regard to available 'resources' aka staff aka PEOPLE- task may require 30 FTEs to accomplish within the deadline handed down from on high, but there are actually only 9 people qualified/experienced to do the task. No regard paid to the toll exacted upon these few: no special bonus or acknowledgement for them when the deadline is met. 

Acquisition & Integration work is handled OVER & ABOVE existing day to day responsibilities. Obviously, zero work-life balance. Because of the bi-annual job elimination cycle, people work to the point that it affects their health out of fear of losing their job in the next round of eliminations. 

Forward facing departments seem to have a glut of employees, yet those that actually keep the ship afloat haven't had approval to increase staff in years. Something is wrong...

IT is mired in process & protocol with multiple sign-offs, bringing no real value. The number and frequency of  these approvals causes the Approver to simply sign-off without review, defeating the purpose. It feels as if the IT process does things just to check off a box. 

System enhancements are costly, even with most IT handled off-shore. Again, bringing no value except to the quarterly bottom line: the off-shore IT lack the associated business knowledge to perform robust testing. Some systems now look like a patchwork quilt - but no central document exists to show what it began as and what it has evolved into. Even offshore IT rotate out regularly, netting no continuity of IT system expertise.  Many decisions are punted to the business initiative owner, who may or may not understand the needs of other interfacing systems....

With each acquisition, the acquired personnel are assimilated into positions and salary bands above those of the long term aetna employees. Often they are artificially promoted to  Director/VP, having zero knowledge of the particular aetna system/process/or policies - yet the position calls for shaping direction/decision making; net result is they rely heavily upon the existing aetna staff to educate & guide them i.e. existing staff actually does the work, and they rubber stamp it/present to upper management.  

Decision was made to move phone lines away from land lines to VOIP- despite varying carrier speeds affecting call quality. Voices are unintelligible too often during meetings, affecting productivity. However, no exception process was rolled out - basically it's VOIP or nothing: pay for your own reliable land line to do your job efficiently, or face job elimination.

review_title: Good PTO and work life balance.
pros: PTO, WAH, flexible hours, supportive supervisor, matching 401k up to 6%.
cons: no room for advancement, very poor compensation - they will demote your current career level without notice, making a salary freeze by doing so.  They say they want to retain talent, yet everything they do makes it appear otherwise. Give raises not based on performance, but only to ensure employees are all paid the same regardless of quality.  Very poor options for health insurance, and not much coverage in any plan.

job_title: Senior Customer Service Representative in New Albany, OH
pros: Great starting salary with the possibility of earning bonuses. Outstanding PTO and benefits.
cons: Vast amount of information to learn and very fast paced. Average handle time per call is low so hard to meet the stats they require. Hard to move up that ladder because many internally apply for the same job when one opens up.

pros: Telecommute options for many roles, fabulous coworkers, not bad PTO.
cons: I've never seen a company so disconnected from not only their front line workers, but each department is as if they're different companies.  QA, education and nursing are advarsarial to each other; they forget they're all on the same team. Recent new programs merging with other programs that weren't running well without direction or leadership.  Management are nice but aren't kept in the loop,  therefore cannot help staff. Zero support anywhere except coworkers left to figure out how to work.  More work, higher level acquity of patients and less pay. No more annual raises even though promosed; merit based bonuses that are structured for people to fail. New hires told they'd get raises even though company announced no raises before new hires brought on . Morale all time low . Chaotic and overwhelming.  So sad . I love being a nurse but I dislike what healthcare has become.

job_title: Claim Benefit Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros:
Decent benefits (With employer contributions to HSA and discounts on health premium if you pass metabolic testing)
Decent pay
Yearly bonuses
PTO
401k
cons:
The culture is do more with less, employees are NOT given the proper access and systems to complete the tasks assigned to them. As employees leave the department they are not replaced (unless they are part of the call center side of the dept), their work load is given to the remaining employees causing them to feel overworked. Senior management is very much focused on a system that tracks "adherence and idle time" , instead of focusing on WHY the MAJORITY of the department is failing in the systems eyes. That should be an indicator of the system obviously not tracking properly and the reps not having the NECESSARY tools to achieve the expectations.  Director and Manager are out of the office constantly for days and sadly weeks sometimes, in my opinion managements attendance is just as important as their employees attendance. Management does not have a true grasp of what their employees do and how the work is done. Instead of micromanaging, they need to get their hands dirty and  fix the issues that hold back the department and that is truly one of the biggest CONS of the reimbursement department at Aetna Specialty Pharmacy.

Also you are hired under a broad title of "Claim Benefit Specialist", this means they move you around as a lateral move when the department needs. You can either be a medical collector, a call center rep, a medicare representative, a cash poster, a medical biller, a copay assistance representative. MANY times you end up wearing a few of this "hats" at a time.

review_title: It's a job but not a career.
pros: Job security, weekends off, paid holidays, PTO time is nice... they are good with the amount of time off they offer their employees.
cons: Not competitive in pay and benefits. The amount we pay for benefits is outrageous for working for the company and pay raises don't even keep up with cost of living. This past year my raise was $800 and that is with a good feedback review.

review_title: customer service related teams,  sales support , medicare depts
pros: Good company I worked for 10 years layed  off in 2008
cons: Company shows no loyalty to their laid  off employees to hire back even after 10 years, its about their the bottom dollar, rather then hire someone trained in their systems with a good report, their hr recruiters looks at outside experience first instead of a loyal trained person executives need to tell recruiters we  care about their layed off employees and their future .

pros: I worked at Aetna for 7 years and found it to be your average corporation cube farm.  The pay and benefits were okay, nothing special and most of the employees were about what you expect to find in most large corporations, some good some bad.
cons: The size of the office was continually shrinking the entire time I was there.  It started out with 2 floors full of people and was down to under one when I left.  There wasn't a lot of inter-departmental interaction.
